full_transcript: hey everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd looking really creepy in this harsh light hmm and just want to let you know that there's a new track that I want to point your attention toward the new st. hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busy I'm Anna and it's time for a review of the new future of the left album how to stop your brain in an accident future of the left is a very cheeky experimental rock band hailing from the UK and this is their fourth full-length album and unfortunately they're one of those bands that is slightly haunted by the successes of their past or more specifically these successes of guitarist and vocalist Andy Falcon who was actually in a band preceding future of the left called McCluskey he used to front them as well and they dropped a couple pretty essential post-hardcore albums in the mid-2000s McCluskey disbanded but it didn't take Falco long to reform things under this future of the left name with Jack Eagle stone the band's drummer and right now they're currently working with Julia rueake and Jimmy Watkins and even though the band name and the band lineup that Falco and Jack have been working with since the mid and early aughts has changed the focus has still remained on post hardcore music noise rock and indie rock with driving bass lines wild noisy guitar phrasing and riffs and lyrics and vocals that are pretty eccentric now future of the left's debut had a lot of the same rawness that McCluskey used to have but the band's ambition brought them on to their next record hoping to make something that was a little bit more refined well recorded dynamic and diverse but the band's experimentation and ambition continued on to their next LP but maybe to a degree where it felt like more songs on here we're kind of losing their rock edge in their aggression especially with more keyboards and softer tracks kind of coming into the picture still this album featured roughly the same personality that's always made the band appealing and it is worth checking out if you're new to future of the left however with this newer LP of theirs which is actually the result of a successful crowdfunding campaign the band brings that rock edge back in a really hard way with some songs that are future of the left's heaviest tracks yet the very first track that kicks this entire LP off is one of those songs with incredibly low-end driven and jagged guitar riffs that are just jutting in between stints of silence sounds like something the Melvin's would have hammered out in the 90s with a very very sludgy finish with a lot of these riffs ringing out instead of playing in this very hard staccato fashion and of course even though the song feels very Melvin's inspired it does uniquely ring out as future of the lefts with just how off-kilter the riffing is and of course the vocals more heavy sludge kind of comes through on the song future child embarrassment matrix however this song is not really a highlight for me outside of how weirdly sexual the lyrics are just because I don't really find much of the singing or the very monolithic riffing to be all that catchy or memorable though it does stand out on this record and does bring this thing some variety sonically the sort of contrast these heavier spots future of the left does bring some very fast nimble catchy tracks on here very well crafted concise and clever little rock tunes with a lot of personality like the track Johnny Borrell afterlife whose choruses maybe one of my favorites on here just a boy just a boy I just know boy with this start/stop syncopated riff on the verses and again very very very cheeky vocals and lyrics there are some misses on the sweeter side of this record though like the male gaze which really kind of feels like a Pixies tune with Falco's vocals on top of it and then the real meaning of Christmas another very fun song melodically and very straightforward and accessible but to me doesn't really stand out as bold or interesting on this album simply because of how weird every other track surrounding this song is aside from that I love songs on here like Donnie of the Dex a killer track with another catchy chorus he was good with a very snarky verses that depict the life of this DJ character and the song has a really absurd refrain toward the back end the stink of sex is undeniable and then there's the song things to say to a friendly policeman which has this killer killer kazoo melody on its chorus there are just so many songs on here that are catchy and aggressive rock tracks with loads of personality and quirk like the two track Sahn here that are obviously very strong pieces of entertainment industry satire like singing of the bone saws which is this very properly delivered piece of spoken word on top of a very grimy bass guitar riff talking about how the music industry is tricking you into being excited and making you be afraid of missing out and then there's the track how to spot a record company which has one of my favorite refrains on the back end of the track how does bad does bad alright with a bunch of somewhat bitter just angry lyrics throughout the track about disappointing labels and disappointing fans and might have been a little bit of a reflection upon some moments in the past of McCluskey or even feature of the left and there are some real left hooks on here too like the somewhat teary-eyed and absurdly worded french lessons which is a kind of a soft willed indie ballad that that i like a lot and there is the song something happen too which is dreary as well but also switches between moments of very sad piano and bass and then these joyous guitar chords playing against people cheering it's one of these moments where future of the left is not only great at playing with sound sound play but also mood play with how the song really transitions from being oh - ah in a matter of seconds and the clothes are on here another acoustically driven track and I do like the tone of it a lot especially with Falco's vocals as lyrics kind of just seeping out between what what sounds like clenched tea and I do love the ending on here - with the harmonized vocals and just how together and joyous and celebratory they sound but this song to me is an example of an issue the future of the left has at times that is drawing out moments for a long period of time that are just not that interesting because I can't say I'm totally in love with the faux back woods dirty down country guitar playing that's on this track it does get kind of stale before the band even gets a chance to add extra instrumentation to the mix still despite those complaints I do feel like this is a great record from future the left one of the better rock records of this year this album has sharp heavy very raw straightforward and dry production that I like a lot is just clear as a bell very good playing an execution on this thing and this record has some great lyrics and personality and vocals which really has been the most consistent element of future of the lefts career in terms of quality really the worst thing about this record is that some of the songs on here just pale in comparison to others but there are 14 tracks on here and none that I really strongly disliked I'm feeling a decent too strong 8 on this thing transition if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana future of the left forever

hi everyone Antoine Fandango here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new childish gambino album because the internet childish gambino is the stage name the pseudonym of actor writer singer songwriter producer donald glover who you may know outside of the music world for his role in shows such as 30 rock or community from his stand-up - and a bunch of other things he's been dropping musical projects for years but he sort of reached this peak of attention with his 2011 album camp which was one of my least favorite albums of that year I don't really want to talk about why and even though there are a lot of people that hate that review and hate me for that review I was not anticipating the same level of dislike from this new record of Gambino's because there were some banger beats and tracks on his royalty mixtape that I thought were pretty good he had a feature on chance the rapper's latest mixtape that I thought was decent and there were some songs that dropped before the release of because the internet that I thought were enjoyable I thought that I would be in for a bit of a mood change on this new project of Gambino's and for sure because the Internet is a very different project from camp however this record is not without its baggage or its hang-ups though for one this LP does kind of come along with a 72 page screenplay which sort of seems to be the narrative which this album soundtracks so while I don't think the screenplay can be completely ignored because the screenplay and the album run is such a close parallel I still ended up being really underwhelmed by what was going on in this tale which wasn't really much of anything we essentially follow the exploits of a silver spoon protagonists truck with this general feeling of malaise and depression which there's never really any explanation or justification for throughout the whole story we're just supposed to accept that he's sad and there's never a point in this storyline where the reader is actually influenced to care about why the protagonist is so sad or depressed it's not like his negative worldview when loneliness brings a special perspective to the table that lends some insight to the reader and it's not like his sadness or his depression is uniquely interesting either as far as I could see all the issues he's dealing with are some of the same issues we all deal with the only thing happening here is that he's handling them in a really ungraceful manner so because the characters and the dialogue and the emotions are so shallow and boring and pointless we're sort of dragged through a series of disorienting plot shifts that follow very little logic and leave more questions than answers for one the boy and his group of friends witness a robbery at a burger place and the protagonist also witnesses a shooting outside of a nightclub which his friend mysteriously leaves him outside of to just hang out by himself seeing some of this violence just makes him go to Oakland to see this girl that I think he used to be with then there's a point when his dad just dies who's actually supposed to be played by Rick Ross so says the screenplay which is really the only legitimately depressing thing about this characters life from what I can tell but after his father dies he has to head to Sweden to claim the ashes where he actually has a fight with the guy who wrote what does the Fox say and then toward the end of this thing spoiler alert he just up and decides to become a drug dealer and then is like shot in one of the next scenes the whole screenplay really reminded me of other independantly film movies that I had seen recently like tim heidecker's a comedy or that new michael cera film crystal fairy and the magical cactus movies that also center around these kind of young careless but emotionally distressed main characters and we follow them on an emotional journey of a very short distance and while these movies for sure are character portraits and I think they work best as character portraits they're very boring and kind of inconsequential as stories and that is especially the case for because the internet even though a lot of people do seem to be kind of interpreting this thing as a social commentary on social awkwardness in the Internet age but for me that is a far stretch either that or the social commentary here is not really carried out that well there are instances in this script and on this album where things like trolling and WorldStarHipHop are brought to attention people using the Internet to treat other people like garbage or gawk at the dark underbelly of mankind but still even sort of important issues like this feel like mere subplots or footnotes in this screenplays unjustified despair and lack of drive not as a script but as an album because the Internet is way more interesting for one it features way better production than what was on camp there are tons of trap influenced beats a lot like what landed on royalty but a lot more melodic more interesting textures - like on the song crawl with the female vocal samples and the killer kick drums the very lavish keyboards and the string sections on this thing and the multiple beat change ups on this track it's really surprising and beautiful instrumental beats like this right now I feel like are the perfect sound for Gambino's music because they're aggressive they're heavy there's a lot of bass but the synth leads and some of the samples make things playful or kind of silly enough for him to put forward these ridiculous punchlines he usually works with I'm glad that Gambino is starting to sidestep a lot of the pop rap sounds that were kind of played out on camp but I don't think he's in totally original territory yet there's so many things that occur on this LP that I think are mere variants of things that have been hot over the past year past two or three years for one most of the slow jams on this album kind of sound like a Frank Ocean b-side from channel orange and in my opinion the singing on this LP is not as good or as distinct as Frank's and neither are the lyrics either with some refrains on here like hold me close my darling or Tuesday afternoon ain't got to do befall in love with you which happens on the song shadow where Gambino is doing these really subdued raps against his singing and to me the song is just really overly sentimental its underwhelming a lot like the track Telegraph Avenue with the Oakland Oakland chorus I do like the fast rap verse Gambino spitz toward the end of this track but it's not so good that it makes me want to stick around for all this inconspicuous R&B style singing still I don't really dislike this track or many other tracks on here instrumentally I may not dig the song or the singing or the lyrics but the beat the beats are really where because the internet shines through I like on shadows the bass arpeggios which I believe are being brought by Thundercat the very cool calming vocal harmonies and the really distorted guitar riff that is just booming and buzzing toward the back end of the track it's really psychedelic it's a great progression 3005 the lead single from this LP it's not a song that I love but to me it's probably the best on here when it comes to this mixture of Donald's pop sensibilities and his hip-hop sensibilities they complement each other in this really cute little love song where the melody is undeniable yeah the chorus is a little rotten my teeth because of how sweet it is but I'm still digging this song a lot more than the slower more syrupy ballads on this thing which I think are just literally so boring that I want to skip over all of them so the instrumentals I do praise through and through but it's the lyrics and the songs on here that can be really really hit or miss for me like the song earth the oldest computer with its really ambitious driving beat and it's numerous synth layers but what Donald does here vocally with his singing and with his flow on here too I feel like we only end up hearing a less grandiose version of Kanye's lost in the world from My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy and then there's the song zealots of Stockholm with its numerous instrumental shifts it's really really linear it's really all over the place but only a very small amount of what actually happens on this track ends up being captivating or even memorable the few tracks on here that I thought were legitimately entertaining were the more aggressive ones like crawl and WorldStarHipHop where some of Gambino's punchlines I at least thought despite them being very silly are kind of funny like y'all be stirring like a broke guitar and I still put it down like the family dog or that one stop in the song worldstar we're gonna go put foam go put hello consistently over the course of this album in this script game you know is trying to give us this character who is this young well-to-do Rekluse who spends a lot of time on the Internet I guess that's what he is and I guess that's what he knows but I wouldn't say he's great at keeping that angle and keeping that persona interesting long-term though one of the best moments where he's in this characters on the song sweatpants despite the fact that Glover is 30 at this point in his life he is saying that he's a rich kid asshole pay me as a villain and there's some hilarious lines in this track - are you even though breakfast lunch and dinners for beginners you don't even know and I do think Donald does display the darkness of that reclusive side on the song no exit successfully the closer on here is really self-defeating but also kind of triumphant - which I thought was great kind of having this character struggle but the thing is this record is so so so dependent on this screenplay to be completely understood or I even think enjoyed just on its own they complement each other in a way the music sort of speckles some of the cracks left in the screenplay with how illogical some of these shifts are in the storyline but I guess the script brings this deeper character portrayal that the album doesn't necessarily have and the thing is this album kind of brings a different character personality trait to this boy individual at gambino is talking about in the screenplay because while this guy is very just quiet and food not really do much boudreaux the whole story there songs on here on this album where this character is very cocky and in-your-face and ridiculous I think there's a lot of potential in the amount of ambition that Gambino came forward with on the script and on this record and and how they come together but there are just so many completely uninteresting spots especially throughout the script I like a lot of songs on here that I think are legitimately good but I still don't like this LP as a whole I think Gambino brought great instrumentals to this record he's very conceptual he's a capable rapper but the lyrics on this record the flow of this record the songs on this record and the singing on this record tend to be very weak I'm feeling a strong five to a light six on this thing transition internet if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana childish gambino because the Internet forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busy banana banana and it's time for a review of the new Gustavo Stein album LF guys savage side is the pseudonym for a French electronic music producer who's been making the rounds over the past couple years with some singles some EPS some official remixes of artists like Lana Del Rey and he also helped produce a few tracks from Kanye West's latest album yeezus however his work did not really grabbed my attention personally until I heard the lead single from this debut album of his pursuit really this track a great combination of techno and house with an array of sounds that feel like they were produced in some kind of industrial facility there's something so metallic and I see about Casal Stein's production on this particular track more so than other techno music producers tracks like pursue have a killer driving kick snare groove but the sounds on this track also sound like they were sampled from an assembly line a thousand years from now in a future where our robot overlords have crushed the human race into submission definitely one of my favorite singles of this year with its dark vibes and undeniable bee tracks like this really had me looking forward to a laugh but I ended up being sort of disappointed by the final result not that there are highlights on here there are but the album is a little bit of an inconsistent mess the tracks on here that are great and play to gas offal Stein strengths are good but they themselves don't feel that varied and how they're executed or how he goes about producing them I mean pursues easily the most detailed and interesting of all the more hard edged tracks on this album then you have some softer tracks on here that I will get to later but there are a few songs on here that just kind of feel like unnecessary detours or distractions like the opening track on here as well as the track destinations songs whose beats are so basic in terms of progression they're just not that interesting from beginning to end and I feel like progression and maybe complexity was sort of sacrificed at the hand of having these really weird spoken word pieces thrown on top of the instrumentals that really are swallowed too much in Reaver and don't really grab my ear in any way shape or form in terms of how they sound or what they're saying really these two tracks are the most lackluster moments on this entire LP then there are the softer and more easygoing tracks on here which some of them are good but for the most part it feels like they only exist to serve as brakes or sort of interludes or spaces in between the more aggressive tracks on this album which is really a less bread and butter like the song nameless which has some pretty dreary keyboards or the track wall of memories whose keys are just as spaced out and Atmospheric but our little earier both of which are I mean good when it comes to bringing a mood to the forefront but they're not that engaging for the duration of their length and they're just a little middle-of-the-road really these songs don't feel anywhere near as passionate or as urgent as some of the more aggressive tracks on here again the song piece of future is sort of an exception to this rule it is a slower track but it slowly grows more lavish and intense as it continues on and then there's the song values which has some pretty sweet keyboards on and I love the groove that the percussion brings forward because it does feel a little craft work inspired the best thing on this album is definitely the bangers but I'm just not seeing enough contrast or perceived contrast among them to not feel like I'm hearing some filler or some redundancy especially with so many tracks here kind of following that type of pattern but really after listening this album goose offal Stein does sound like a very very capable producer the the sound quality and just the richness and the crispness of the sounds on this record deserves to be praised all day the audio on this record is so hard-hitting and just so sharp it's like just staring into a giant diamond however this diamond is not cut all - impressively goose offal Stein does bring some good grooves to the table however due to a lack of progression and variety he allows them to go stale very quickly he allows the tone of this album to go stale very quickly as well trying to balance out these very Sammy Sammy aggressive tracks with these softer songs that just aren't all captivating on the whole really I loved just about as many songs on here as I disliked and majority of the other tracks on here I felt were just kind of passable I'm really feeling a strong 5 to a 6 on this thing transition but if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that said Anthony Fantana gets offal Stein Aleph forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new era broad album self-titled this band is a norwegian rock outfit and their lineup has been a bit of a revolving door since they've been dropping releases in the early 2000s right now they seem to be functioning off of two core members who collaborate with a bunch of different musicians and noise makers and producers to create their records and i heard an EP of theirs that they dropped this year called murderers art had three tracks on it that were a bit of a mixed bag one was a bit of a generic sludge metal track one was an eight-minute noise piece and another was sort of a noise rock sludge metal combo that was 15 minutes long that had this sort of hypnotic repetitious thunderous riff approach not too unlike something swans would do the EP caught my attention and made me want to dive into the band's other records look back into their discography and I found that they came out with an album this year and it's like their sixth album and the sounds that were on these albums was pretty interesting in terms of just the stylistic influence combinations we're getting really heavy just BC sludge metal and some elements of noise rock - topped with some pretty eccentric vocals that vary from these deep guttural growls to these somewhat deadpan and nasally ah moans and some very hellish devilish snake-like whisper yes I liked the variety that the vocals brought to the table but still listening to these records back to back I kind of got this sense that era brah is the sort of band that slowly fine Tunes its sound over years upon years upon years rather than coming through with something completely radical and different with each new release a lot like a bands such as high on fire or The Melvins to a lesser extent both of which I know I'm sure her Arab rot takes at least a little bit of influence from especially given that they have worked with producers that have created some of the best albums from those bands people like Billy Anderson as well as Steve Albini so the years that this band has been spending on the heavier side of things has definitely resulted in them having a very aggressive and ear catching sound I wouldn't say the riffs on this LP are thunderous like they're raining down from the sky but they are pretty aggressive and they do bring the rumble the good of these characteristics is that the album is loud as hell and that the vocals are so weird and just off the chart when it comes to the general sludge metal sound that it's hard not to get caught up in the eccentricity that era brought brings to the table like the very throaty snide whispers on the opening track here that be nagged and if Noah is yes then there is the song throwing rocks at the devil which is maybe my favorite track on this entire LP has a fantastic guitar lead that feels sort of influenced by Middle Eastern music or music from the Eastern Bloc and just these really hard-hitting juts of guitar bass and drums just syncopated and the vocals are all over the map we have the very gruff growls screaming this fantastic hook and then shortly after we're getting these just nasally moans coming back throwing rocks at the devil it's a great track the bad side of some of these characteristics though is that the album is so boo me it is so boo me man like especially the drums and the drums do get to the point where at times they swallow up the vocals they swallow up the guitars and kind of cover everything else that's going on a lot like on the horns of the devil grow or the vocals here can get so weird that they feel a little silly and and kind of take away from the aggression of the song like blood on the poet which oddly enough is sort of inspired by a pretty odd French film of a similar title I do like the wailing lead guitars in the background on this track but man do the vocals dumb daughter go feel a little absurd and not necessarily in like a flattering way I do like that this band has some odd lyrical concepts though and while that's great it doesn't necessarily make up for what I think is this album's biggest issue and that is the riffs and the song structures not really being that interesting or adventurous I actually think a majority of the riffs on this album are pretty inconspicuous and and standard when it comes to the sludge metal sound especially the lead single on here blood on bunny which is maybe the most forgettable track on this entire album just because of how bland the Rivage is if the riffs are going to be this overly simplistic I wish they would come through with more tracks like drawing down the moon where essentially we we not only have these basic riffs but we have a bunch of noises and and sounds and sound play going on in the background just kind of keep things layered and engaging because this track is not only sludgy but also psychedelic and borderline disturbing with just how chaotic it is the horns in the second half of this track too sound fantastic and make this song sound really anthemic overall while I did like the odd vocals and I thought the guitars and the riffs on here were very visceral I thought the recording was heavy and there is some sound play on this self-titled LP for sure this record does have its eccentric moments but there just wasn't enough of a structural or a melodic or a musical appeal for much of what's here to stick with me and I mean we're talking about noise rock and sludge metal on here when it comes to melody I'm not looking for a whole ton I'm feeling a decent strong six on this thing transition if you've listened to this album what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana arrow brought self titled forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internets busiest music nerd and I am sitting here hoping to make what I think will be a pretty quick video about a concert I went to last night and Hamden Connecticut Rat King live forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new Hopson album nach madness Hopson is a West Coast MC who's had a pretty illustrious past couple of years with a lot of hot singles coming out through his ill mind of Hopsin series is a double XL freshmen alum he has a handful of projects right now under his belt and he has had a lot of success through his label funk volume lately too with some artists like Jarren Benton and dizzy Wright gaining a lot of attention and he really doesn't mince words or worry about what's going to be offensive to other people and that has pretty much gained him a very passionate cult following even if stylistically a lot of what he does come straight out of the M&M playbook Hopson just gets a lot from Eminem when it comes to flow and delivery and hooks and personality even the dr. Dre style production on some of the tracks from this new LP of Hobson's shows influence from Eminem's earlier albums and for the most part I do think Hopson does Eminem's really cartoony rap style justice he's a really animated MC is foul-mouthed bars can be pretty hilarious on some of the more hard-hitting tracks here however I'm not really saying that Hobson's brand of comedy is all that mature or clever or well-groomed he really kind of shoots for that cringe style of comedy in the you know you like I'm an animal a mink coat bitch wear me or I got balls like Ash Ketchum or I love Christ but I guarantee you wouldn't want to cross me or it's like having sex with a nun what the heck have you done this handful of lines only comes from a few tracks on here but believe me these songs are not really the exception on this album everything on here is pretty tasteless and the thing is that's not even really my biggest issue with him I think Hobson is really good and and capable as a nasty offensive giggle worthy rapper the issues that I do have with this LP for one lie with the hooks which I mean with Eminem being such a big influence on Hopson and hooks never having been Eminem's strong suit Hobson's hooks sometimes are really just nightmarish they're either sung in this really melodramatic tone that is hard to believe and hard not to laugh at like on tears to snow or dream forever or what's my purpose sometimes the singing is just really hand up in a way that makes it cringe-worthy like on old friend gimme back my oh man or I still got love for you where I mean really that the singing on the course is kind of excruciating or on jungle bash where you kind of have the call and respond hey yeah yeah yeah the hooks are one thing but when Hopson really starts to grate on my nerves is when he hops on some kind of moral high ground and tells the listener what's what a lot like on the song what's my purpose which is essentially a lyrical attack on the human race and Hopson is pretty harsh on the shortcomings of people and I think he has some points on here like people don't know how to act people don't know how to handle themselves there's all this monkey-see monkey-do stuff going on hivemind but the thing is what on this track or on this album in general makes Hopson a worthy messenger of this point of view or even somebody who can be a torchbearer to fix these problems or bring these problems to the attention of those who might actually try to change things there's also the issue that Hobson's views on romantic relationships are completely shot especially with the nice guy mentality on the song good guys get left behind not only is the song cringe-worthy because there's a Twilight reference in here but there are plenty of lines on this album that objectify women which kind of makes it hard for me to believe Hobson playing into that nice guy role but still it feels like Hobson is taking this nice guy mentality pretty seriously as he details this failed relationship play-by-play and the whole time he's just being really bitter because he couldn't get in this girl's pants because I guess he was just too good of a guy and the problem with the nice guy mentality is that they always blame their inability to get in a relationship on everybody on the planet but themselves and they always come out the hero too like when Hopson is saying that he's paying this girl's way who got pregnant from this other guy when he was planning on getting with her first on the song I still got love for you what nice guys fail to realize is that maybe they're not getting laid because they're insecure bitter whiny and boring I mean just take the really sick and desperate emotions that come through on the track dream forever on this album I can't imagine anything that would be a bigger turn off to a level-headed woman nice guys constantly blame their failures on women just having bad taste in men and they fail to even think for a moment that maybe their issue is that they have horrible taste in women and are bad actually gauging whether or not another woman is interested if they actually even get the guts to approach that person you know I don't want to doubt that life is unfair and I don't want to doubt that Hopsin has had some traumatic experiences in his lifetime but the way he puts his experiences into words just makes me not want to sympathize ever there are some tracks on here that legitimately I think are good I think are entertaining I think are fun like the lead single hop is back or give me that money a hilarious track with Hopson saying that all these new friends he makes are constantly trying to get money from him begging him for money because he's so famous and popular now then there is lunchtime cipher which has two of the more solid features on this entire album and has just a hilarious beat it's a great song concept rapping spitting bars at school between your friends and then there is hip-hop sinister which is easily the angriest most just frothing at the mouth track on this entire album and I actually thought it was it was great definitely a highlight on here but there are even some shortcomings on the more upbeat tracks on here honestly on this thing overall the production and the hooks are just weak weak weak and Hopson doesn't do anything with his punchlines his views on life or his personality to make up for that he's occasionally entertaining with how empty is and how zany he is and how he goes at other people like I love the verses when he was making fun of Kanye and Kendrick but he is way too obsessed with dropping jewels for a guy whose life view is just too bitter and warped to be taking notes from if you are copying off of Hobson's paper you are probably not going to pass this class I am feeling a strong three to a light four on this thing transition if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony fan tanto Hopson nock madness forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new demacia 6 mixtape the 6 6 the 6 commandments organized crime hate that you left that world in the behind I thought so too but I've still doubt that live em seen amazing de mafia 6 might be a relatively new name in the world of hip-hop but do not let this fresh tag fool you the mafia 6 is just a variation on the seminal southern hip-hop outfit three 6 mafia a group that has had some pretty sturdy hits in their career like hard out here for a pimp as well as poppin my collar and my personal favorite stay fly but now that the southern hip-hop sound is hot in the mainstream in the underground people are going back digging up old gems and the southern sound like three 6 mafia's 90s output their early contributions to gangsta rap in horrorcore like mystic styles now there are quite a few artists who are trying to bring back that old three 6 mafia Memphis rap style sound artists like little ugly Mane Halle Kamal space goes purp of course there's a huge influence from three 6 mafia and a lot of the ASAP mob stuff and now you have pivotal members of three 6 mafia coming back and reliving this sound as well gangsta boo crunchy black Lord infamous DJ Paul as well as coupe stuff and there are some very good features across this mixtape too like 8ball & MJG yellow wolf bone thug Space Ghost purp and little white plus plus there is a massive posse track on the back end of this LP that is about 9 minutes long and has a verse from Juicy J project pat and a lot of other familiar faces from three 6 mafia's past they even redo an older track of theirs on the selfie break the law with just a whore hitting catch your version of the classic 1995 cutoff of mystic styles and honestly it goes over really well and so do most of their attempts to bring their devilish sound back to the forefront now lyrically uh I'm not promising anything on this mixtape that's going to uplift you this is definitely not the kind of rap mixtape that is going to make you pat yourself on the back like I listened to a smart song six commandments isn't really an album that tries to impress it's more of an act of intimidation the verses on this record are really just like coming face-to-face with a junkyard dog with bar after bar after bar after bar on this record having to do with trappin cooking pulling triggers cold-blooded murder smoking mobbin pretty much every greasy thing in the book the only thing that keeps this album from being overly redundant is that every member of demacia six or three 6 mafia has such a distinct flow and voice and style the way the features are peppered throughout this album adds to the variety as well if you're already familiar with three sixes older stuff you know what makes each member stand out DJ Paul being gruff is hell gangsta boo always very cool charismatic as well as confident and being the only female member of three 6 mafia of course that makes her voice stick out too there's crunchy black who was incredibly animated with his deep voice Lord infamous who flows a little bit harder than every other member of the group from what I at least hear on this record and then there is coupes - who is incredibly creepy and eerie the production brings a lot of heavy sometimes over modulated 808 sand twittering high hats for rhythms there are a lot of dark minor tones synth leads and chord progressions and even though this record is pretty heavy on the since there are a lot of samples interesting samples that are looped throughout this muddy mix - like the Black Sabbath song God is dead one of their more recent tracks that pops up on the song better pray and the theme to the song Fame which is loop pretty quickly a little snippet of it in the song remember and again the sound on this thing the sound of the production the sound of the vocal recording it's really really rough at times I would say lo Phi and then blatantly so but still the production on here bangs it is Basie it is heavy the recording quality doesn't take any of the aggression away from these beats and even though you do have the backing of these hip-hop rhythms melodically a lot of these instrumentals just have the aura of a creepy slasher movie there's some really hard-hitting tracks on this thing like better prey and remember and Ben had hard which is one of the few tracks on here that has an awesome beat change up in the second half where coups too pops out of nowhere and get such a creepy and the song go hard whose title does not lie it's just this really grim southern hip-hop sound that deserves to be cranked with an incredibly catchy chorus which is nastily growled by DJ Paul's voice and that is kind of the approach that most of the choruses on this mixtape take however it is effective it is catchy it does lead to a lot of infectious tracks and there are some songs on here that tone it down a little bit and take a creepier direction stash spot murder on my mind and beacon in a blender which is blatantly a song about cooking drugs and dealing them and yeah just a slower track on here but still a memorable track on here and there are a lot of memorable moments on here this mixtape is just so goddamn raw punchy horrific and catchy there are a few shorter tracks on here toward the back end of the mixtape that maybe are not favourites for me but still this tape does not have too many shortcomings in my opinion even though it's not incredibly diverse in terms of sound or production or anything like that personally I don't really feel like this mixtape needs a moment where it makes me feel warm and fuzzy inside or something that I really need to contemplate because it's simply just so good at being tough-as-nails for sure this thing does have its limitations if I guess you're getting the mixtape version because you're constantly getting hit with the check daleks real trap shit and all the DJ paul interjections and there is even a weird outro track here where he is just mentioning this staying off all the social media of everyone in the group which actually did lead me to a YouTube channel where you have Paul doing a bunch of barbecue cooking but the songs themselves are an incredibly great grouping of just again dark dark violent southern hip hop music with absolutely no remorse and you know just really nasty scowl on its face feeling a light too decent ate on this thing transition if you've given this mixtape a listen what did you think about it and I have a new episode of my music video review show over the maker music channel you can watch it by clicking on my face right now also what do you think I should review next and did you love this album hate this album why and I hope you're having a nice day Anthony Fantana de mafia 6 6 commandments forever

feeling really good today sorry sorry just feeling good today it's all that's all that's all I can say that's all I can say for myself oh come on let's let's go sad sick currently right now is a new jersey-based music producer he has come out with a slew of different projects in the past but we're gonna but but but what we are going to be talking about now is this new self-titled full-length LP that is out via the collective resonance label and electronic music label that has a lot of beat music beat tapes on their electronic music very very forward-thinking and on the surface while this thing may not seem like anything more than your average beat tape on the internet though it is very dense with about 30 tracks in its regular track listing from what I understand you can get off of itunes or bport but if you grab this thing off of band camp for just a few pounds you actually get an additional 16 tracks added to the tracklist of this thing making the final runtime of this altogether about an hour and a half thankfully sad sick comes off on this thing anyway as a pretty versatile producer men not only are the beats he creates on this thing very dense with detail and layers and samples but his influences seemed to spread pretty wide as well while he definitely loves your underground Kings such as mad lib or J Dilla I for sure think that this guy's in the DJ shadow and even newer acts and experimental hip hop instrumentals such as flying lotus he is also I think pretty into neo psychedelic music such as panda bear animal collective stuff or even a little black moth super rainbow now this dude loves sampling so many tracks on this album loaded with samples he tends to layer them very heavily a lot of the time which leads to a lot of these sounds just bleeding into one another in a very psychedelic like display in a very trippy tapestry and the songs themselves sort of fade into one another to a lot of longer tracks here being somewhat well-developed and their book ended by the shorter moments that are maybe a minute or less that seemed to bring the album from one beat one groove one song idea to another I would say overall this album is very diverse set of purposeful odds and ends there are some hiphop inspired head bobbers on this thing like the track citizens sleepwalk a moment that opens this album up kicks things off with a very jutting bass drum groove this guy is fantastic at engineering bass the bass and really everything considering how dense these productions are is so well mixed crisp everything is really defined so despite being overwhelming some of the time I would say a lot of the sounds here are impressively organized because as citizens sleepwalk progresses we have these choppy vocal samples these crispy snares that come into the picture as well as some handclaps and then on top of it melodically we get these swirling organ arpeggios in this very just epic somber bass line that is moving so slowly and it takes the track from being just sort of a quirky hip hop beat to something that's really grandioso so so so and while there are a lot of really great punchy psychedelic cuts on this album that I think are great the latter half of this abridged version as it continues through we sort of get to hear the darker side of sad sick the more tender side of sad sick the more experimental atmospheric side of sad sick with the league of tracks that some of them are really atmospheric and cloudy and feel a bit like a drone or kind of like floating through a dreamworld some tracks like night phantoms still a beat but very very nocturnal and dark and eerie there's the title track on here sad sick which is sort of like this really weird noise wall with a beat happening in the background and some mumbled spoken word not a favorite moment of mine on here but I guess it does show some diversity of sad sick just trying some different things some of which go over really well some of which feel a little boring however nothing happens on this album for so long that it makes me want to flip the track or really angers me however there are tracks on here that I do wish we're longer that's kind of the double-edged sword of making a bunch of tracks that are so short and lumping them in a bunch while there are tracks on this thing that do feel like filler there are tracks that for sure are not going to hit you because you just may not find anything special about them there's no denying the level of ambition that is going into this thing because of how long it is overall and how diverse the songs are together while I don't feel like this album comes together as a cohesive whole there is something about sad sick kind of going into this project making sure there's at least a decent noticeable amount of variety among these somewhat short cuts I'm going to leave a link down there in the description box to check this album out transition and if you've given this zishan if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it really what did you think of it and what should I review next Anthony Fantan oh sad sick forever
