hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new quality Chris album ghost at the finish line this guy is a Detroit rapper songwriter producer he crafted a few of the instrumentals on Danny Brown's triple x-- mixtape and he has a handful of projects out two of which have dropped this year this is the second of them quali chris is an odd dude however I don't think of him as being so strange that I would lump him in with other art rappers such as open mike eagle or bus driver or milo i don't really think he is a meme rapper either or simply absurd and his delivery is far far far from aggressive however I would not call a comatose boring or listless either he's a guy who's just very very chill however his words are very dense with wordplay or deeper meaning or personal introspections or just straight-up weird jokes he's really an equal balance of thoughtful playful and serious there are moments where his music really reminds me of Danny Brown or MF DOOM or mos def push a tee or maybe even like Das Racist I think there are a lot of artists out there that have similar qualities right now to Chris and to me that means potential fans but I think part of what keeps his music from translating far outside of the underground is that he writes his songs to be so low-key Chris's songs have plenty of hooks I wouldn't really say any of them pop per se and there are lots of hip hop artists out there who made that sort of songwriting and and they're great doing that they're completely fine doing that I just think Chris is so eccentric that he has the potential to make songs that are a bit catch here a bit more pop savvy because as of right now like I said a lot of the courses here very understated like on the song loop dreams where essentially we get Chris saying and overdubbing himself saying loop during loop dream Lube dream you may get a moment a very dreary spoken word like on the track King is dead as the hook or a very eccentric shouted refrains such as on the track what up como it's them bitches and another thing that really kind of kills the flow some of these tracks is that structurally Chris keeps it so simple with a lot of these songs starting with mere fade ins or hardens and ending with fade outs or just abrupt finishes the fact that the songs on here don't start or finish that fantastically leaves this LP to me feeling like a bit scatterbrained despite these structuring and the flow limitations that this LP has quality Chris still manages to captivate on many songs here there's a good handful of tracks on here that are completely whacked out and they feel bold because of it case in point the song super this track to me has Chris feeling kind of like a hip hop blow fly where he is working out the calves working on the ABS using the shake weight trying to get in shape frapp and ever since I heard this album one of my favorite things to sing in my apartment has been and then there's the song coke with Denmark in black milk which instrumentally feels like a beat that Swizz Beatz sort of produced in bizarro world I love the ridiculous refrains on the chorus the crazy lyrics throughout the song and of course the at the end where we get a club a club bitches on the flyer e-ever at the club it's moments like this where I feel like Chris is at his most surprising at his most interesting and the closer to to an extent while I don't like this song as a finisher I like the repetitious don't nobody love me don't nobody look over a very quirky spacious synth heavy beat and I like how just simple this song is with Chris saying that nobody loves him but things will change as soon as he gets money the track does seem a little too dumbed down to be interesting however in a way it can kind of be a self-criticism with Chris making so many tracks on this LP about his time in the rap game and trying to make it in the rap game and how maybe he's boiling his passion down to merely wanting to get money on this track making it all seem maybe little shallow in the long run when Chris is serious on this album he is dead serious like on the track loop Dreams which is actually a really depressing look at Chris struggling as an independent artist he's making no traction labels or to his fans think he's made it but he hasn't really made anything and all of this is performed over a very dreary beat with a pretty eerie tremolo simply that I like a lot and I love the track undying one of the best instrumentals on this entire LP with the background vocals oh the Tom beat that feels really primal on this thing as well as the jazzy flourishes of horns that occur throughout this track - it's just a really lovely instrumental and this track is just sort of about Chris's passion for music passion for success I love the refrain on this track where he's saying I thought you did it for the love but I love life and since it's all connected then I guess I got it right and then there's the song life beyond which is sort of an introspective moment about personal choices and on his bars here Chris reflects upon a lot of the other artists around him who sort of influenced him in a positive way in music Black Milk Danny Brown Mosel who actually appears on this track with a verse and then there's the very eerie King is dead one of the more chilling tracks on this LP and there are some more hard-hitting moments - like the previously mentioned what up as well as the song prx with guilty simpson as well as alchemists with open arms is a bit of a posse cut I liked these tracks I mean really I liked all the tracks there are only a few that underwhelmed me but still as a whole when I listened to this album I don't find myself captivated by the entire thing as an experience because of just how unorganized and unkempt it is in a way it's kind of like looking at a really great sculpture but it feels kind of unfinished or it feels like the corners and curves haven't been completely sanded over or chiseled out to perfection there's just something about ghosts at the finish line as a whole that feels kind of a uneventful and while I am drawn to the weirder moments on this LP maybe there are some tracks here that I feel aren't such great songs versus just silly song ideas sort of like super however its spots like this that I think are a testament to Chris's personality because even though these songs don't feel fleshed out that heavily don't feel that builds up I'm not getting a great sense of ambition from the songs on here still Chris is such an eccentric and just off-the-wall rapper that he shines through a lot of it much of the time I'm feeling a decent two strong seven on this transition but if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it he had the name antenna quality Chris forever

yeah hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest me sick nerd and it's time for a review of the new blood orange album Cupid deluxe blood orange is the musical project of singer songwriter and multi-instrumentalist Devante Hines who you might know for his other recordings under the name like speed champion or even earlier as a part of the band test icicles of course these projects were in different musical styles but this blood orange project of his this is his sophomore album under this name and this project is one that he uses to not play singer-songwriter music or chamber pop or indie rock or pop or dance punk genres that Devante has played in his earlier career but this is all about synth pop synth funk contemporary R&B especially these sounds as they were being portrayed in the eighties this guy tends to where his influences on his sleeve the likes of Michael Jackson Billy ocean Lionel Richie and Prince I'll show up in his tunes in some way shape or form and he grabs all these influences and he portrays them in a way that's really smooth but also very inoffensive and not that catchy or memorable it's like he's grabbing all of the nostalgic Kitsch but just taking out the personality with the vocals and the very sensual grooves on this album it's like blood oranges shooting for sweet and sexy but instead he delivers an album that goes down like a warm flat glass of Mountain Dew there is a lot of revivalism going on right now but there's nothing on this record that says to me that blood orange is great bringing these sounds back with the ambition of like Daft Punk's latest record or the eccentricity of destroyers latest record or the conceptual ideas of a Janelle Monae across the 11 tracks here there are some decent dance grooves being dished out but that is where the strong points of this album start and end because truthfully the songs here are so uneventful that it really becomes difficult not to tune after halfway in to any of them especially since blood orange doesn't really progress a lot of these songs compositionally as they continue not only that but the lyrics and the vocals for every track on this thing just sound like hilarious mimicry I'm singin ACK this these songs have nothing but weak falsettos and breathy vibrato 'he's on top of weak falsettos and breathy vibrato 'he's sometimes sometimes it's tolerable like on the opening track and the song you're not good enough but even these songs sound like they were made with the intent to just merely be background music for whatever store you go to at the mall to buy overpriced clothing I actually think the first interesting moment on this entire LP occurs on the song uncle ace and believe me it is not due to the cheesy sax solo in the middle of this thing and the really melodramatic spoken word which is not attractive at all actually I would call these two things low points on this record right up there with hearing David long strength of the Dirty Projectors sing in this similarly sexy way on the song no right thing which believe me is not sexy or entertaining at all it's like this entire record is just devoted to bringing back this singing style that was hot in the 80s and just redoing it in the most unflattering way possible really the only interesting part of this whole song uncle ace are these woodwinds and horns toward the back end that are arranged in a way where it sounds like it's part of an epic Philip Glass piece it really sounds like Devante is borrowing straight from that Philip Glass playbook and as much of a ripoff as it sounds like it kind of makes me wonder if he can put together musical pieces like this why is he hanging around in the doldrums of offensively simple synth funk and songs that rehash the same instrumental ideas over and over and over throughout the track to the point where the song gets stale like on the line and time will tell the record can't even manage to pull together a good vocal feature from singers who are proven to be good singers like Caroline pull a check of chairlift or the rapper despot who raps for the majority of one single track on here while I do think he is a good lyricist the very hard nails tone of his voice just does not fit on this record at all it really ruins what little flow this LP has going for it already the UK based rapper sceptic ahooo is featured toward the back end of this LP the tone of his voice and just the subtlety of his delivery is much more fitting for what goes on here instrumentally but still I don't really see how his success or him starting to make it in the music industry which is what he raps about in this song is really relevant to the theme of this record out of all of his vocal features Hines gives the most airtime to Samantha herb annie of the band friends who was easily the least interesting vocalist of everyone who was invited onto this thing not only was the full-length from her main band friends really underwhelming but the first few lines she sings on the song it is what it is just sound incredibly awkward and and very amateurish that and the song always let you down and it's like there's no effort to remedy this at all instrumentally these songs feel off at times to either rhythm guitars slightly out of place or the synth solo on the song you're not good enough which is just really really shoddy and boring or the slap bass line on the song always let you down and swing and across the cell P instrumentally I feel like Devante runs out of ideas too like the track always let you down feels like a little bit of a rehash of the first song on here not to mention that it sounds a lot like a track off of glasses first album as well again the only thing I really liked about this LP is that I thought that some of the grooves were pretty good but they're never structured into an interesting song the vocal melodies and the lyrics and the refrains and choruses are never really that memorable neither is the singing that great and really that is maybe the biggest kicker on this entire thing if the singing was fantastic then maybe the incredibly bland songs and instrumentals wouldn't be that big of a deal but they really are simply because there's nothing else to really pay attention to for me Cupid deluxe is a shining example of the darker side of modern music's current addiction to nostalgia because I feel like we're merely gravitating toward this record because of this lost essence that it's captured versus what's actually going on here musically compositionally or vocally sitting through this record is like having someone try to seduce you for 50 minutes straight after you've already told them no ten times because I do not find anything sexy moody emotional or attractive about what goes on here honestly I'm really feeling a light decent too on this thing transition if you give it to Sophia listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantino blood orange forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review the new sky ferreira album nighttime my time sky ferreira is a Californian singer and model this is her full-length debut album on which she has a pretty indie friendly sound which she has built up to for a handful of years with some singles and some ep's skies first big musical outing came around 2010 with the single one which was just a really offensively generic piece of dance pop and then last year she had that ghost EP which dropped where you could definitely tell there was movement from point A to point B here instead of dance pop we're getting these indie folk tunes these synthesizer pop tunes that have a bit of grit to them a bit of a underground production aesthetic and then there was the song red lips which had this really heavy loud grunge sound to it for sure sky was evolving and she was putting out tracks that had some nostalgia for past musical movements and was kind of capturing the essence of that with her producers the instrumentals were tight however I've just really been consistently unimpressed with her lyricism and her singing because really I personally find a lot of her songs just be too lovestruck and melodramatic the instrumentation that backs her time and time again is just really really safe and unadventurous and there's nothing about it that says to me anything but this exists just to spotlight the singer which would be fine if she was a stellar singer but really she's not for the most part she's passable on the more acoustic cuts from her ghost EP she's certainly a motive but nowhere near distinct and chock-full of personality I honestly could not pull sky Ferrara's voice out of a lineup if I saw it commit a murderer and then I was called in for police questioning until now sky is kind of held off on dropping a full-length LP though I'm sure she could have done that earlier and I imagine that must have had something to do with maybe her and her producers waiting until they kind of struck upon a sound that they could ride and draw out for 30 to 50 minutes and while I guess they found a direction with this new full-length album I still think sky is sounding as commonplace as ever now just like the new you'd cover on this LP suggests the sound on night time my time is moving into edgier territory however unless you fear the sharpness of butter knives I can't see if phasing you songs like boys and it's your right Christine are essentially dreamy lightly shoegaze pop rock that kind of sounds like a sugary version of a place to bury strangers or like a noise pop version of best coast and you know one of the opening lyrics on this thing about boys being a dime a dozen songs like this are a dime a dozen we already have bands like dum dum girls on the scene and frankly that they're more interesting especially considering the state of the lyrics here where we get this nauseating refrain of cross my heart and hope to die stick a needle in my eye I do get the point of the song with the lyrics progressing talking about how she doesn't trust boys and then eventually she finds a boy that that makes her love again as if she's never been hurt before but it's still not a song I would return to some of the vocal harmonies that pop up with Skye's multitrack vocals on the courses here are very sweet they're very heavenly but most of the comatose moaning which I guess is supposed to be singing most of the verses here is just outright boring it becomes most unbearable on the song Oman ko which is essentially Japanese for but not that that matters because the song is essentially reading Japanese comics Japanese  and having a Japanese Christmas all kind of piled up into this really lame set of lyrics that are so pointless it's just inexcusable and I see that they're sort of a weird post-punk minimal synth influence going on with the instrumental here really cool musical reference going on with this track but still if the lyrics were more interesting I can see it working but mmm they're not another one of the slower songs on here that's incredibly awkward is the closing track which only ends up sounding like a slowed down more atmospheric version of one of the more forgettable songs on this LP melodically and compositionally the song is really simple so I imagine there must be something really emotional or powerful about hearing Skye awkwardly vocalize in the midst of this very reverb heavy instrumental but if there is I'm not seeing it please educate me the best songs on this album because there are some good ones here are the ones that make no buts about what sky ferreira is a pop singer that makes pop music the sweeter songs on here are much more enjoyable than the foe experiments and mock rock like the arena Psy's new wave ballad 24 hours great it's the first song in this entire LP that makes sense Sky's voice is not strong enough for modern radio pop so having her sing sleepily over this somewhat vintage synth pop ballad is fantastic the hook is catchy as hell the plinking synthesizers behind her voice over that chorus melody sound great and the lyrics about being with this person for the next 24 hours wishing this day could last forever wishing the clock had no hands it's a sweet song and so are other tracks like you're not the one really nice lead single that is not so big but still a very catchy track then there is blame myself and love in stereo tracks that are heartbroken or really smitten and sometimes about more personal stuff that I can't necessarily get down with specifically on I blame myself I feel like there's so many moments on this LP where sky takes the opportunity to lyrically remind the listener or maybe remind people she's frustrated with that you don't know me she's trying to put out this message that she's not being understood and that people aren't listening to her and while sky does have some very passionate vocals when singing on this topic I just feel like I want to be spared when it comes to this because really if you want to convince people that there's more to you sing on legitimately interesting instrumentals or don't deliver lyrics that are laughably dumbed down case in point the song heavy metal heart or the track nobody asked if I was okay where again and again and again we are reminded that nobody asked sky if she was okay overall there are some bright poppy spots on this LP that I enjoy but even the better tracks on here including the big single feel slightly disposable when the songs on this LP try to work outside of that poppy comfort zone into something noisier grittier more rock driven it just becomes whatever as much as Skye and her producers might like post-punk and garage rock they really failed to capture the excitement and the rawness and the essence of these genres and just create very pale imitations I am pretty much feeling a light for on this record transition if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it you have to be Fantino night time my time forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new soup cans EP parasite brain soup cans is a filthy scuzzy gross disgusting and raw ass rock van from Ontario Canada this is their new EP they have two full-length albums that drop before this if the music here interests you I do recommend that you check out their 2012 album good feelings it breezed by me last year and these guys are a trio that embraced the sounds of noise and garage rock and psychedelic rock and really noisy post-hardcore acts like the jesus lizard and this band is just not bring incredibly low phi distorted and saturated production to the table but their approach to vocals is pretty interesting as well basically their philosophy is to be as insane as humanly possible while still sounding like you're actually fronting a rock band these six tracks on the CP barely breached the 10-minute mark but what the CP does not have in length it does have in intensity with the vocals the distorted bass the distorted guitars and the very dirty drums all blaring it's such a high volume that after listening to this thing even one time through years will be just ha ha the opening track on here parasite brain the title track has this fast killer riff and the vocals are really caught up in the chaos of everything going on in this song but they just go so berserk that they feel as if they're drowned out by nothing there's a moment where the band slows down the riff of this song out of nowhere with no warning whatsoever and it adds up to a pretty interesting moment and there's also the masturbatory guitar solo that happens after this that really just feels more like noise-making than actual solo and even though there are things about this track that I think are are catchy just the speed and the intensity of it just it's it's so over and done with right as it starts it's like ripping off a really big band-aid then there is the song new teeth that comes right after the opener a more mid-paced track on here and a moment that is one of my favorites just because of how hopeful insane the vocals are a track that is really minimal lyrically got no teeth I got OJ with these lyrics being kind of grunted out as if they're being performed by a caveman and I just love the band where they're pulling together something a little slower like this because then things just seem so much more noisy and insane there are great faster tracks on here like the closer where essentially the vocals are rendered down simply too but still moments like this are just a bit of a blur it's these slower tracks that just bring that pain and so much more of an intense way which maybe is why my favorite track on here is future crimes part two the longest song on here and when I say longest I mean this song is like the length of three other tracks on this EP it is the slowest track on here as well featuring these loud loud 4 soup cans booming guitar chords that are just Brown Wow very primal drums and some of the most deranged vocals yet on this entire release and you know for a band that plays it this loose soup cans do seem to have some kind of command over their dynamics because as this song goes on it just gets more and more and more intense again what this EP does not have in length it does have an impact and it's it's definitely something you're gonna want to seek out if you like your music to work like a hot strong black cup of coffee being violently splashed into your face even though there are a few moments on here that are a blur and I do wish this EP were longer and I do wish the lyrics were fleshed out a little bit more so that they added to the insane quality of the vocals the vocals and the distorted guitars the dissonant guitars and the catchy grooves are all just so sharp that it's hard for me it's impossible for me really to charge much of what's on the sea as being forgettable or just sort of run-of-the-mill I'm feeling a decent strong seven on this thing transition if you've given the sepia listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that said Anthony Fan Tan Oh soup cans parasite brain EP forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new moon face album Julia with blue jeans on moon face is the pseudonym for Canadian singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist Spencer Cruz he has been in a number of different successful bands and projects over the years like Swan Lake sunset rubbed down as well as Wolf Parade his newest his moon face and it's the most indulgent and seemingly flexible of his project so far putting out an EP of songs based on marimba an album of songs based around organ another full-length album where he actually featured a full-fledged band that was playing songs he had written he's been releasing at least something with every year that he's been writing music under this name and his latest here Julia with blue jeans on is another pretty surprising turn in his moon face based ventures Spencer is not with a band on this record he's back to doing things solo and he is on he is behind his main acts the piano and this LP delivers 10 tracks that are a little out of the ordinary for Spencer in that they are very personal and blatant about the fact that Spencer is writing about some experiences that he's had especially dealing with a lot of the tracks on here are very clearly love songs however it's not like Spencer explores just simply one side of love throughout this record this album has romance and tragedy infatuation loneliness and there are some moments here where Spencer is just being deeply introspective like on spots such as love the house you're in it feels like he's trying to deliver these personal experiences without sugarcoating things over dramatizing things or building things up a little too much this philosophic approach that Spencer is taking with the lyrics on this LP is stated in just a few lines on the title track here it's a mad man's game making the commonplace unreal fantasy it's a madman's game at the very least a young man's game thank you thank you thank you and this is really like a turning point for Spencer because typically his songs lyrically are so odd and esoteric and extravagant and eccentric he's not even delivering his lyrics on a lot of these songs in an incredibly concise way there are so many tracks here where it feels like his lyrics are just rambling they're not structured that heavily at all and this is a direction that I think Spencer pulls off very well some of the time maybe not so well on other tracks here I think an example of this working out was when Spencer can pull together a passionate track a moving track a riveting track like the title track on here where there's a lyric that hits me where he says I think the only word worth singing is not God it's you and the track to me is all about finding beauty it's about finding inspiration in not only the ordinary but this other person whom you are in love with then on the flip side of this double-edged sword we have the song dreamy summer which is one of the longer tracks here and meanders melodically structurally vocally lyrically to the point where I just feel like this song is very very mundane there's not really much about it that I like aside from the very refined piano playing however I do think Spencer is conscious of that mundaneness and doesn't care because I think he's focusing a lot more on just exercising these emotional demons and kind of taking the good with the bad on that and it really is more good than bad a lot of the time on here like with the opening track barbarian where I feel like lyrically Spencer is putting his dark side and putting his more innocent side on display measuring them up a bit something that I think he does in an even more bold and obvious way on barbarian part 2 a 2 minute track a follow up but in between these two tracks is maybe my favorite on this entire LP everyone is Noah everyone is the ark where Spencer is taking relationships and needing other people whether these relationships be tonic or romantic or whatever and comparing this to the story of Noah and the Ark I think my favorite line on this entire track is when he says everyone ends up talking to the sky or staring the elephants in the eye another particular line on here that makes the metaphor really obvious is when Spencer is saying that everyone gathers Souls around themselves to feel needed and useful and loved then there is the dark yet unapologetically cheesy November 2011 a track where Spencer is talking about how he is destroying his own music and how it wasn't that good anyway destroying computers and getting together with his significant other in this track who he refers to as his slaughterer and I feel like there are a group of lines on this track that display just how crazy Spencer and this girl are and how flawed their relationship is but there are moments of great beauty throughout this track too but then we get hit with the refrain it's just basically a repeat over and over and over of baby we both know that we're both crazy baby as far as other tracks on here there's the very dramatic black is back in style and the very grand closing track your chariot may be not one of the most epic songs on this LP but as far as the piano playing on here it is very very again grand and a beautiful display of Spencer's chops to kind of close this LP out as far as the sound goes on here it's a very simple portrayal of voice and piano the piano sounds like this very well-kept grand piano and the sound the recording is just pristine and the singing on this record another change for Spencer in a sense is some of his most vulnerable yet I feel like you can call Spencer Krug a lot of things but you cannot call the man emotionless as he croons and yelps and moans and shouts and through every single track here typically songs like the ones that are delivered on this LP where the structure and the lyricism and the story and just the point is also it just doesn't turn me on I mean prime examples the last weekend album the new Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds album however with Spencer's captivating vocals and potent emotions and somewhat self-deprecating lyrics I think this and the very sharp piano playing adds up to some great introspections a lot of personality and some very enjoyable songs too I didn't love this thing but I did like it quite a bit I'm feeling a light too decent 7 on this transition if you've given this up he'll listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana moon face forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and just letting you know that Rat King the New York experimental hip-hop outfit has a new track out titled 100 hit the description box down there to give it a listen a lot of you might remember that I reviewed their wiki 93 EP about a minute ago and was a little on the fence with it loved some tracks was pretty underwhelmed by others however this track to me so good that has got me kind of wondering or rather anticipating where they're gonna go next Bumi hip-hop beat on this thing a lot of bass kicks very steady hi hats and a very eerie synth lead that reminds me quite a bit of 90s West Coast hip-hop and wiki rapping on top of this beat reminds me a lot of like a young young zack de la rocha but very very smooth Rat King finding a balance between their very dark abrasive kind of moody production and a lyrical emphasis as well again give this track of listen let me know you think of it down there in the description box it's out now on itunes as well at the moment and yeah that's it Rat King 100

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new mi l b'm matang e mi a is a UK via Sri Lanka singer rapper producer and songwriter who is on her fourth full-length commercial studio album right here when mi is music first gained popularity in underground music her sound was fresh exciting and bright she had this really eccentric vocal style and these very hard-hitting and colorfully produced beats that featured musical influences from all around the world and after this full-length debut mi a took this very magnetic personality in her music and focused it into some bonafide hits on her next full-length record kala and the singles on this record made her a household name in the world of pop music at the time also made her a pretty controversial figure she was collaborating and performing with big-name artists her name was on everyone's lips it seems like she was really on the cusp of becoming a long-lasting figure in mainstream music and she just threw it all away not in this really dramatic way or anything like that even though there were some spats and Fiasco's that have occurred in relation to her over the past few years that we could talk about New York Times super bowl these things certainly impacted her popularity on the whole but I think really what made her take a nosedive musically was her third full-length LP Maya an LP whose instrumentals moved into territory that was way noisier just harsher more obtuse than anything on her previous records at the time this record was released the harsh power tools and the shots of noise and the heavy heavy kick drums opening up one of the tracks here step up turn a lot of people sour even I myself did not find a lot of the production on this LP to be all that pleasant to the ears however in a world where currently we have things like Death Grips and trap electro bangers because people love that bass and they love those hard-hitting noises I think it might be worth kind of going back and re listening to this record simply because of how bombast the beats on this thing are even though this record did get a mixed reception it didn't slow m.i.a down a bit she went on to release the Viki Leakes mixtape shortly after and last year she put out her biggest single yet only seconded by Paper Planes Bad Girls which lands on this LP the song is catchy as hell fantastic chorus really sweet epic and catchy Middle Eastern melody as well as a hard banging groove and vocal emia brings that cool as a cucumber charisma that makes some of her best songs so great so not only does this LP have some of em is best tracks ever on it but it's not like some of the mixed reception around her last record has really shaken her sound at all because some of the tracks on this LP are just as unapologetically noisy as moments on Maya like the song Yolo with these buzzing bass lines and these very very loud shouts from mi a at the beginning a really catchy chorus banger beats lyrically there's a lot of club imagery but again mi a is kind of doing a little clever turn of phrase here talking about that excess and that materialism in mainstream music but also talking about hey yalla you always live again Hinduism Eastern religions and forms of philosophy and it's not like she comes off in songs like this as if she's looking down her nose at you or anything like that its tracks like this that like any hip-hop artist mi aegis braggadocious Li represents what she's all about and there are other tracks here that are also freaking just aa huge bangers that I find to be just as enjoyable like only one you and warriors there is the song Double Trouble bubble which is sort of a weird fusion of electro trap and reggae it's an oddly refreshing combo and just a fun song then there's no it ain't right which is kind of this slowed down trap sex ballad that is kind of catchy one of the more underwhelming tracks on the album but I like that they were able to take this very hard aggressive sound that's very popular right now and kind of turn it into something that's a little sweeter or tender in a way and then there's the song attention just kind of another sort of left-field surprise on this album where essentially instrumentally we have a two-step type track and I know this B I know this rhythm is really popular right now on electronic music and rarely do I catch an artist sort of doing a one-off track in this style where it feels really bold and interesting and very brash and that is certainly what I got here with how zany and noisy and colorful the production is which Mis production typically is it's not like she put together some kind of sleeper snoozer of a two-step track especially with the lyrics on this track doing a sort of odd concept throughout where mi a is using words over and over and over that had the word tent in them and emphasizing that word of the very brash I use the word again use of auto-tune like president-- attention 10 account tent mutant most of the experiments that mi a does on this record most of the new ground she tries to step on at least new for her goes over pretty well I think one of the most underwhelming spots though is the moment here where she samples the weakened track lucky star or the song Exodus in a way I do feel like songs such as Exodus put a line between moments when mi a is singing and that really sort of listless girly silly tongue-in-cheek style like on the song come walk with me a track out here that I do like but her voice kind of just gets old for me by the end of the track especially with the repeating lyrical verses but still that is a very fun interesting and hard-hitting a song about social media friendship people interacting in this current modern technology age but here on Exodus mi use singing is just fiery it's passionate the beat is especially killer and Atmospheric and epic it's just a shame that across this track which is one of the longest on this LP mi a singing and the beat don't change up that significantly and it just all kind of gets stale by the end of it there's not that much structure to this track and I feel like the entire song hinges a little bit too much on this lone weekend sample the song lights to me has that same issue of just not being diverse enough from beginning to end and then there is the song sexy de switch finishes this album off and it's just like a hard trap a fied banger version of Exodus the sample is pretty much the same mi a singing on this track is exactly the same it doesn't even feel like she changed the vocal take at all either to hear it rehashed in this way it's just not that great it doesn't add to the album for me at all still despite my complaints about that track and a handful of other songs on here that that underwhelmed me a bit in just this general overall feel that this album doesn't flow all that well I did think a vast majority of these tracks were great to listen to like usual mi a comes through with tons of personality great beats and production sharp singles despite some lyrical and vocal limitations mi a craftsman really fun thoughtful and infectious tracks on this LP still her first two LPS are my favorites this album does not beat them out but I'm still feeling a decent a strong 7 on this thing transition but if you've given this LP a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it mi a Matangi forever

hi everyone Anthony Phan tanto here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Daniel Avery album drone logic before we get into this LP I know some of you are still a little sad still a little down in the dumps but hey come on it's another day another album to listen to put a smile on your face it's alright man chill I love you Daniel Avery is a uk-based electronic music producer he has released this full-length debut of his drone logic right here on fantasy records earlier this year and I was pretty impressed with what this guy was doing with techno and house music from a technical and from a sonic standpoint I wouldn't say Daniel Avery is reinventing the wheel here or violently burning down the status quo even though he's not blowing me away with a really experimental take on these genres he is delivering a very long album a very well assembled tracks the beats on this LP have a lot of rigid robotic techno characteristics but are still undeniable to the hips a lot of Drive in these rhythms and I think the bass lines are especially bouncy it's really nice to hear beats that have such a synthetic aesthetic but still appeal to those very deep got to move to this primal instincts there are quite a few vocal snippets on this thing moments like Walter Jones weird little cuts of spoken word that play throughout a lot of these tracks for the most part the vocals add to the very stone-faced near emotionless vibes that this album gives off through a lot of its sounds even these sustain singing notes on the opening track here that are sampled and looped over and over and over are manipulated and distorted and feel so grainy that they are just merely a shell of their former selves in terms of feeling human anyway the most tender vocal cut on this entire LP is the whispered singing on the closing track knowing we'll be here it's pretty nice to hear a techno album an electronic music album that starts off so just lockstep and chilly war month as it progresses relatively anyway like on the very gently pulsating soft and melodic tracks Samuel wreck or the track new energy which gets progressively more and more intense and noisy and fiery as it goes on with a very krautrock inspired beat and there are a lot of sharp and noisy drones that occur on some of these tracks to adding a bit of emotional heat and intensity as far as the melodies go on this LP and the counterpoint with the bass lines and some of the synth chords that pop up Daniel Avery's approach is very simple but there is purpose here because all of these elements do add up into some catchy synth sequences or just a really potent moody mix of sounds and structurally these tracks justify five six seven eight minutes song lengths with the theory that if you start out with a great groove you can keep things interesting by varying the rhythms dropping out ideas introducing new ideas or slowly layering tracks for a gradual climax and even though drone logic to an extent is easy to sum up as an album it doesn't take away from the magic and the tension of listening to these songs in the moment like the song water jump which has multiple phases and all of them leave me feeling like I'm listening to the soundtrack to driving at night at very high speed through a neon lit City 1000 years into the future and things get especially epic when a few very grainy minor tone chords enter the picture on top and already growing pile of beats synth leads vocal samples and some ba-ba-ba-ba-ba bass and some tracks do hit harder than others with some very punchy rhythms and hard ass bass like the song naive response whose low end is very heavy and rubbery as the song progresses with its bassline just bouncing over and over and over or the song these nights never end whose groove is very lightly kissed with these sharp distorted oddly placed since sequences and these eerily sustain notes I will say that the Assembly of sounds on this LP lacks a certain finesse that you might find in the productions of an R like John Hopkins or Pantha new prints however I do kind of enjoy the hard entrances and exits of new sounds and ideas on these songs because it does add to the already enjoyably rigid characteristics that these songs have to offer and while there are some sharp noisy drones on these tracks that I do like and I did kind of expect given that the name of this album his drone logic for the most part the drones do feel more like an accent or a side dish not a main attraction the most spotlight a drone gets on this LP is on the 1-minute interlude tracks spring 27 and even though the drones do add character to this LP they're not exactly enough to save some of these tracks from their very very repetitive selves like the song all I need where even though the drone is entering the picture and changing things up slightly there's not enough variation in the instrumentation underneath that to kind of keep things feeling tense and the song all I need is well to me is is lacking in a bit of drive to progress and kind of change the sound of this song as it plods along so yeah there are a few tracks on here that do feel a little less developed a little less detailed than others and I did think the clothes are on here while good was sort of anticlimactic for a finishing track that and the fact that I felt like there really could have been a little more sonic adventure going on with these tracks these were the only major issues I had with this album though again I don't think Daniel Avery is reinventing the wheel here he has put together a series of very very well crafted techno tracks with great grooves rhythms bass lines since sequences I am feeling a strong seven to a light eight on this thing transition but if you've given this up he'll listen what did you think why am i whispering what should i review next and that's it Anthony Fantan Oh Daniel every drone logic forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Lady Gaga album artpop Lady Gaga is a New York pop music artist this is her third full-length LP she has released two before this and an EP by the name of the fame monster and across her handful of releases thus far she has had some incredibly ubiquitous hits like bad romance as well as pokerface Born This Way but personally I've never been somebody who has taken Lady Gaga that seriously outside of her singles not only that but I think the album she came out with a few years ago born this way is easily one of the worst mainstream pop albums to come out in a while my issue with this record and Lady Gaga in general is that she has this eccentric look and way of dress these alternative personalities as well as this political activism edge - it seems like she's adventurous and experimental with everything except her music which she keeps incredibly bland and uninvent Eurus really Gaga did the worst thing that I think a pop artist can do to their fans on this record and that is give us some really great memorable singles but then have the rest of the album just be really fun enjoyable maybe this is less of a sin in the download age when people can just kind of grab the songs they want and don't listen to what they don't want to but still after a long very painful album like this I can understand that it is easy to count Lady gaga out maybe not just predict her downfall in popularity but maybe sort of write her off and just expect nothing interesting from her ever for the rest of her career and that prediction seems to be coming true in a sense because this is easily Gaga's most lukewarm album release year yet but I like art pop I think it's her best album yet and I understand why a lot of you might hate her image in her persona and her very look at me style and publicity stunts but at least on this LP Gaga is taking very little high-heeled baby stuff in a direction that I've always wanted her to go in it all I've ever wanted Lady Gaga to be is consistent if you are mentally and personally as whacked as you look then put out music that lives up to that and I'm not saying Lady Gaga should put out something avant-garde or anything like that she's a pop artist I expect her to put out pop music but give me pop music with some legitimately great fantastic instrumentals with some amazing music being written into them give me some personality give me catchy melodies give me a sense of bliss and that is what I got on here for at least a good chunk of the tracks and it's funny there are a lot of professional critics out there right now who are saying that this record is really run-of-the-mill for Lady gaga but maybe Lady Gaga shtick is getting kind of old for some people because truth be told it's not like there's much more to her than her shtick it's not like she's an incredible wordsmith or anything like that like on the song or aware our first introduction to the chorus is do you want to see me naked lover do you want to peek underneath the covers or the song dope where toward the beginning of the song Lady Gaga is saying I up again because I lost my only friend and then the song gypsy where it gets really ridiculous naming off all these different places I get the concept of the song and kind of going around and being a bit of a nomad maybe through how Lady Gaga is always moving in her career and touring so on and so forth but toward the end I'm a gypsy gypsy gypsy Hey then there's the song Donatello which is kind of a parody of Donatella Versace and a lot of the sort of high-class fashion types out there and even though there are mentions on this track of being blonde being a rich bitch only having eaten a salad all day asking your gay friends for tanning advice it feels like the song just does not go far enough to be truly funny or biting or hilarious not only that but the vocal melody on this track and the verses seem so underneath Lady Gaga's chops because she has some serious pipes and at the end of the day it only ends up kind of like a Weird Al parody when it comes to writing lyrics Lady Gaga just does not have that much tact however the fact that she doesn't mince words sometimes as sort of a makes the song so entertaining to go back to the song dope where we have the refrain I need you more than dope I need you more than dope where Lady Gaga is just on this huge meatloaf trip and then there's the song sex dreams which kind of gets me in the mood what you in the mood for I'll tell you when you're older and with Lady Gaga's lyrics on this track touching yourself when you're thinking of this person with these dirty thoughts in your head how you and this other individual are convicted felons of thought the song is just so hyper sexual it's like Madonna's like a virgin except never a virgin ever and then there's the track swine where Lady Gaga is straight up calling someone a pig talking about squealing and screaming herself all over this track again another moment where Gaga is just really yet one of her most vocally eccentric zenus to hear her singing in such a weird and just over-the-top way is a little refreshing to me like on the opener or aware again we return to a moment very similar to Born This Way where we have some Spanish guitar playing but musically we slide very quickly into what seems like some middle eastern vocal melodies over an instrumentation change and then as the beat kicks in and really gets going on the track it's like we're getting some jittery French electro house sounds that remind me a lot of justice and this very progressive noisy abrasive fidgety EDM sound is pretty consistent throughout the very colorful instrumentals on this thing and when aura starts Gaga's vocals on this thing are just so whacked I'm not a wandering slave I'm a woman of choice then there is the song Venus which is essentially this love fueled intergalactic space travel mission of epic pop proportions with a very explosive harmonious chorus and some verses that March in this really militaristic way and then there's a refrain that comes up later in the track take me to your planet a moment that really reminds me of like some 90s era Michael Jackson this is a really multifaceted track in terms of structure for lady gaga especially with the very tight tight multitrack vocal harmonies on the back end which are so colorful and quick to hit that they remind me of lightning of Montreal song there are other moments where the instrumentals really surprised me like the trap influence beat on the back end of manicure or the rock opera esque instrumentation on the end of Mary Jane Holland and there are more straightforward tracks on this LP too that I think are just as entertaining just because the song and melody is so freakin catchy like GUI and the disco fried fashion which is so freakin enjoyable I love the groove I love the fashion this track is so fun to me it makes me wish I was a rich socialite piece of with nothing to live for other than a coke habit and expensive clothes I would just blast this song all day I blast this song all day anyway however there are tracks on here that I do not blast all day I would not blast any day for example jewels and drugs a song that I do not get down Rosa Maya and the song even features rapped verses from ti too short and twist up but I am NOT trying to hear TI rap about beating the case on a lady gaga album the other feature idea on this LP ruins what could have potentially been the greatest song on this album the greatest song Lady Gaga has ever done do what you want the sexiest song on this record it hits with this very pulsating thick heavy rigid New Wave inspired beat just really done and then and then Lady Gaga's voice sounds fantastic on this track I love the refrain man as basic as it is it just works do much and then our Kelly comes into the picture and now only is his lyrical contribution to this track incredibly weak but this is the last guy who you should be giving license to do whatever he wants to your body and you know why it's the same reason Lady Gaga has to be careful pronouncing the word party around him or else it will sound like potty he'll pee on you oh he went there oh yeah there are a few softer ballads on this LP that aren't too bad but aren't too exciting either like the title track which sort of in a weird way reminds me of a Crystal Castles song if they were totally stripped of reverb and were really made to rely on the vocal melodies of their tracks and then again there's the song dope which goes in that meatloaf s direction and it's an okay track but I wish it had a very explosive Bat Out of Hell type ending to kind of finish things off the track gypsy sort of goes in that same direction too with how it opens up with the piano piece and then kicks in with some pop house beats and some Springsteen influences on the vocal melody but this track just feels sort of redundant to me on this LP it doesn't really add anything it feels like in a way what dope should have been and then there's applause which I feel like is a very good single not Lady Gaga's hottest but certainly a highlight for me on this album I love how eccentric she is on the verses here for me what makes this song good is a lot of what makes the tracks earlier on this LP so good overall I feel like this album has more positives than negatives for Lady Gaga for one the beats the instrumentals are fantastic props to her producers on every single track here I feel like Lady Gaga is still a great singer she is certainly facing in a stranger direction on this album with songs that still remain catchy fun and have personality but on the con side there are a lot of underwhelming tracks on here too and moments where it feels like Lady Gaga just doesn't go far enough to be interesting and again Lady gaga when it comes to lyrics her ideas seem so half-baked at times while I do like this album if this is as art as pop gets pop has a pretty dismal future I would say I'm feeling a strong six on this thing transition but if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it why what do you think I should review next and that said Anthony Fantan Oh Lady Gaga art pop forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new cara cara cara near album portals to a better dead world before i review this thing though there's got to be a retraction i recently did a review of the new action bronson mixtape and in this review i said that action bronson has an alter-ego on this tape by the name of big body bes when the fact of the matter is is that that is not an alter ego at all he's actually a real guy sometimes you hear people and they sound like other people and you assume they're the same person just like how when someone looks like another person you assume they're the same person you won't say it it is a good to say don't talk I don't need you to talk right now okay so action bronson big body best i apologize many please forgive me yes kara near is a dallas rock and metal duo and this I believe is their third full-length album now the members of this duo Chris Francis and Gary Brent's they have been in a bunch of different rock and metal outfits of various styles over the years and this variety shows up in how they write songs for this album a lot of the tracks on here feature vocals that blur the lines between punk rock scream Oh black metal death metal there are plenty of guitars that are quickly strummed on this thing feature a bit of tremolo picking and some very dark archaic mulatto sysm but the tone of the guitar is very very clear it's not like the guitars are sort of over modulating or blurring in some kind of lo-fi mix or anything like that they're actually quite punchy and very tangible like black metal mixed with the power and ferocity of just straight-up punk rock it's a stylistic blend that I think a lot of you will find sort of familiar to that deafheaven album sunbather that dropped recently and while that LP is good deafheaven is definitely going for something a little they look for a certain crescendo to carry their tracks a certain level of reverb an atmosphere to carry their tracks instead care near is just so much more raw bear in your face instead of a big up and down rollercoaster ride it's more like a brick to your skull the seven tracks here very pretty heavily in terms of song length from the ten minute closer to the two minute four Lauren loves a song that kicks off with some really intense speed some brutal blast beats some blood-curdling screams very dismal guitar lead melodies slither in when the drums and the rest of the instrumentation seem to slow down for a few moments at a time this song definitely has intensity but I wouldn't say it's one of the more memorable songs here this track and maybe a couple others too are that I guess distinct from a melodic or a riff standpoint a lot like the opening track on here which is this really interesting hybrid of black metal and scream oh the lines are really blurred on this track and it seems like these genres have more in common than ever but sometimes it feels like the most novel thing that this band has to offer is their mash of these genres because their approach to song structure and melody writing and riff writing doesn't really feel anywhere near as novel or as radical I can't say every track on this LP is that way though the track closing doors definitely catches my attention another song on here that features some really high speed guitar work and drums very tight very intense but the guitar leads on this track are just so bright and ear catching I love the fast tones that are playing not only does this track sound like clenched teeth and white knuckles but the melody written into this song sort of makes these angry feelings feel triumphant and I love the way this track sort of settles down in the middle with some dark primal guitar work and then finishes off of the riff at the end it feels a little speed metal inspired this is a moment where I feel impressed with the structure of the track not only that but this song glides very nicely segues nicely into the next song on here and this track 2 features a lot of speed blood-curdling screams and a chord progression that feels really anthemic but as this court progression repeats throughout the song it sort of loses its flavor just kind of gets a little stale I sort of have the same issue with the song exalting the shadow proprietor what a little longer tracks on this LP seven-minute song in which I think the most interesting moments are the first two minutes where you get this really nice violin this riff that feels like an epic march into battle and then the last two minutes of the track which has one of the most fiery amazing guitar solos on this entire LP the coup de Gras on this album is the final track the 10-minute long three thousand three hundred and eighty pounds and in a way it feels that way it feels like you're kind of being crushed by that amount of weight in a really unpleasant way though I do like the vocals on this track the very cleanly sung vocals which I assume are sung by a female but they're kind of a nice heavenly contrast from the very hellish vocals that are performed throughout much of this album and of course the duo brings some strings onto this track as well they're really pulling out all the stops on this song and trying to write the most unique track that this album has to offer and honestly all the very dark heavy riffs leading up to the end which is this very wide panoramic blissful drone of guitars it's it's just okay it's like there are some very blase moments on this LP that really breeze by me but the band manages to surround them with some really fantastic ideas and it's just got me on the fence a little bit with this LP though I think in the end I really do like it overall there is some great production on this thing really great performance intense playing very tight there's definitely a very refreshing combination of influences on this LP there's a nice variety among the tracks here every song felt pretty distinct from the other I'm feeling a light 7 on this thing transition but if you've given this LP a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Carra near album review forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new Action Bronson and party supplies mixtape blue chips dos movember super refresh style Action Bronson is a New York MC who sticks pretty passionately to that East Coast hardcore hip-hop tradition early on in his career his flow and his voice earned him a lot of Ghostface Killah comparisons but as he's progressed from project to project and drop more songs he's really separated himself from his influences in a pretty big way with his lyrical style which pretty much adds up to excess excess and excess a lot of food a lot of eating which is something that is sort of informed by his background as a cook and as I also said about Action Bronson in my rare chandeliers mixtape review he sort of takes on that big heavy powerful Don persona that a guy like Rick Ross portrays the sex the money the power the luxury but action does it in a way that is just so much less self-serious way more funny clever after that he dropped a little ap with Harry fraud which was a little all over the place but kind of showcased action on some newer more modern production and then we have this new party supplies project blue chips - and even though blue chips is not really my favorite bronson project it was one that I definitely remember because it had him over some pretty unique instrumentals which essentially had me looking forward to this thinking I would hear action on a lot of different beats that I don't usually catch rappers on and not only is Bronson on some interesting production on this thing but blue chips - feels like a concept LP in the same way that rare chandeliers was a concept album it's not really like Bronson is reinventing his persona or whatever it's kind of like he's taking the same recipe but putting it into a different setting but really all of these differences are just kind of window dressing because Bronson is the same guy on this album that he was on previous projects you're getting the same flows the same types of lyrics the same personality hits just a new installment of bars on a new assortment of beats to go to the instrumentals like I said some of the samples here kind of surprising a lot of synth pop and new wave and funk music on here that feels like it's from the 80s and then again there are some tracks that do feature some soul and Motown sampling just like on the original blue chips project but a lot of the time it sounds like party supplies is merely grabbing some loops that are pretty great but he doesn't really reinvent them or rehash them or I guess alter them in a significant way really just kind of clipping them and then ooh boo boo boo going through that cycle and going that route is a bit of a double-edged sword or maybe even a triple edged sword for one the production can get kind of redundant with just hearing the same groove over and over throughout the entirety of a track but on a positive side because the sample source material is so obvious with how party supplies treats it it can kind of grab your ears and just make you think oh hey I like this song but as a rapper you also kind of compete with then the heads of listeners and risk losing their attention or just not really grabbing them if your verse isn't tip-top and your enthusiasm isn't up there enough to kind of wreck the attention away from what the sample is and toward what you're saying and this is a challenge that action is up to most of the time like on the track Amadou Diablo which has the very iconic plucked guitar on the beginning of the Tracy Chapman track give me one reason give me one reason to stay here and even though the sample is a little distracting with how untreated it is action does drop some funny attention-grabbing bars I note it in like three strokes now that's no way to rep the East Coast it's not technical but it's funny and even though there's not a strong song concept here action does have bars but another downside to this track is that it's really just a minute forty three long kind of on the short side which is actually not a rarity on this LP there are quite a few songs on here that are sort of on the short side it's more like him and party supplies are kind of shooting for a vibe or a feel to a song and then merely sort of cut out on it maybe just a few minutes in like on the track Pepe Lopez which has a pretty generous sample of the song dick ela it dip it dip it dip it or the song it's me which has this really kind of cheery bright Island instrumentation it kind of sounds like the instrumental to a coconut drink commercial and the track contemporary man is kind of a unique song in that it feels like a bunch of little baby songs in one giant song with just one 80s loop hitting you after the next one I believe is actually Huey Lewis and the news might be wrong but one I know is John Mellencamp and two others I'm pretty sure are Phil Collins Susan so do these tracks particularly are not terrible but the samples are really what sort of end up standing out to me at the end of the day not actions bars or even what the song is about or what the chorus is if there even is a chorus in short there are just so many tracks on here that I feel like are filler and there are some longer tracks on here to that start off pretty well maybe you have a great beat to them but then later around the middle point of the track action Bronson's alter-ego big body best comes in and just performs this really long interruptive monologue while there are spots on this LP that are hilarious it sounds like Action Bronson is having fun making this project it really hasn't added up to a whole lot of memorable focused tracks that have an incredible amount of impact to them the few tracks on here that I think are fantastic not just likeable or sort of breezy our Rolling Thunder for one fantastic soul sample on this track and I love the way party supplies put some really punchy drums in the background adds a nice groove I just love this instrumental to its core it's simple but it's great in a way kind of reminds me of the UGK track international players anthem in a good way a rap song with a really classy edge and the song through the eyes of a G has a great instrumental really sweet organ loop and a murky murky bassline it's a spacious instrumental like this that I think showcases action bronson really well and makes me want to really to in and listen to everything he has to say I love the lines on here about the ginger shot that he's taking and doing concentration curls with a cinderblock just all of these lines again add up to that character portrait that he does of this big Don type character that he plays and a lot of his songs not only that but with ABS soul on the back end of this track this song really is the best feature track this mixtape has to offer which is unfortunate because on here we also have Mac Miller and Mae helm a wren landing on this thing overall blue chips - it sounds fine but it's just way too breezy hmm and that's because most of the very short tracks on here while likeable feel so effortless for Action Bronson in comparison with his better stuff so while blue chips was okay not really horrible it definitely fell short of being exciting I'm feeling a strong five to a light six on this thing transition but if you've given the listen to blue chips what did you think of it did you love it hate it oh why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana action bronson party supplies blue chips to forever
