hi everyone antthony Fantana here the internet's prettiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Eminem album The Marshall Mathers LP - oh I love mr. damn net since when Oh ever since he put out that album that one I know you're saying man that album was was pretty good Eminem slash Slim Shady slash Marshall Mathers is a Detroit rapper I personally grew up on the man's music through the Slim Shady LP Marshall Mathers LP as well as a lot of his very hot radio singles like loose yourself oh my god and maybe you know things for Eminem have been a little turbulent lately kicking an addiction going on a little hiatus and releasing a few lackluster LPS people are always consistently comparing his newer stuff to his older stuff we want the older stuff back we missed the old Eminem he's a different person now you know and so many of the people like me who grew up on his music I'm a full grown adult who kind of cringes that people calling other people faggots in a public forum hmm aren't I a little too old for this but then again I think of things like the aristocrat joke which I think are really funny as well as South Park and how people like George Carlin took crude humor and framed it in a really thought-provoking way it kind of makes me wonder if there's really anything on this album that I'm too mature for and no I guess there is not an Eminem definitely does approach crude humor with the tact of a flame thrower on this LP with plenty of lines about wiping his butt and firing a machine gun at his 99 problems which is one girl get it the bitch ain't one she's the 99 of them he still got a pretty big pension four grand and yes and I really did grab my nuts there however despite the fact that Eminem is a total prick who refuses to grow up I still find him pretty interesting as a musical personality especially on this album he is self-hating yet braggadocious and self-aware of both of those sides the dude is also a total badass with a knack for versus that just make you wince and cringe not only because of how offensive and foul they are but because of how really they attack the sensibilities of what makes a traditionally good line and hip-hop throwing out these unapologetically corny bars like this is your jam unless you've got toe jam Eminem is also a dude whose songs can be really sensitive and personal motivational inspirational and he's a pretty decent cultural satirist as well plus I think Eminem is the only hip-hop artist right now who topped charts in the 2000s in a big way and still is really really about his music as far as other people like the diplomats and DMX and jay-z and 50 cent Kanye West and Nelly it's really no competition a lot of these artists are just either not making music anymore or not making music that anybody cares about or have just continued to put out albums that are kind of lazy Eminem is still really technically proficient showcasing tons of personality flows different Cadence's at the drop of a hat will totally break into this entirely different vocal impersonation it just sounds like he's incredibly invested in where his sound and story go next and that's really what a lot of us have been anticipating ever since the announcement of this new full-length album of his merely because of the title The Marshall Mathers LP 2 which is an album that yeah for sure maybe some of the jokes and maybe some of the beats sound dated by today's standards but following this album up Eminem's most critically acclaimed album it's still a tall order but in a way I think Eminem kind of meets that challenge Marshall Mathers LP 2 is one of the more ambitious releases he's put out in a while he has plenty of tracks and lines on here that are direct references back to his earlier stuff if not just sequels and he's got plenty of songs on here that are just personal epic hilarious this LP kicks off with the song bad guy it's a seven-minute monster and here Eminem is kind of dealing with his problems in a way that we are familiar with sort of dumping them in the trunk of his car and this track is wrapped from the standpoint of the younger brother of Stan who was killed in the song Stan on the original Marshall Mathers LP but I think the reason is sort of falls short is that I don't really get a vivid sense of this character in the same way that I did with Stan on that original track for the most part I think Eminem sort of uses this as an opportunity to not critique how crazy some fans can get but sort of critique himself which i think is primarily the purpose of the last verse on this song where Eminem is sort of pointing out the fact that time has passed since he was at his peak he talks about the polyps on the back of his throat after his concerts sort of pointing to him being older being worn out aging also the double standards with what he puts out in his rhymes versus how he lives his life treats his daughters and how he came up rapping about how he hated bullies but sort of became one himself through his rhymes and that is the focus of a lot of songs on this album Eminem's past how it affects his present his remorse and his regret with a lot of the things that he's done up until this point there are moments where it feels like Eminem is seriously beating himself up on these tracks but there are also spots on here where it feels like he is so hungry and fighting for the last breath of relevance that he has in the world of hip-hop which I think he does pretty well on some of the tracks here like survival which is a song that has I've listened to it more and more sort of grown on me a track where I don't really care for the hook and I don't really care for the huge arena rock beat but I feel like Eminem bust some serious rhymes on this track and has a really relentless flow he sounds hungry he sounds fiery and as silly as some of the bars on here are like the line about how he is wiping his butt stabbing a knife in his gut he still sounds mad as hell delivering this stuff and kind of convincing - there are other tracks on here that I feel reference Eminem's current place in rap music like the song asshole but not every track that delves into Eminem's past in his place in current hip-hop music is that exciting like the song legacy which has an incredibly melodramatic cook with a really basic rhyme scheme legacy me see guarantee and lyrically this song is a bit of a tale of evolution in Eminem's younger years which I feel like he's able to give us a different picture of now being older but I feel like the story is framed in a way that we're already very very very maybe too familiar with people bullied me here I was misunderstood there and there are some kind of corny lines on this track that are just a little unforgiveable like one of the final verses on this thing where he essentially just gives a shout to five dog from A Tribe Called Quest I mean cool for him but sort of arbitrary and that one line about the Italian sausage and the Flying Saucer and I know being purposefully corny has always been a weapon of Eminem's but they're just some moments here where the jokes just aren't that funny and I also accept that hooks have never really been Eminem's strongest point as well like on the hilariously bitter so much better where Eminem says on the hook that he was laying in bed and this thought came into his head plus a pretty cringe-worthy first verse on this thing about smurfing yourself and then puking blue kool-aid with this female character sort of sleeping with other popular rappers cheating on Eminem making him but some of the hooks where Eminem is singing aren't too bad like on the song rhyme or reason which has one of the most interesting flows on this entire LP a track where Eminem sort of focuses on his hatred for his father and those abandonment issues a little bit and here Eminem has a very generous sample of the zombies song time of the season where he is singing the melody to the chorus on this thing with some multitrack vocals it's hardly bearable it works though it really takes a turn for the worse on the song stronger than I was a track that I guess as I'm reading into it is sort of written from the standpoint of his ex Kim but it's really a song where Eminem is singing for most of the track and I feel demands a level of singing talent that Eminem just doesn't have and it really becomes so bad every time this song pulls up I just skip it I give it a skip however there are spots on here where that more tender side of M&M totally works like on the song headlights a track that I'm surprised does on this LP was I feel emotionally mind-blowing a song about his mother and how after all these years of hating her and hating her and hating her maybe most bitterly on the Marshall Mathers LP he forgives her it's rare when you see Eminem being this consistently serious and because of that this track was a real tearjerker and the chorus at least in my opinion wasn't the worst in the world maybe one of the better courses on this LP with the singer from the van fund as far as other singles on this LP go like berserk and rap God songs that I had previously reviewed in another video berserk has grown on me a little bit because of how catchy it is with repeat listens but rap God I'm still sort of on the fence with it with not liking some of the rhymes especially the gay looking boy bars that all sort of come together at once as well as some of the battering women talk toward the end but still the flow on this track super impressive it's moments like this that I think real M&M fans and potential Eminem fans could really get excited over not another Rihanna chorus the ride that the Marshall Mathers LP 2 presents is a little bumpy some tracks that I really hate some tracks that I really love but it is at its most solid toward the last quarter I love the four tracks that this LP finishes off with the song so far which has a very generous Joe Walsh sample taking a different section of a single track of his and building a different part of this Eminem song with it a track that not only reflects on Eminem's southern roots a little bit but I think is a whole hilarious take on this new older self of his he's sort of dealing with fans harassing him he is dealing with fans making fun of the fact that he looks older he's trying to cope with new technology and the song love game 2 which I think has it's hilarious moments especially the part when he walks in on his girl and she's rapping and sucking at the same time and the verse that Kendrick Lamar has on this track too while the song I feel like on the surface is a little corny with a very generous sample of the game of love Kendrick really comes through the verse that matches Marshalls very cartoony energy and then the song evil twin which i think is a dark hard-hitting closer to this LP yeah man who was just really happy with how this album ended off overall because of how diverse a lot of these tracks are and just how much context this album relies on with its sitting so far in Eminem's career it's really difficult to sum the Marshall Mathers LP 2 up but let me say that even though Eminem is older and I feel like he can sort of look back upon his past career in his life with a bit more intelligence and and be a bit wiser when approaching a lot of these topics he's still not a guy who has matured he's acknowledged that and it's very plain to see that he's not interested in maturing at all I feel that growing out of Eminem's wares is is kind of understandable but I really do think he's writing some stuff here on this album that is early Eminem quality Eminem is definitely bringing that competitive side back that fans have been wanting to hear for a long time while a lot of the hooks are sort of sour and the beats for the most part are passable there are some interesting ones on here with some pretty obvious popular music samples but still they bring this album character they do bring diversity all that said I really am dig in the cell P I'm feeling a light decent 7 on this thing transition but if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's about it Anthony Fantana Eminem's forever

hey everybody Anthony feat Ana here Internet by Munna Minard and it's time for a review of the new black milk album no poison no paradise black milk the pseudonym for detroit-based MC and producer Curtis cross the dude has been producing albums collaborating with other artists for years he's pretty much a seasoned vet at this point he's worked with people like let's see J Dilla Black Thought lsi you know another slum village connection they're guilty Simpson and Shaun price on that random acts album as well as Pharoahe Monch he was an early supporter of Danny Brown as well not one of the biggest names out there but very well known in the underground well-known where he's from at least in the world of hip-hop and he has a strong affinity for boom-bap hip hop as well as jazz rap soul samples but he is a purveyor of bold experimentation - he's not afraid to put together a strange beat and off-kilter beat a dark beat especially on this album I mean look at that cover not exactly sunny days and birds tweeting now I was not crazy about this guy's last full-length LP album of the year what do you want me to say I just feel like on that album it was so apparent that black milk's lyrical abilities are not really up there with his production abilities and while yeah that's sort of a consistent thing throughout all of his LPS maybe the gap was wider there than it ever has been before but I no poison no paradise I think that gap is closing in a pretty big way I wouldn't say lyrically Black Milk is blowing me away but certainly what he doesn't have inflow or sort of really clever punchlines he makes up for in just how reflective personal relatable and a descriptive of his life his experiences this album is the instrumentals on this thing the beats the kicks thud the snares are dirty he loves to use a lot of sawtooth wave synthesizers I usually prefer a very smooth square-wave but they work in his favor a lot of the time make his beats really rough and they add to that grimy feel that he loves to deliver he's really great at bringing together some jazzy samples on this record some soulful samples on this record as well and I would say that even though no poison no paradise is a pretty grimy album I mean there's just filth on this LP urban decay uh still that does not stop it from being really melodic cinematic the track interpret sabotage which opens this album up it's a great track a killer opener a song that lyrically seems to be about Black Milk kind of aging in the rap game fighting to stay relevant fighting to stay interesting continue giving fans that next evolution that new and he talks about this in a really speedy and passionate flow and it brings the song some serious urgency and the instrumental here has a very simple drum beat but it is lifted with some very nicely placed synthesizer strings and some very catchy melodic leads as well usually a much bigger on sample based hip-hop you know I just love the way that samples get twisted and looped and so on and so forth but I really am drawn toward a lot of the synth based stuff that Black Milk does on this LP like the song ghetto DMF which is obviously a reference to the Detroit electronic music festival and that electronic feel is sort of reflected in the beat with the heavy use of synthesizers and the skittering hi-hats the synthesizer sort of have a phaser quality to them really the track with reference to this festival is more of a very gritty and dark portrait of the city that he comes from and quali Criss drops in on the back end with a lyrical feature with a with a very Randy verse I love the instrumental to the song dismal as well another dark track and synth heavy track it's got a bit of an eerie Halloween vibe to it but still very gritty and lyrically it's a song where Black Milk kind of reflects on a loss a shrinkage in his fame in his success and how that's a bit of psychological torture to him I also love the roughs in leads and the bubbling arpeggios on attract parallels it's a nice backdrop to black milk's lyrics which are kind of romantic seductive about attraction to this woman and sort of a very intimate moment that they're having and I like the song moneybags too which is also very synth heavy and funky because of it the leads on this thing are bright they're kind of noisy the production is solid the issue is that the tracks that are less lyrically driven maybe the beats are not wowing enough or progressed enough or detailed enough to be interesting from beginning to end like the track Sonny jr. which is a song that has Robert Glasper appearing musically very nice jazz hip hop fusion and a good groove just not a track that to me is fiery and interesting from beginning to end and then there's the song X chords which is one of the more playful tracks on this LP where the synthesizers are kind of cartoony but I don't find every melodic element in this track to be all that interesting to me the song ends up more of a mess than anything and maybe that was kind of intentional because of how tongue-in-cheek the song feels but maybe there is sort of an issue with song structure occasionally on this album because it does hinder some of the lyrically driven songs on here like codes and cab fares with black thought and because of how subdued and underwhelming the instrumental and sort of the pacing of the song is even though I do like how dark and moody the song is and I do like the lyrics on this track too when Black Thought finally appears it seems like such an anti climactic moment and there are moments on here too where the overall rough and somewhat lo-fi sound of this album does kind of hold it back a bit especially when it comes to Black Milk EQ ngahiwi tongue a track that features a lot of pianos organs some tight drum fills and this very soulful instrumental serves as a nostalgic backdrop for Black Milk to kind of spit and wax poetic about older times when he would hang out with his friend the real sort of subject of this track is sort of how Black Milk is having a hard time getting along with this person's mother and how she sees him is you get out of here it's a pretty funny trip down memory lane but there are some moments here where it feels like Black Milk is a little underwhelming poetically about how he takes the blame because everyone expects him to be insane or the closing track on here where he says that because he's not able to pay his bills he feels like he's falling there's also a line on this track as well where it's like if you don't make dollars then you don't make sense some of the Rhymes and wordplay on this album are basic but maybe not as laughably so as it was on album of the year and I do feel like again this is sort of made up for by the very true to life and from the harsh storytelling that Black Milk is delivering like on the song Sunday's best and Monday's worst which the Sunday's best track has a sample that feels gospel inspired and it's a song about being a kid and getting up on Sunday going to church the family the deacon you're pretending to be sick you'd rather be playing video games it's all there later in the track referencing how as an adult he sort of chose the wrong path made some bad moves and that's essentially where the track Monday's worst comes in where we find Black Milk sort of plotting on doing some dirt robbing this guy who's drunk outside of a club taking his chain and I love the soulful hook on this track to sing about how it's never too late to get your values straight and it's cool to see this connection between these two tracks and there are other connections between two tracks on here as well other pairs of tracks songs like parallels as well as X chords because X chord sort of seems to be the sexy moment that follows the seduction of parallels and then there is Sonny jr. which is kind of like this jazzy dream sequence before Sunday's best then there's also perfected on Putnam Ave which is kind of this dreamy positive light-hearted trip backwards into nostalgia land like many other tracks on here are but right after that is the song dismal which is more about the current adult state of affairs where Black Milk is sort of not seeing that much hope in his career right now there are some well-formed dichotomies on this LP between the past and the present the good and the bad making positive and negative choices in your life being a success being a failure but still despite all of that hoping for the best at the end of all of it I love this out I think it's very good I think it's well put together I think I have a few issues with it maybe it's a little too low-key I wish it was just more I guess in your face with how great it is is is plus there are some points where the mixing is just okay in the vocally cueing like I said and the clothes are on here the money bags track while I do feel like much of what Black Milk suffering sort of comes down to is lack of money and maybe that's why this track ends the album off musically sonically it still feels like a somewhat anti climactic closure and not really the most poignant finish to you know an album that seems as personal and as reflective as this there are some spots where I feel like this album could be just tighter more cohesive maybe flow a little bit better in a storyline sort of way but still I I feel like even in this disjointed State no poison no paradise is still an incredibly telling and uh relatable album I'm feeling a light a decent eight on this thing transition but if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Black Milk forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's busiest music nerd and this is a review of the new four tet album beautiful rewind for tet is the pseudonym of electronic music producer kiran Hebden this is his seventh full-length LP if you're counting the compilation of singles that he dropped last year pink and musically this guy has had an incredibly interesting evolution look at his discography he has tripped through numerous electronic music genres and some not so electronic bringing together elements of house music and IDM with jazz he's also dabbled in glitch full chronica his compositions have also had a bit of hip-hop influences well but his most recent album sound a lot like their coming from the micro house minimal techno oh tech house side of things getting the bounce of those 4 or 4 beats but with tracks that aren't exactly poppy and really hard-hitting more introspective more odd subtle experimental especially on pink which even though that album was a series of different singles still a release that was pretty cohesive in that you had a series of songs that were very stripped back for four tet definitely a change in pace from the very lovely and lush there is lovin you one of my favorite four tet albums and beautiful rewind is essentially a continuation of that evolution that four tet has been on since like you know forever and i like it it's a very short sweet and textured tech house album straightforward grooves rough samples very rich synthesizers some hypnotic rhythms with a few different musical detours here and there across the 11 tracks here like there is one song that is a two-step foray into future garage there are some hints here and there to ambien music and then there is the song unicorn which is this synth arpeggiated track where it feels like you're getting this one synthesizer sample looped over and over and over different pitches and speeds one sample being dropped on top of another for about three minutes and then it kind of coasts downward and fades out it's got a bit of a whoa no tricks point never vibe to it honestly but without all of the nostalgic chic a lot like OPN on this record for tet seems to favor outright experimentation adventure i guess he's at a point right now in his career where it feels like doing something sort of left field at least for him again is more interesting than doing what's comfortable I feel like for Ted is on his way to kind of carving out his own little niche in this sound that he's shooting for like the song dong the opener to this LP it has a lot of very speedy break beats hammering away in the background it's a track that is sonically a little money and maybe intentionally so but I feel like it takes away so much punch from the song because of it still the song is layered with some really odd interesting tones what feels like a sound Bowl or a really nice bell is ringing out in a very long hung gated way just calling out against these beats again it's a sharp groove a very busy song and really there is so much sound here that it's like kind of crackling in the mix a bit varying cacophonous and the progressions are really buried in all of this cacophony I do dig it it's not epic like I do enjoy my four tet songs to be you know that very slow awesome engaging from beginning to end rising action but still the songs that he ends up delivering are of some quality at least like the songs cool FM and bullsh tracks that have incredibly hard-hitting grooves that are very dirty some odd vocal samples to set against these pretty noisy beats cool FM has the sort of surprise start/stop quality to it while bullsháá has this very dark droning bassline very moody song it's sort of glitchy as well and I think one of the most emotionally intense tracks that for Ted has put out since there is love and you then there's the song aerial which features quite a bit of hand drums in the track very lively song it feels like a freaking from circle it's colorful its energetic there are all these weird muffled vocal samples playing against this noisy beat sort of like listening to a crazy radio DJ try to announce over this song and the song your body feels with these very gentle vocal samples playing throughout it is a very serene track I think one of the more tender tracks on this LP at least one of the tender tracks on this LP that is fun to listen to you from beginning to end because there are quite a few underwhelming moments on here that don't go quite as hard and I feel like are kind of lacking because of it like the track our navigation which is that song I alluded to earlier that goes into a future garage direction with a two-step beat but even though for Tet I feel like is trying to make his mark doing a different take on each of these electronic music styles that he jumps onto with this record this is maybe one of the least bold of the eleven tracks here then there is the song crush which is sort of an experimental footnote of sorts and comparison with all the other songs on here while it is very off kilter not very memorable and then there is ba teaches yoga which is this very fast twittering rhythmatic piece with so much sound and very light breezy sound all coinciding at once to the point where the song really feels like an ethereal drone of sorts it borders on ambient a bit with how it hangs in the background it sort of loses my attention so quickly structurally it's not really a highlight for me and that is maybe my biggest issue with this album I feel like for Ted delivers a lot of great grooves on here but how he orders them in terms of a song structure it just doesn't make much for an impact here it's really how good the grooves are and just how great the beats are and how good some of the funky synth lines are that keep this album engaging I'm just not seeing that level of ambition to sort of take these songs to the next level pull them out of these somewhat low fight doldrums and really give them some body and some size and some girth I'm feeling a decent of strong seven on this LP an addition but if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it for Tet beautiful rewind forever

vocally lead dream pop track that is pretty sweet on the ears and then there's the song let go one of the slower tracks on this LP one of the earlier and more wintry tracks on this LP a song that also feels inspired by a relationship where you can't get away this track like others on here that do feel like they have some kind of romantic route in them the lyrics at times can be sort of basic in terms of description and it makes it difficult really separating these songs and getting a different emotional vibe from each of them still I do like the tune of the track a lot in the very ghostly vocal harmonies on the song sort of scratch a special itch in my eardrums I guess overall as an album it sort of feels like a mixed bag of tracks that sort of all follow a similarly dark blue print and there are quite a few tracks on here that while not terrible are sort of underwhelming and just pale in comparison to others I think blood tears is decent but there are enough highlights and interesting moments on here and especially catchy choruses that make me feel like there could be more interesting stuff coming from this project into the future I'm feeling a strong six to a light seven on this thing transition but if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantan Oh sisu blood tears forever

hi everyone Anthony Pham tan Oh here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Arcade Fire album reflector Grammy award-winning famed Montreal rock band considered by many to be indie rock kingpins known for their lavish instrumentation epic and femme ik songwriting and very emotive vocals from front couple wind Butler and régine Chassagne since the mid-2000s the band put out three full-length studio albums that I and many other people consider to be great for years the band has been celebrated as this group that just pushes things further reaches higher just has this massive amount of ambition and I was pretty excited to see that playing out into this next record of theirs reflector in LP that looked fantastic before its release that looked fantastic on paper we're talking about a pretty interesting cover here a double album James Murphy of LCD Soundsystem and DFA records Fame taking the reins on production for a lot of these tracks and on the lead single the title track to this album that was released months in advance of this LP fantastic song a track that embraced the tenets of disco and is one of my favorite tracks of this year this single and all the other elements that I just mentioned added up into me being super excited for this album and overall I gotta say Arcade Fire does go in some kind of direction with this thing I do feel like this is a more groove oriented record for Arcade Fire I think this is a slightly popular record for Arcade Fire those still very epic and long-winded I do think there are some really strong lyrical themes running throughout this thing maybe a little bit more obvious than what was happening on the suburbs but despite all of that I feel like this record still fell short of my expectations I want to start off with the lyrics on this thing because I think they are my favorite piece of the recipe that Arcade Fire tries to pull together you have a myriad of different song subjects and just one liners on here that deal with troubled love heaven hints toward Greek mythology with Orpheus and and you're a dice with songs that essentially talk about seduction attraction and a lot like on the suburbs there are a number of tracks on here that sort of deal with being an outsider being on the fringe I feel like the first song to kind of hit with that message is we exist a track that lyrically to me feels like the band is singing about being this smaller group against this greater power sort of having the face or having to live in the world of a majority that may be morally or ideologically they don't really agree with and this majority is trying to ignore them and count them out similar themes sort of run through tracks like Joan of Arc and normal person and then there's flashbulb eyes another track on here a lot like reflector deals with this current vanity age or fame with wind making reference to the old wives tale that when you get your picture taken it steals your soul and then there's porno where you seem to have this male narrator singing to a female in a way kind of apologizing or just being upset about these two living in a world where they just don't see eye to eye with the sexual standards or what constitutes sexy lyrically I feel like reflector has a lot to offer on the surface and on a more subtle level to maybe there are a few hooks like on songs such as you already know an afterlife where the lyrics are a little redundant or overly simplistic like you are right you know or scream and shout till we work it out but that's it it's musically where I feel like this album sort of fails to entertain instead of embarking on another group of immaculately layered songs Arcade Fire instead delivers a musical jumble a stylistic hodgepodge of different genres across the length of reflector without much attention or care toward whether or not all of these sounds are flowing together well as a record and a lot of the time I don't even really feel like they're putting that much care into whether or not they're doing some of these genres justice I've already said I like the song Elector which obviously goes into a bit of a disco direction and then there is we exist which feels kind of New Wave influenced and that's a song that I like too it's got a very mid-paced easygoing dance music beat a warm synth bassline some shimmering guitars it feels like a very moody nocturnal take on the instrumental to Madonna's like a virgin but the tune of the song is great and a lot like reflektor Arcade Fire manages to take this epic anthemic feel of their music draw it out against a very hypnotic groove and just progress the song with different layers of instrumentation keep things engaging and keep things entertaining in the process then there is normal person where it feels like Arcade Fire is is trying to play with the idea of this being a bit of a live recording or something thanking people for coming out and opening the singing line of the track asking them if they like rock and roll music and while this track does sound rock and roll instrumentally there's kind of an awkwardness to how the instrumentation links up and it feels like there's a bit of a tongue-in-cheek vibe to the way the music is being played of course the song lyrically sort of takes shots at society and bringing that together with a weird portrayal of a popular music genre I can't really think of anything that is more Talking Heads also the big distorted chorus and the wailing lead guitars as well as the the faint distorted and kind of buried horns in the background of this thing it's a great track it's very well put together even if it is kind of fuzzy and just really over modulated which I'm sure was intentional there's also the very heavy dramatic and driving song it's never over hey Orpheus another favorite of mine on here hey oh yes the groove on this thing is hypnotic it just captures me and I'm like yes I am so happy James Murphy is doing production on this because this is one of the moments where his influence is is most apparent this song and the next track on here porno which is a bit of a subdued track with a bit of electronic drums in the background some synthesizers playing a very big role yes there is a bit of a new wave post-punk minimal synth influence here but it's very stripped back sort of reminds me of moments from the LCD Soundsystem's last full-length LP tracks like I can or somebody's calling me and while I think the production is decent I'm more enamored with the message of the song and the tune of it more than anything sadly that's about it for highlights for me I only liked about half of the songs on this album and many of the other tracks here I just find to be half-hearted imitations of different genres that Arcade Fire just wanted to pursue on this LP for no other reason than to do them like the song flashbulb eyes I just don't find anything entertaining or good about hearing wind butler moan over this sort of straight back dancehall beat that is kind of underwhelming there are some echo effects over his voice and a lot of the instrumentation here and it's really turned up too much to the point where the song doesn't really read it feels like a dub reggae nightmare and then there's the song here comes the night where it feels like the vocals are really too distorted as well as the bass and they're presented so upfront and in-your-face in a way where it's kind of claustrophobic something that I feel like works for an LCD soundsystem song but doesn't do this tune too much justice I do like the song here the melody the piano playing is pretty quaint but again I feel like we're delivered and instrumental here that is just not really a flattering portrayal of a Caribbean style of music not only that but I feel like Arcade Fire continues this faux live feel on this track and it results in some of the instrumentation feeling way less explosive than it should be like the outro where they really kind of kick up the tempo all the instrumentation is going incredibly fast you have these guitar strumming very quickly and the song here only ends up feeling like sort of a dull drone rather than an exciting explosion of feeling and instrumentation you have the song you already know with this quirky playful silly rock bass line and this drumbeat that kind of feels like it could back a song from the grease soundtrack groove wise the song just feels really stiff and kind of corny the only thing the song is missing is a group of backup singers going wow wow then there's the track Joan of Arc which starts off with this distorted fast punk rock intro but then kicks into this slowed down tempo that delivers a guitar riff and a B that feels like a slow-motion version of a sweet song it's got a hard rock glam rock vibe to it but none of the joy fun or viscera the track just feels like bad emulation with very very little attention to musical detail and not only that but as the song progresses a growing problem is that it doesn't stay interesting as the band starts to draw this slow rock beat out longer than it really should be awful sound sort of an underwhelming ballad which has some distance strings that kick in and really sort of brings home the title of the song but then the second half of this track instead of being underwhelming is sort of a slightly insipid explosive feel-good folk rock opera that just does not vibe with me all too well then there is supersymmetry the closer on here which I don't even know what hour Kade fire was going for on this track an incredibly anti-climactic closer with some sequence drums some synthesizers and I feel like the rush of instrumentation and the experimental last six or five minutes of this track are more interesting than the tune itself because winds and Regine's vocals are so buried and so comatose that the song isn't even really entertaining so in short I did not dig this album as much as Arcade Fire's previous LPS was it what they said no the lyrics on this thing are solid was it the tunes necessarily only a few of the melodies and the tunes and the songs on here I felt were unlikable the problem is Arcade Fire wanted to make this overblown double disc album and ended up neglecting flow in a huge way cohesion musical cohesion between the songs and for Arcade Fire the sound of these songs was incredibly unimpressive - even with James Murphy being credited as a producer on this album historically the let's try to sound like this song and let's try to sound like this band and let's try to do that hook that formula works really well for James Murphy but it did not work out for Arcade Fire on this album there are two new wave songs on here and a few tropical songs on here and if you disco oriented songs on here a bit of rock and roll a bit of Afrobeat and they only end up doing some of it justice I'm feeling a strong five on this thing transition but if you've given the cell peal listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantan Oh Arcade Fire reflector forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here Internet's busiest music nerd going to do a quick simple straightforward review of the new glasser album interiors glasser is the musical project of producer singer songwriter Cameron my sorrow this is her second full-length album her full-length debut ring kind of a short LP but still one of my favorites of that year brought together elements of electronic production and MIDI and her really beautiful soaring vocals and the the style of just music underneath her vocals was really synthetic but also very primal very i want to say basic or simple but there was kind of this rudimentary old-world feel to the grooves and just the pacing and the and the growth in the progression of the tracks that was kind of seductive beautiful hypnotizing and something that just fell archaic in kind of away now this LP did earn Cameron some Bjork comparisons all around from numerous music fans and critics as well and while there was a really obvious influence they're coming from the world of bjork it didn't really get me down because i thought the songs were so catchy the melodies were so good and i thought this very rootsy primal feel to some of the beats and the progressions of the songs had glasser kind of in its own little camp you know like oh this is obviously an influence but this is her style this is something that she approaches songs with this is something that if I heard it in one of her songs I'd be like oh well this is definitely a glass or song so I wasn't really down with the whole like make up your comparison but sort of in a negative light kind of thing because I was appreciating what glasser was doing as a project on its own and I wasn't even hoping I was just assuming it was a sure thing that on glasses next full-length LP not only would her influences diversify a little bit in her music at least because I know she's an artist like Laurie Anderson who I also have a great love for her work but I just expect did this sophomore full-length LP to be a bit more original and honestly I can't even say that it is as original as glass errs debut in fact I feel like there is an increased production value on this album which is good and I think the compositions and the atmosphere are a little more vast but I feel like glass or has taken all of this extra all of this new effort and merely put it toward I don't even want to say it this album just sounds like a Bjork imitation it's it just hurts to say because I was like ah you know I don't think she sounds that much like Bjork to the point where I would cringe or think okay this should all right but honestly everything from the fluttering somewhat glitchy instrumentation in the background to the melodic phrasing and the vocals there are so many songs on this album that don't even sound like a myriad of different places in Bjork's ever-growing career a lot of these songs just sound like they could have been on vespertine which is my favorite Bjork album but even though it does feel like there is a clear influence from that album this LP is way less textured than vespertine and and way less layered instrumentally in way less epic as well and honestly there's not too much about this LP that I can say there are a few songs on here that remind me of a few of the songs on ring and I don't mind that I think that's fine I guess I was just perplexed listening to this album as to what I kind of see as a huge step backwards rather than forwards into a more interesting or just a more distinct sound because with the last full-length I think glasser had a pretty good thing going with this combination of primal beats and futuristic synthetic tones and her voice on top of it it was something that I feel like had potential and it seems like she in a sense has sort of scrapped that and while I don't normally get automatically disappointed by some artists showcasing and influence from another artist this is just one of those cases where the influence is so deafening I don't hear anything else but if you've given this glass or album will listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana glasser forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for your review of milla phobia fear of music from the band Cage the Elephant I know more free them now free them today free free free them no more in the cage none never no more free free I hate couch acosta Cage the Elephant is an alternative rock band and with the release of mellow phobia they are on their third full-length LP and truthfully I have not really been a huge fan of their previous output mostly because when I listen to their stuff I just don't really feel like I'm I'm missing out on anything sure it seems like Cage the Elephant is into some really good modern bands like hives the vines white stripes of course the Pixies maybe a little bit of underground or left field post hardcore like future of the left or mcklusky but I just think some songs of theirs like ain't no rest for the wicked are just unbearably corny like on this level of like Kid Rock whitey Ford sings the blues sort of cringe-worthy songwriting but with the sort of snide indie rock vocal it's just that there's this really underwhelming sense of ambiguity that I feel like runs through their first two albums where when I'm done listening to them I just feel like who is this band what is their sound what is their direction what are they doing I'm just not sure I was gonna skip over melophobia I wasn't gonna listen to it but out of recommendation by a lot of people whose musical tastes I trust and a lot of people who watch the show I decided to check it out and was pleasantly surprised and in my opinion this is Cage the elephant's most consistent album in terms of the way that it sounds and some writing quality the production the mix and the instrumentation is great it all sounds punchy clear well balanced and yet there is kind of this gritty dirty low-five vibe to the recording as well that feels like it's intentional place there just to make things a little dirty stylistically it still feels like cage the elephant is coming from that same place with alternative rock blues rock a garage rock on this LP I would actually say that cage the elephant sounds like the black lits if they could pass a drug test mr. Matt Schultz vocals are still really over the top whimpering maybe some people would say whining and I wouldn't exactly say that his lyrics have evolved into pure 14-karat nuggets of gold but I don't think there's a single song on this LP where he comes off as obnoxious or unlistenable or just generally unenjoyable I think the most unenjoyable vocal on this entire LP actually comes from Alison Mosshart who at the end of the song it's just forever is sort of displaying the definition of overacting while singing and there are a lot of songs on here that I think are great the LP kicks off really well with the song spider head not a bad tune with some fun catchy sweet melodic guitar leads as well as some plinky pianos I also love the really weird skip edits that occur toward the end of the track that lead into a pretty nice guitar solo I think maybe the weakest link in the chain is the lyrics talking about spiders in your head and your mind she took your eyes but you're not blind not exactly Shakespearean and not exactly going so far into absurdity that it's like oh but it is kind of a breath of fresh air to not be cringing at the lyrics in the way that I have on previous caves the elephant releases come a little closer another track on here that's not too bad the lead single from this album and explosive song that when I first heard it didn't really think too much of it but it really has grown on me since the song has these really subdued verses that are pretty short feel a little surf rock influenced to an extent Matt Schulze is really downplaying his vocal in a big way and then when the song explodes on the chorus with these multiple layers of instrumentation and what I like so much is that we had this low-five vibe here and yet the song seems so huge and seems so epic and layered it's a pretty beautiful come a little closer and you see the ending of the track is pretty explosive too to me says a lot about caves the elephant's maturity with their songwriting on this LP even though all the songs here are pretty much a verse chorus verse structure the band is really great at sort of throwing some little surprises in here or bringing some significant instrumental changes from one part of the song to the other so that there's a lot of variety there's a lot of color there's a lot of personality the song telescope being one moment that I think is an example of that and I think a song that is actually interesting from a lyrical standpoint a track that tells a story of paint a character portrait about a person who's a bit of a recluse I won't go any further into the lyrics than that and I think it's a beautiful tune a frontrunner for my favorite on this LP and kind of has that tenderness to it that a song like a day in the life from the Beatles has I especially like the vocal bridge toward the end of the track with the beating drums in the background it's a really nice piece of progression for the song again Cage the Elephant impressing me with the way that they build these songs and move them from point A to point B there's actually another ballot on here called cigarette daydreams which is the closer it's kind of a short track a little anticlimactic for the last song but another tender moment that goes over pretty well I actually like the strange sections on this track a lot the bowed strings the plucks strings I think all over track 4 track 4 track these songs have a really nice layer of subtlety that previous Cage the Elephant albums just lack and this subtlety even carries on through to the more aggressive and hard-hitting and catchy songs like the song halo which has these multiple instrumental shifts throughout with these downstroke guitars on the chorus and some pianos through the verses and stylistically especially with Matt Schulze vocals the song feels like kind of a hybrid between a stroke song and a Vampire Weekend song to me that's sort of the appeal in the combination of influences too on the track take it or leave it not two tracks on this LP that are favorites of mine maybe because of where they're coming from is a little too obvious but I guess they're pretty successful at bringing that straightforward rock-and-roll swagger a van like The Strokes but also that sort of boyish armed that Vampire Weekend has there are more surprising moments on this LP though like the track Black Widow which is this hard rocking sultry horn backed tune that is about seduction and Matt Schulze is singing all over this track with a really goofy weird falsetto oh there's a good row and then there's the track teeth which I think is another favorite of mine on here not only the most authentically wild song I've ever heard from Cage the Elephant but actually a weird song for just about any band these days a track that starts off with this really wild cacophonous rock instrumentation that to me feels like coming from that post hardcore background a little bit eventually progressing the track into this really nasty weird sax solo and then an odd space of spoken-word that's really off kilter and kind of unsettling again to an extent I feel like we are delivered an album from Cage the Elephant that is all over the place it's kind of schizophrenic but they did a much better job this time at finding a sound finding a production style that links all of these songs together even as Matt Schulze goes through just as much schizophrenia with his vocals I like this LP I was surprised pleasantly surprised how good many of the tracks on this LP were the production is great the performance and execution of the instrumentation on this album as well is raw it feels really in the moment it feels alive and it feels natural the melodies are solid the choruses are really infectious even on the songs that I'm not too crazy about there's quite a bit of detail and personality I'm feeling a strong seven to a light eight on this thing transition but if you've given this Cage the Elephant Album oh listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it also I have a new music video review video over at the maker hi everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new toxic Holocaust album chemistry of consciousness toxic Holocaust is a metal outfit that right now I believe is portland-based and is fronted by singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist Joel grind this is their fifth full-length studio LP and for years this project has been dropping music that has been a pretty seamless combination of thrash metal punk rock a bit of black metal which was placed into the equation ever so subtly overdose of death being an LP that I think brought some of Toxic Holocaust most well crafted songs yet to the table ferocity variety and detail and the songs on this record and then there was conjure and command that dropped a few years ago which showed toxic Holocaust bringing a better recording to the table the band sounding much heavier thicker just who probably the most visceral album to come out of this project and Joel really subtracted the black metal influences from this record in a big way and just sort of stuck simply to the thrash metal and the punk sounds that they had been playing with for the most part up to that point anyway there's no question on this album Joel really simplified the Toxic Allah to some of its most aggressive just no BS elements and that sort of left me wondering or fearing that maybe the next album would entertain me a bit less because there would surely be a lack of surprises on it I do kind of feel like that is happening here to at least some degree I guess the recording and the production on this record are a bit thicker a bit more distorted Joel's vocal delivery is roughly the same if toxic Holocaust goes in any direction with this album I think they actually boil things down even further because many of the heavy slower or more ominous moments from the projects previous LP conjure and command are sort of subtracted and even though that means that on this LP are not really waiting around for the song as the start kickin ass it's just one non-stop ass-kicking fest what that has also created here is an album that to me feels a lot less dynamic than its predecessors toxicology leaves no room for finesse whatsoever and they really lay the weight of this album success on to the guitar riffs which are by no means bad they're executed very well again the grooves are hard-hitting they're infectious but toxic Holocaust guitar riffs don't exactly have a track record of being incredibly original or distinct for me on toxic Holocaust previous stuff the riffs and the beats were just a really good foundation for some more interesting things that brought this base flavor and that would be some interesting lyrical concepts that were grim or dark or socially aware some guitar leads or melodies that were memorable may be an interesting bridge and the song structure or a song that was kind of a coming out of left field in a darker or slower tone or something these variants don't introduce themselves enough on this album to make the entire listening experience memorable there are highlights on here though like the sort of slow and feedback filled out row to the closing track here or the ominous guitar peji OHS on the song rat eater which opened the song up there are some refrains some courses on here that are pretty memorable like acid fuzz the guitar solo is pretty badass on that track too and then we have some lyrical ideas like deny the truth we're obviously we have Joel talking about in the lyrics this blatant refusal to believe what is true and sort of right in front of your face just self-imposed ignorant and then there's the track MKULTRA which I'm not sure how many thrash metal songs there are out there about top secret government projects but this is one of the few one of the proud and honestly throughout this LP there's not really one huge moment where I feel like it falters or Joel comes through with a horrible song the production is crushing the riffs again passable the album is fast paced there is an element of just adrenaline-pumping madness - the way these guitars and drums work together I liked this album but I'm just not seeing what toxicology is doing here that they haven't already done better on their previous releases so I'm feeling a light - decent six on this thing transition but if you've given this toxic Holocaust LP a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana toxic Holocaust forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review this is a review of the new fi record burials these guys are a hardcore punk outfit that dropped some of its most aggressive albums in the late 90s and early 2000s and they didn't really do this sub-genre of rock much justice at all with a series of albums that didn't feature much in the way of variation interesting riffs or hooks and honestly I think davey havok svos is one of my least favorite in punk rock ever there's not really a single AFI record that I like there are a few that I think are alright but I'm just letting you know where I'm coming from now in the mid-2000s this band really refined it sound cleaned its sound up sort of kept the punk thing on the backburner a bit but we're embracing a lot of these popular sounds and emo in indie rock and even though Havoc's locals took a turn for the incredibly whiny and not in a flattering way this change in AFIS career resulted in albums that had more variation and a few pretty big hits like with the LP December underground with the track miss murder but even that album did end up disappointing a lot of the Bands older fans because of how radio-friendly their sound was going and even though there is sort of the sentiment that oh AFI went mainstream AFI did this a if I did that in every single phase of AFIS career and there have been a lot of phases they've always sort of been this virtually unoffensive somewhat watered down version of something much more interesting in the world of underground rock the band's bland ways have not changed at all on this new LP burials and even though their sound has altered a little bit they're not singing the praises of emo as much on this LP or indie rock or even hardcore punk I actually think the band moves in a somewhat Moody dark and Atmospheric alt-rock direction if it wasn't for the fact that the songs are so succinct and chorus driven and void of experimentation I would maybe call it post-punk there are some spots here where it feels like AFI is trying to be a little edgy or hard-hitting but the raspy shouts and the toothless guitar chords on most these tracks just do nothing for me neither do the cleanly sung vocals which are harmonized a lot of the time and it's not even the foe aggressive sounds that AFI puts into its songs that really gets to me it's the surface level melodrama that I feel like is presented in a lot of these tracks that's a huge turnoff to this is the kind of boring modern rock aggression that I erased from my life when I traded all of my new metal CDs in an FYE which I actually did yesterday and I got a pretty good price for my copy of disturbs the sickness so throughout this entire LP afi's attempts at heavy and hard fall incredibly short offensively short for anybody who has actually heard anything heavy or hard again like I said before there are some moments here like the start of a few tracks where I'm hearing some Spacey guitars lots of reverb and I feel like I might hear something that feels a little interpol influenced or maybe Joy Division influenced but instead I'm just getting this dramatic melodic pop punk that feels like it is way too reverb to really grasp at the lyrics or the meet of the instrumentation even the song wild feels like I'm hearing a pretty decent pop punk influenced band play a song on the other end of a sewer pipe with some pretty weird vocal sampling and some obnoxious keyboards now even AFI has fallen victim to modern musics addiction to reverb cover-up bland songwriting cover uninteresting vocals all with this magical mystical effect we have a falsely dark atmosphere on this album that is just a front for incredibly sterile rock music songs like a deep flow panic are a little more straightforward a little more upfront and tangible but still this style of pop punk feels so dated to me I'd much rather listen to an old My Chemical Romance record at least at that time that band had personality and ambition with the way that it wrote its songs overall even though there are some spots on here where I did like the dark atmospheres before I realized that they weren't that dark or interesting not a single song on your had anything to offer for me this album is overblown under written and covered with too much reverb to the point where it just takes away what little teeth this album has for a rock album that as its foundation uses a style of music that is one of the most biting styles in rock music this LP is a lot like getting gummed to death just like burials in a nutshell just being chewed by these slimy little gums I'm feeling a strong to to a light 3 on this thing transition but if you've given the cell peal listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana AFI burials forever
