hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new armand hammer LP race music armand hammer is a newly formed hip hop duo out of New York consisting of MCS a lucid and Billy woods Seleucid pretty underground guy on the come-up you may remember him from his numerous features on a bunch of different Billy woods tracks and Billy woods you might remember him from some reviews I did of his recent LPS the latest of which door candy I think might have grown on me a little bit since I initially reviewed it however I really pronounced the name of that LP wrong quite a few times in that review woods and a lucid kind of debuted this duo a little earlier this year back in September with a mixtape that had quite a few tracks on it it really seems like a less polished and more grimy and sort of more rough around the edges not necessarily in a flattering way version of what we're being delivered on race music Billy pretty much still comes through with that flow where it's like half spoken word half passionately shouted lyrically Billy's bars add up into what feels like an incredibly scattered narrative a lot of very gritty and potent and very vivid but disjointed imagery that sometimes until you've heard the entire track and paid really close attention time after time after time then you're able to kind of figure out how it all comes together and tells a story but still even not totally understanding what a lot of these songs are about Billy's very sharp wit and his dark sense of humor really rings through on lines like bad trip like you had to take the bus back or weeks with no sleep I'm living the dream don't really want to know how it go like ground beef a mother's grief Billy never comes through on this LP with a sharp or a speedy flow not really his thing really he's the kind of guy instead who will space all of his words out and emphasize things like raw emotion and concept a lot like Billy woods history will absolve me from 2012 you just get one track after another that dives into a different theme some very obvious from the lyricism and the title of the track itself and others need lots of replay in order to fully comprehend because making sense of some of these tracks it's really like putting puzzle pieces together like the song hatchet job which doesn't really tell a direct direct story but if you pull all the various lines together it kind of tells something about doing dirt and not being able to trust someone or some people who you're working with they're dealing with them sort of being in fear of a double-cross and you've got moments lyrical irritability Woods is saying you know white man handshake twinkle and I this new guy's got my spidey senses tingling later in the track you're getting these lines about maybe some of this coming back to hurt your family and on the track Sunnis blues you get what is essentially a lot of imagery dealing with much of the conflict going on in the Middle East right now especially it gets really vivid on the verse lucid drops toward the end of the track with children being mangled but maybe from the perspective of the person seeing this it's all for a just cause then you've got the track Willy basket which is a really standout track on here because of how dark and just sad it is with its subject matter you've got kind of mental illness on this track kids who are essentially underprivileged living in urban areas and are suffering from serious aggressive mental diseases and don't really have anywhere or anyone to turn to and the track actually gets pretty disturbing with a lucid rapping narrating about one particular kid and sort of the suffering he's dealing with and Billy would sort of turns it into another standpoint of a parent or relative or just someone being afraid of what this kid might do just how he lashes out song no roses is sort of about these broken damaged relationships which it seems like there's a lot of adultery kind of being implied back and forth it seems like there are some emotional hang-ups on this track to that I feel like I have to listen to a little bit closer in order to fully get them but then on the back end of this LP we have a song like Nosferatu - which feels like it's another male-to-female relationship dichotomy but what's going on here lyrically just seems like a much more prime evil and and physical sort of lustful kind of thing you've got the song Duffy on here which is actually a term Jamaican Patois for spirit Billy Woods goes into grave detail a situation that went on when he was younger with his father dying and his funeral and what seems like a lot of people in his family turning against his mother because there was some kind of suspicion that his death wasn't accidental and lucid comes through with a verse on the back end of this tract and what I like so much about him is that they both take a concept and it seems like both of them run in a very different way with it and yet it ends up so cohesive he goes into a lot of just incantation type stuff ritualistic type stuff lyrically talks a bit about superstition as well it's a really chilling track and maybe one of the most spacious atmospheric instrumentals in this entire LP then there is hand-over-fist where it seems like we have three different verses with a guest rapper creature hopping on this song and each verse seems to paint a picture of people who seem to have lost their lives to drugs or addiction there's just really sharp detailed concept after sharp detailed concept on this thing where the wild things are you've got kids kind of running wild in the streets fighting gang activity just sort of falling in with the wrong people I love elusive ersan this track sort of talking about sort of the initial fights that kids get into being kind of a gateway into that and having to stand up for yourself and using violence in a kid's youth as a rite of passage of sorts and then we have Billy woods on the back end I feel like talking a little bit about the school system failing kids too and then failing to pull kids out of the cycle of violence there's a really sharp line on here saying Waiting for Superman the classrooms full of kryptonite and then there is new museum a track with four different MCS including a lucid and Billy woods I remember one of my critiques of Billy woods door candy was that we had this longer Posse cut on the LP but I feel like it sort of took away from the concept of the album or didn't come through with a strong theme at least in my opinion but this track definitely does and it's kind of a tongue-in-cheek look at the everyday grind of the modern artist with Billy talking about being addicted to the Internet constantly refreshing always looking for what people are saying about you but always coming across the same handful of mentions you've got open mike eagle rapping about his caliber as an artist and how he should be brought out with the show dogs and how he's so dedicated he never breaks character he's so dedicated he edits his own Wikipedia page a lucid is rapping about NPR think pieces being voted consistently averaged by other rap fans and then bus drivers verses are taking an interesting theme in that they sort of bring the museum thing into place on this track and he's shouting like a ringleader a bit on this song in my opinion and a lot of his verses have to do with very avant-garde odd art that when you see it you actually question whether or not as art just go into this expecting something kind of like a book of different short stories with each tale telling a different story or painting a perspective or a character portrait I should also mention loosens rap style on this album because it is a pretty sharp variation from Billy's and you can really tell the difference between these two rappers not only with how they attack things lyrically but with their flow the sound of their voice two-for-one aloose it has this incredible rasp that sometimes swallows his words a little bit his rasp really is overbearing sometimes kind of like on Aesop rocks latest stuff and he definitely flows a lot more traditionally than a guy like Billy woods does who really spaces his words out however a lucid I wouldn't say because of his flow is any more catchy than Billy woods because a lot of the flows that he uses are constantly changing or really off kilter in a lot of ways he's just as non-traditional they're a pretty good match but I will say that with over an hour of material on this thing it can get a little redundant especially with a lot of the beats on here being so heavy electronic slow noisy however each of these beats do have definitive characteristics like the really whaling off-kilter kind of dissonant sense on the track hatchet job or the rumbling bass and the kind of interesting cult sample on the song new museum I just can't get away from cults their sample too right on the hook hear the song go outside the pianos on frog and toad are friends as well as shark fin soup are pretty nice addition the beyond new roses is one of the speediest and detailed on this entire LP and has this incredible gospel sampling going on in the background it's a chaotic beat but elusive and Billy just cut right through it Willy basket actually goes in a trap direction which we have Billy woods and elusive flowing over this track in the way that a modern young trap trapper normally would but of course the story and the personality that they bring to the table and the very noisy sense in the background really change up the flavor the song hand-over-fist has these odd reed instruments with this really quirky melody sampled in the background that I like a lot that give that song a lot of personality and then there's the song cloisters which is one of the more toned-down soft and jazzy tracks on the album really there's just a lot of variety on this LP despite the fact that it is so dark and the beats again are pretty lumbering I would say that the Achilles heel of this album is though that it is so freakin dense and while for people who are willing to give this album multiple listens given they're already into Billy woods and Anna Lucid style this album rewards it pays out a lot however it is so heavy with these loose puzzling word assemblies that it may scare off some newcomers to Billy woods elusive Armand Hammer whatever definitely not as many instantaneously catchy tracks in comparison to door candy or history will absolve me but in my opinion an album that is about as enjoyable as those two releases I'm feeling a light too decent 8 on this thing transition but if you've given this LP a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantino Armand Hammer forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new cult album static cults are a pop duo who gathered quite a bit of buzz a few years ago with their debut album and some pretty hot singles leading up until that point mostly the song go outside which was maybe one of the most viral songs of that year for sure listening to these songs cults did have a style and aesthetic pulling together pieces of rock-and-roll jangle pop a little bit of Motown some indie pop as well and just being incredibly cutesy with it sugar encrusted like a Sour Patch Kid and on top of it there was just tons of reverb and just a weird vintage gritty sound to the way that they recorded their instruments - that just made everything that they were playing seem much older than it actually was it became pretty apparent that when they put out their full-length debut their style while very distinct was very limited not only were a ton of songs on the band's debut sort of uninspired and unmemorable but very Sammy Sammy - especially in the case of Madeline's vocals on this record which i think was my least favorite thing about this album by the time I was finished with it because of how light and high and limited in range her vocals are this record just becomes very unpleasant to listen to not grading when you first start hearing the band but it slowly becomes very because I felt that cults were very attuned to the styles of music that they were copying a little bit and bringing into their tracks I was hoping that they would mature a little bit onto this sophomore album of theirs that they would bring maybe more layers more depth and just make things poppy but a little more interesting to listen to upon replay but as soon as I heard the first track on this thing sounding like the soundtrack to an eighth grade playing out of busted speakers in 1955 I knew that that was not going to happen cults have not changed their foundational aesthetic had not really changed the core of their music at all they seemed pretty content with where they are and what their sound is one Madeleine fallens vocals haven't changed a bit I actually think they're a little less entertaining this time around because you kind of know what to expect from her with the reverb and the instrumentation on this LP she is incredibly buried so much to the point where it becomes difficult to make out a lot of her lyrics or really make an emotional connection to much of what she's doing I actually found her vocals and a lot of tracks on this LP to be unenjoyable e lethargic take a look at the very comatose duet on the song where before maybe one of the most boring spots in this entire LP and when I can get a good grip of her vocals the melody the cadences or the lyrics like on the song always forever for example it sounds like I'm listening to I don't know a local singing talent show as opposed to somebody who is actually putting out a commercial music release the vocals are just a really huge downside for me on this LP and I don't see myself ever liking a cult album if that doesn't change because with the kind of music that cults play vocals are such a focal point because the melodies and the backing instrumentation are certainly not stealing the show still this time around they're incredibly incredibly basic however I do feel like a bit more ambition and production value came through this time around with layering of instrumentation like the numerous guitar tones layered on top of each other on the track I can hardly make you mine or the sweet organs and the psychedelic effects on always forever the song we've got it has a pretty sweet key change so far has a great string arrangement wrapped around the backing instrumentation songs like we're before and high road would have a very strong backing beat and really separate themselves from the rest of the tracklist with very standout percussion but going to the song high road that is pretty much what's become the biggest track the the lead single if you will with a pretty nice music video off of this LP and in my opinion nowhere near as catchy as anything from the band's last LP I actually think what they do on this track is sort of average for the kind of music that they're trying to play in general you can catch a lot of very schmaltzy poppy organ grooves like this on plenty of Records sitting in the dollar bin at your local thrift store and it's not even the dated style and aesthetic that leaves the feeling so uninspired on this record it's that a lot of the time cults are such slaves to reverb the instrumental progression they make on this album leaves very little impact as far as the instrumentation has been assembled it's not a bad album yes it's really basic yes the melodies don't really stick with me but everything kind of falls into place and it's not that cult sound is necessarily awful it's just that over time it just gets really old and doesn't stay interesting for the duration of a full-length album and that was basically the downfall of their last LP now what makes this album less interesting to me despite the fact that more instrumentation has been thrown into this thing in a nice way it's that there are less memorable songs on this thing this album has much less single power than cults debut it's just got less highlights I'm feeling a light too decent for on this thing transition but if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana cults forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and this is a review of the new dismemberment plan album uncanny valley it would seem that these days there really is no shortage of comeback albums and this record is most certainly proof of that being an album that it's been about a little over 10 years since dismemberment plans last full-length LP i believe they disbanded in the early 2000s and in that time that they were formed as a band they penned a few what people consider to be indie classics like emergency and i which is an album that to be completely honest while i know that a lot of people are living and dying by this LP it's a seminal record for a lot of people in indie rock it's definitely not a favorite of mine i do like a lot of the musical characteristics of the dismemberment plans tracks i like they're typically jagged and and very tight drum beats that are at times dance music influenced the very groovin bass the angular guitars i guess i always gravitated more toward their energetic tracks toward their i don't want to say aggressive since it's it doesn't feel like anger is fueling these songs but they're more over the top and and very fiery songs like girl o'clock and eight and a half minutes i love a magician I thought that I would give this new album of theirs a listen even though a lot of people haven't really been asking me but I'm just personally interested because this really seems to be a band that a lot of people love this new album of theirs to me feels like nearly everything I remember about the dismemberment plan - and this is a big - - all the eccentricities even the drumming has mellowed out in a pretty big way with maybe the most energetic and danceable track on this album being Mexico City Christmas for the most part the drum beats do not feel as sharp or as jagged and they're thrown in the back of the mix a little bit the guitars have a much more equal balance with synthesizers now and they come off much more gentle as well I think the most unchanged characteristic about this whole record is maybe Travis Morrison's voice again you don't have him reaching up into those really frantic highs of his range but he does still have this vocal that feels really youthful feels really boyish and yet there's this strange vibrato to it and this really earnest tone all that's really occurring on this record is dismemberment plan is is merely working with their softer gentler more playful side there are moments when the music in my opinion shoots for a blatantly feel good mood kind of like the track daddy was a real good dancer even though there is sort of a sad personal story going on in the lyrics there I'm definitely trying to advocate for the direction that the band is moving in from an outside perspective I don't think this is a terrible record but does it appeal to me not really the truth is a lot of the music a lot of the guitar phrasing and a lot of the lyricism on this album are insultingly simplistic like the track let's go to the dogs tonight with the opening lyrics about well what is it I'll be the sugar and you'll be the cream I'll be the dreamer and you be the dream and of course these lyrics are delivered with a flow that kind of feels like it's it spaced out like a children's rhyme or something and I mean that could have totally been intentional maybe that is intentional especially with the the level of rhyming and imagery going on here too but I definitely don't feel like Travis Morrison juxtaposed this in a way where it actually feels like an adult can enjoy it not only that but there are tracks on here like go and get it where the music feels much more well suited for a band like okay go that's how saccharine the dismemberment plan sounds on this record and while that wouldn't necessarily be a bad thing I feel like the pop appeal of this record isn't quite as high or as energetic or as thrilling their spots here that I enjoy like the earnestness in the lyrics on the track white collar white trash or even how tender and and wonderfully melodic the song looking is but as I've said before when it comes to more toned down tracks more ballad driven tracks from the dismemberment plan they just don't really thrill me they just don't really move me I guess I could say so not only are there moments where I just wish this record was a bit gutsy er but for music that has a wider pop appeal when you compare to their earlier stuff it isn't particularly catchy or infectious and for music that is much softer and gentler and sweeter than music from their earlier records it's not incredibly moving or in my opinion beautiful so yeah honestly I'm really left out in the cold on this new dismemberment playin album but what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana dismemberment plan forever

they do bad bad zebediah hi everyone Anthony Fantino here intranets busiest music nerd and this is a review of the new Tim Hecker album virgins Tim Hecker is an electronic and ambient music producer hailing from Canada this is his seventh studio LP under his own name and for me a very highly anticipated return from his fantastic 2011 album rave death 1972 and on this LP tends typical blend of ambient music noise and drone got a bit more textured a bit more layered piano really took over on this album in a big way and it felt here more than on other Hecker releases that the instrumentation was kind of live in the moment not only that but all of the sounds combined on this record added up into a very post-apocalyptic vibe it's a great LP if you haven't heard it go listen to it and with this new album though rave death did get a bunch of hype when it first came out it is really a highly praised album I think Tim has hit it out of the park once again right here once again Tim is ambitious with his layers his sound play with his instrumentation with creating a somewhat live feel with the instruments on this record but the instrumentation here seems so much less bleak and wandering than on Tim's past few releases even though virgin's has plenty of soft and sparse moments on its tracks I think this is actually one of Tim's more direct albums a lot of the tracks here are actually quite busy with sound and don't take too long to start don't take too long to build I wouldn't exactly call it fast paced but it definitely is one of Hecker's more tightly composed efforts but that just speaks to the structure of this album as far as the instrumentation goes of course you have piano returning on this record you have harmonium on many tracks here as well what feels like a few different synthesizers and maybe some woodwinds that could just be more harmonium and it feels like Tim played out planned out wrote composed some music for a variety of different tracks here but he grabs the instrumentation or the performances that he made and he reverses parts of them he loops them he chops them he swirls them and layers them and scatters them Tim manipulates a lot of the instrumentation on this record very heavily and yet it doesn't really lose that live-in-the-moment feel that you would get if you were just listening to a quartet or some kind of instrumental music ensemble not only that but Tim just layers piece of instrumentation on top of piece of instrumentation to the point where a lot of these compositions end up feeling a bit like drones and even though these very heavy thick layers may feel a little impenetrable sonically because of just how large and wide they are there are very beautiful melodies and interesting chord progressions that peak through it all to those who are attentive and sort of focused on what's going on Tim Hecker usually approaches his records with an eye on the bigger picture and how the record sounds as a whole and virgin's is no different however even though this album really feels like it was created from a holistic standpoint there is a bit of a disjointed and fractured aesthetic to a lot of the music on this LP as if a lot of what the listener is hearing is being conjured through some kind of distant idea or memory and to me that comes through on just how cloudy and and muddled the melodies can be sometimes with the instrumentation being layered on so heavily so cacophonous Lee but the sounds and the emotions on here though are so vivid this record could really put a dent in the happiest of days but I think Tim Hecker goes about that melancholy and a slightly different in a slightly cleaner way the way this LP starts with the track prism with an incredibly bright drone so bright it's just like staring into the Sun there are these weird shots of reverse piano playing throughout the track and the song just grows more and more and more cacophonous and eventually gives away to the splintered pianos that are layered throughout the second track on here virginal where it feels like Tim Hecker is indulging in a little bit of piano minimalism in a bit of modern classical he's just grabbing this one piano piece which it could be from a bunch of different takes and he's just placing them on top of one another to the point where it feels like you're listening to this piano being played within a Hall of Mirrors it's like you're hearing a repeat of the same piano phrasing being played again and again and again with slight variations on top of one another to the point where it's really dizzying it's an amazing and kind of creative effect and the song just grows heavier and heavier and heavier and eventually coasts down really beautifully toward the finish we also get a little piano part playing toward the end of this track that is cut off that foreshadows to another song around the middle point of this album the next song on here radiant's another very bright drone and kind of a sad melancholy post-rock esque footnote on this album that feels like a bit of a transitionary track not really surprised to kind of see some post-rock influence on this album considering that Tim Hecker record his last EP in the infamous hotel to tango recording studio the first incredibly noisy moment to pop up on this LP is the track live room where you get the same fractured piano approach but playing a different phrase and it's matched up with these incredibly heavy Basie ways of distortion that kind of sound like you're listening to the last dying breath of some kind of about to break synthesizer and even though it's a really ugly sound there's something very beautiful and and final about this track too especially as Tim starts swirling and rapping and surrounding all of these ugly and ethereal sounds with some really beautiful synth Keys live room out is a very touching closer to this track and then you have virginal 2 which kind of takes that piano phrase from virginal but goes in a different direction with it I like that Tim has these recurring themes on his album he can grab Mel ladies from previous tracks and reworked them in a way that sounds fresh and even though Tim is really great at layering and recycling and reusing and manipulating one of the most stunning tracks on this album is maybe one of the most bear to black refraction now after this point in the LP I actually feel like the album hits a bit of a lull not a bad way but most of the very heavy and structured compositions on this album are doled out in the first half a lot of the songs on this second part of the album are a bit shorter like the song in sense Abu Ghraib which only really feels like an introductory moment to the next track on here amps drugs and harmonium both of these songs consist of very chilling harmonium passages and I like that Tim is able to pull such coherent songs together especially on amps and drugs with what feels like just a bunch of pieces of harmonium playing maybe a sound collage of sorts my only disappointment with this track though is just how suddenly it kind of drops out and and and finishes again I feel like that's Tim sort of shooting for that typically fractured feel that he likes some of his songs to have but it's really only so appealing to me if it's getting in the way of the feel or killing the vibe of the song or just sort of the mood that has been building up the clothes are on here though stab variation is maybe the most damaged sounding and psychedelic instrumental on this entire LP taking some of the distortion from stigmata one and some of the heavy percussion what feels like percussion just rumbles kicks in the lower end of the mix from stigmata to and bringing them together with a really big epic climax for an artist whose music is constantly tagged as being ambient this finish is really explosive I really am in love with most of the tracks on this LP and even the songs the tracks that I'm not head-over-heels for by themselves I see them having a very important part being played inside of this album as as kind of a transition or just a moment where we're moving from point A to point B you're changing the mood for an album that is so short just like 47 minutes long it feels much longer this LP really is a very hefty journey and a journey that is incredibly well recorded fine tune colorful at times meticulously composed and at other moments very vast and open and no matter how busy or sparse this album is it always comes off as beautiful fantastic I'm feeling a light a decent 9 on this record transition but if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Tim Hecker virgins

minutes that it lasts some of the songs on here are the band's longest material yet 11 minute track on here 15 minute track on here but the four average sized songs that surround these two monsters for this band are pretty straightforward like the opener Vino versa where the band delivers this pretty nice mid pace guitar riff got a good groove to it banana now but this really only is a foundation on top of which the band lays some very twisted bright synthesizers some guitar chords here and there that are so distorted and brittle that they sear like the Sun and synth lines that are it's not fantastically intense or mind-blowing I do like the fact that this song progresses in a much more interesting way than other songs on here the band is always looking for another level of their track and then just a little bit earlier in the song like around the 930 mark we have some guitar intervals that don't feel all that well mixed into the song and are simply going plugging away hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a video a question comment thing talking about whether or not you should physically print your album music the auditory art for years celebrated on physical mediums through visual mediums like gold records and elaborate packaging today it is this almost invisible medium it's a digital medium it's just ones and zeroes in order to listen to it and experience it you don't need to have this physical representation in front of you artists have made the necessary changes that they needed to in order to maintain and grow their audience by putting their music and places where people are most likely to hear it and even though there is all this newness being embraced there's this progressive attitude in the music community there is an old habit that is dying very hard if it ever will die and that is printing your album as long as music collectors music nerds and incredibly passionate fans walk the planet there will always be room for CD sales record sales cassette sales since they're kind of coming back and who knows what else will come back into the future so I put together this handy flow chart so that you can decide whether or not you're going to print your album do you make music no go away yes do you have a passionate fan base willing to spend money on your merchandise no don't print anything yes you may want to print just remember that the music industry in terms of sales is not what it used to be 20 or 30 years ago depending on how you interacted with the music that you enjoyed everybody was lumped into it essentially one single sales group if you liked a few songs from the album if you liked five songs from the album if you loved the entire album you bought the entire album nowadays if you love those two songs use it by those two songs or you pirate the entire album or you could stream it and of course you're going to have fans of your music that will buy it digitally but there is going to be an even smaller subset of hardcore passionate people in your fanbase that will be willing to buy your music physically and what you need to evaluate is whether or not you have people like that in your fanbase for the music that you're creating question/comment thing is over okay alright thanks for watching that's my opinion whether or not you should print your album let me know what you think did you hate what I had to say did you love what I had to say agree disagree whatever let me know and yeah you're the best anthony Fantana printing your album [Music] you

well since about the 2007 album Bambi's dilemma mel banana has pretty much been on hiatus from releasing new studio material but now they are back with this LP fetch and on this LP as it is with their previous LPS mel banana has a pretty unique sound and style when it comes to rock music one that has won them over some pretty passionate fans some of whom are pretty big names and experimental and underground music guys like Mike Patton John Zorn The Melvins but their sound is also something that has turned a lot of people off on first listen as well the band's guitarist Ichiro prefers a tone that is so bright and is so just ah ear piercing that at times it feels like instead of a guitar no you're just hearing raw feedback or maybe even a dog whistle the bass lines are usually pretty busy driving and occasionally if they want to stick out have a crunchy tone to them the drumming which I believe on this record is sequenced programmed it's basically a drum machine that's how melt banana has recorded a lot of their records though I have known them to perform live with different drummers over the years but on this album the drum sounds are just so loud they're just so ah they sound like gunshots they're so tightly sequenced to some amazing fills on the songs here and you have a myriad of different beats on this album from dance beats to just straight-up rock beats to grindcore style beats and D beats and just a bunch of different punk beats and then there is yasuko's vocals which maybe throughout the Bands career have been the most consistent sound in their canon her voice is just so high-pitched and it doesn't help that she is shouting and shouting and shouting in this really hyped staccato way that is incredibly ear grabbing and as far as song structures Mel banana can be pretty unpredictable as well with some songs in there earlier records lasting up to 10 seconds now as the band progressed into the 2000s they drifted with some of their records away from the typically low five recordings that would cover their earlier stuff they started fleshing out their songs a little bit writing tracks that had more accessible rock grooves maybe incorporated some elements of pop some electronics its hero really got very very ambitious with the guitar effects he was toying with with records like Cell scape in 2003 Mel banana was sounding way way way more coherent than they ever have and even though they continued to make music under the tag under the genre of noise rock at that time the noise that they were bringing to the table was changing from really the sequel to cell scape it's the growth beyond the cleaner and more organized sounds they created on that record for one the guitar effects and the layering which sounded so great on cell scape are much more ambitious on this LP and stacked to a higher degree the sound play on this LP is pretty surprising it's hero comes together with some pretty interesting textures there is actually more melody brought to the table by Mel banana on this album there are intros and outros and softer moments worked into some of these songs and this album in general bringing this a little more dynamics than any other Mel banana LP and the production here is so clear and notch it perfectly complements Mel bananas incredibly busy sound me being a fan of Mel bananas ins college and also being aware of their musical trajectory over the course of their discography it's hard for me not to see fetch as melt bananas best album this help he kicks off with the track candy gun the opening of this song just starts with these colorful epic layers of guitar leads that actually sound not too unlike something I would normally hear on a Marty Stern album but what ends up arriving around the corner of this intro is something that's very different with the throbbing bass lines the very sharp fast rock drumming and yasuko's very energetic shouts that are interrupted only by these very colorful shots of guitar noise this is a formula that the band repeats with even better results on the song infection defective [Music] that little two notes slide in this track is so freakin infectious but yet it also sort of sounds like a siren to an ambulance or something like that their music seems so meticulously and melodically crafted here even though you are hearing such an overwhelming sound being brought to the table when you dive into it it's just so perfectly executed it's like wow there is not a note or a sound out of place on this song on this entire album is there and at least for me it's rare that a band comes along that that seeks to reach this level of execution perfection and yet their music stays so visceral exciting and joyous joyous despite the fact that on this track the drums are so loud that they're like bomb shells exploding that there's even a moment with some tremolo guitar picking that sounds pretty heavy metal for just a just a little spine this track Yasuko actually experiments with her vocals a little bit on the next track here one of the first tracks to drop from this album the hive it's a song that actually sees yasuko's voice with the auto-tune or some kind of auto-tune esque effect and it actually doesn't sound too bad not that it complements her voice or makes it sound amazing but it works for her in the fact that it seems at least here like a weird little distortion effect because she's not really singing in a typical or a normal way the end result of her voice in this effect is she sounds like a robot malfunctioning going berserk just about to explode and the guitar work on this track matches that with something that is just as dizzying as frantic with these guitars that are constantly sliding up in this very noisy way on the chorus and on the bridge to this track with these constantly skipping guitar notes it's like taking a sample of guitar and just repeating it on end the vocal Adventures on this record continue with the track schemes of the tales where you Sukho actually has her vocals multi-tracked on top of one another in a pretty harmonious way this combined with the pummeling drums and the really triumphant guitar melodies make schemes maybe one of the most joyous musical beatings of 2013 and the closer zero on here to features again what I think is a bit of auto-tune but the instrumental in the background is not normally what you would hear melt banana pursue there's a dance beat and a really sweet vocal melody and yasuko's vocals seem so heavily treated that it's almost like listening to a keyboard as opposed to a person's voice and it's a pretty catchy tune too but still in my opinion this song is maybe the lowest point on this album because of the really redundant and repetitive guitar layering and the really abrupt finish that this song meets at its end but still this track goes to show that despite the fact that Melba Nana is such a loud fast and in a way an abrasive band they're not a dark group their music doesn't feel tortured their music doesn't portray for me any type of suffering if their music does manage to appeal to you it's actually pretty exciting and and somewhat smile inducing I think the dreariest song on this entire album is the track my missing link where you have the guitars taking a much more minor tone and you have one tremolo pick note on top of another creating this darkly epic menagerie of guitar sounds the vocals on this track are harmonized as well but as far as their performance they feel like they're taking a bit more of a stern tone there are shorter tracks on this album as well that are just as enjoyable as some of the longer songs tracks that barely break the two-minute mark tracks like lie lied lies where you've essentially got these Punk riffs layered with noise played at light speed and then there's vertigo game which has these syncopated snare drums and guitar riffs this track actually sounds like some kind of weird cyberpunk college football fight song from the year 20 X DX I love it there are just so many moments on this album that feel familiar to melt bananas style that feel like something I would expect from Mel banana but they're doing it better than ever and then on top of that there are spots where there venturing outside of their comfort zone and seeing a lot of success as well after decades of existence and this very short studio album hiatus Mel banana has come back and and has proven that they are still frantic speed noise virtuosos and are capable of making one of the boldest rock albums of the year I'm feeling a light too decent 9:00 on this album transition but if you given the cell peal listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that said Anthony Fanta no belt banana forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd it's a great day to be alive it's a great day to be listening to music and this is a review of the new self-titled fuzz album fuzz is the collaborative duo of multi-instrumentalist and garage rock garage Punk modern garage Punk icon ty Segall as well as Charlie who Ty has actually performed with and collaborated with on numerous occasions the most recent of which I believe was actually bringing Charlie on as a guitarist in the ty Segall band which dropped a full-length LP last year except Charlie and and Ty take this LP in a slightly different direction by embracing some influences from the worlds of heavy psyche stoner rock a little bit of hard-nosed blues rock or classic rock but the downside is that a lot of the songs here feel like they could have really been swapped out and thrown on to any other ty project and they really wouldn't have thrown off the track listing or the flow the album or anything like that like the opener on here earth and gate doesn't sound too unlike many songs from the slaughterhouse album and honestly it's not that memorable of a tune either the intro is overly long when it starts getting good toward the end it just kind of fades out and the vintage riffs that are played throughout this song at a very high speed while they're not bad the very chaotic and distorted production kind of just blurs them all together and they lose some of their defining characteristics I think the only part of the song that really stuck out to me is being awesome was the blaring fiery guitar solo that pops in before the song finishes off there are other spots though on this LP that come off as memorable like the really crunchy riffs on the song sleigh ride I love the groove that ty and Charlie hit on this song it really reminds me of something that could have been on the Stooges record raw power also the blaring lead guitars toward the beginning of the track that are harmonized in a really odd way it adds a bit of a quirky characteristic to the song and the spot-on here is singing about isolation is one of the few moments here that are memorable from a lyrical standpoint these song loose sutures wasn't a bad moment on here actually reminded me of an incredibly extreme version of an old Led Zeppelin song or two especially when they hit that distorted peak around the middle point in the song and there is a huge drum solo that finishes this track off and it builds into this really explosive finish that is maybe one of the most fantastic points of this album the song what's in my head is one of the darker tracks off of this LP and really feels like ty is borrowing in a huge way from Black Sabbath especially with the huge elongated and just overly emphasized drum fills did it that it and the vocals on the verse from this track are pretty melodic as well it's a it's a welcome change of pace from some of the snotty and snide and sort of vocals that you usually hear on other Thai songs that you usually hear on other songs on this record while I'm not against the really raw and aggressive presentation that Ty's music usually delivers I feel like a lot of the time he allows that to overshadow things like finer details and grandeur and possibly more progressive ambitions typically ty bringing other musicians to the table ends up in a record that is a bit of a standout does shake things up in his discography a bit does bring some new elements or just some newer sounds to the table but maybe this time it didn't quite happen though still you know the there is that energy here there is that ferocity like I said there are some worthwhile solos and some great interplay between ty and Charlie when they focus on that but it feels like the songwriting sort of fell to the wayside on this album a bit but if you've given Fuzzle listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana fuzz forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internets busiest music nerd and this is a review of the new of Montreal album lousy with sylveon briar these guys are ignored a rock band who has had one of the longest-running careers in indie rock and pop music they are famously known for early on being members of the infamous elephant six collected they've also put out quite a few albums on the famed poly vinyl records and their earliest stuff which is my favorite stuff in their discography had musical leanings toward indie folk as well as art pop and psychedelic pop and for the most part Kevin Barnes would write tracks that were sort of cute quaint boyish playful lyrically witty but also at times kind of dramatic and troubled now eventually the band evolved to take on some really clean nice and detailed production and start to incorporate a little bit of studio trickery they kind of laid it heavier with the effects and started to use some more sense and electronics this led to some hyper colorful vocal layering that reminded me of artists such as Queen for example and albums that just generally had more pop appeal LPS like satanic panic in the Attic son'll antic twins as well as hissing fauna are you the destroyer quite possibly the band's biggest album to date however hissing fauna is is kind of a turning point for me in the band's career in that I feel like lyrically and and sonically melodically of Montreal was getting really really gaudy they're very over-the-top vocals and dense instrumentation kind of caught up with them a bit on skeletal lamping as well as false priests which is maybe my least favorite release from them because of just how chaotic it is however since this record I think Kevin Barnes and the band have been kind of slowly drifting down to earth again and putting out music that is while lavish and very emotionally distraught lyrically intense it's also maybe a bit more sensible I think that was definitely the greatest quality that paralytic stalks had going for it if it which had some fantastic arranged instrumentation around some pretty solid songs and since then of Montreal has put out a few compilations of older stuff and I feel like that has definitely set the tone for this new record of theirs which in a way goes back to the band's roots in a really big way the band has really put out a true-blue rock album again with this release with plenty of catchy sort of poppy hooks hard rocking guitars of course some guitar licks and bass lines being borrowed from that psychedelic rock and pop tradition and some full key elements too but there is sort of a new addition to the repertoire the stylistic repertoire that Kevin Burns usually brings to the table there is a bit of a folk rock and I would say all country influenced on this LP songs like fugitive air and Belle Glade missionaries have certain twang to the guitars that wasn't quite as prevalent on the band's earlier releases plus I guess it's kind of hard to call this record a true return to form because over the years as Kevin Barnes has released more records with of Montreal he has become an incredibly volatile frontman I mean at least artistically with his lyrics dealing in some real real emotional distress so while this record to a longtime of Montreal fan may feel like a bit of a trip back there are elements in the music here that do kind of keep lousy from feeling like a deja vu moment now regardless of what musical style this record sits in I do truly feel like this is one of Montreal's more solid albums as of late lyrically this album can really be read into on a pretty deep level melodically this thing is really sticky it's sweet and as far as the production goes while this album does have a raw and somewhat acoustic vibe to the sound just like old of Montreal records there is a newer cleaner punchiness to lousy that of Montreal's earlier material just didn't have because the band's production chops have been evolving for years up until this point this album kicks off with the song fugitive air maybe one of the most potent songs the band has released to date when it comes to just having a rock and roll attitude and this song opens up with a really sharp succession of chords which of Montreal is so great at putting together some very tight and complicated chord progressions that really add a lot of character to their songs and then this is no different and there's sort of a noisy and slick slide guitar playing through this track to adding kind of a backwoods bluesy country aesthetic vocally Kevin Barnes is coming off bitter and emotionally explosive the lyrics on this thing are a barrage that are a little difficult to decipher there are some songs that when Kevin is singing and I'm trying to read into the lyrics I feel like I've been thrown into a giant spider's web and I'm trying to escape but it's the other tracks on here that are a bit more readable that I feel really resonate with me even though they are just as worthy as the opener here songs like obsidian currents which is a great track about someone who is just too logical to be emotional this person that Kevin is singing about is a very cold and contemplative person who doesn't see the point in getting worked up or really emotional over much of anything and I can relate to that sometimes but I find the course especially hilarious talking to this person telling them that there's a virus in their tenets and melodically the song is so warm and sweet it can melt any cynics heart there's also the incredibly tender song sirens of your toxic spirit and if I was the person who this song was written about I would be absolutely depressed apparently this individual has no real friends everyone surrounding this person is just kind of there in some warped form of charity this person is in a struggle with addiction which he or she inherited from his or her father however Kevin Barnes sees this personal destruction having gone so far that he literally goes out of his way to say that you know what why even change why even do anything different at this point and there are some parts here where Kevin Barnes just seems like a very raw and upfront modern-day individual but it's lines like sirens of your toxic spirit that kind of make me want to liken him to a Renaissance poet there is the track Colossus which I love where lyrically Kevin Barnes is sort of describing an incredibly dysfunctional family and its tracks like this where his lyrics feel especially jumbled and wordy to the point where his singing is maybe just a smidge away from almost talking and there are tracks on here that actually go further down that road like Belle Glade missionaries as well as Hegira emigres where over some really energetic folk rock instrumentation Kevin Barnes is sort of just rambling in the same way that Bob Dylan would on a record like highway 61 revisited or bringing it all back home and these songs are just as entertaining Lee scatterbrain as those Dylan tracks too though I guess there are some spots where Belle Glade feels more like a character dissection of course there are moments here where lyrically Kevin Barnes seems to be singing about some kind of personal experience that deals in a bit of emotional trauma like on the track triumph of disintegration where he literally kicks the track off with the lyrics the last ten days have been a  but as far as the music goes on here I guess I can't really complain either like I said before of Montreal kind of goes back to their roots but does it with this slight very subtle country vibe and there are some familiar musical tropes being played out on this record some grooves that kind of feel borrowed right out of the psyche pop riff playbook but I feel like of Montreal continues to play in this realm of music but they still end up dazzling because of just the good melodies the good writing and good playing - and just some creative segues and contrasts between different points in the song like the surprise acoustic transition in the middle of the song Belle Glade some of the romantic acoustic strumming in the background on song sirens is is pretty moving the chorus on the song triumph has these really wild guitars wailing against Kevin Barnes very manic vocals on the chorus toward the end of hit gara there's a very nice psychedelic jam with this folk rock instrumentation just intensifying on this groove and getting louder and just crazier and the string kissed raindrop in my goal is easily one of the prettier tracks on here - as far as downsides and complaints these instrumentals would I be wowed by them would I be blown away by them if Kevin Barnes vocals were not in the picture and they were just completely erased and gone maybe they would feel a little kind of every day but honestly Kevin Barnes really is that electrifying of a frontman that I do enjoy the record anyway and obviously these songs have been pruned to kind of put him up front and center in the mix there is the song amphibian days which I do feel is a little underwhelming neither upbeat and catchy and exciting or so low-key and pretty that it moves me a little middle-of-the-road and sort of the double-edged sword - Kevin Barnes being so over-the-top and and lyrically verbose is that there are some tracks here like the closer that are literally so wordy that listening to Kevin Barnes sing is more like listening to him stumble because of the way his words are parsed out in such a scattered odd way that the pacing of the song is thrown off a bit I'm feeling a light too decent eight on this thing transition but if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it of Montreal lousy with sylveon Brouwer forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd and this is a review of the new Darkseid album psychic Darkseid is the musical duo of David Harrington and new york-based electronic music producer Nick Louis jar who you may be familiar with if you've been watching the reviews for a while because he has made some of my favorite electronic music of the past few years I was pretty psyched to listen to this new album even though maybe I wasn't head over heels for the EP that Darkseid dropped on Nicholas jars clown and sunset label but as a duo Darkseid under the name daft side did put out a strangely interesting and oddly creative remix album a track for track remix of the new daft punk album titling at random access memories memories and even though the remix album wasn't tracked for track amazing it said to me at least that Darkseid was evolving into something a project that wasn't afraid to take a risk and just kind of do something a little left-field and give fans something a little unexpected and maybe unexpected sums up a little of the music on this album - like I anticipated from Darkseid and just from a Nicholas jar project in general I feel like this record in a way fits squarely into that micro house wagon and of course the overall vibe an aesthetic of the sounds on this LP are very nocturnal their shadowy but I think this record takes those characteristics and just turns them in a different direction while the beats and the grooves on this album are sort of subtle and spacious there is a pretty over rock vibe that bleeds through on most of the tracks here for one the song paper trails with its percussion with its guitar lines as well as its vocals mud there was a bit of a doors influence radiating off of this track from the first moment I heard it and whether the influence is intentionally being shown off or not it's still a great track I love the bluesy guitar licks that Dave brings into the fold as the song is building Nicholas jars vocal phrasing seems very Jim Morrison inspired maybe a bit of a Scott Walker vibe in the vibrato in his singing and there's this weird based chorus effect behind his voice kind of adding this just unsettling unnerving characteristic to the vocals on this track that while they were weird the first few times I heard it I sort of have grown to love it with repeat listens I also love the subtle keyboards hanging in the background that sort of pop in against the course around the 2:30 mark this song it's a really beautiful track overall one of the most melodically interesting songs that I think Nicolas jar has been involved with so far I would say that the song heart too has a rock vibe in it with its crispy err drums as well as it's trudging and slowly descending chord progression with the guitar melodies echoing this really obvious rock influence from the 60s and from the 70s I would actually even say the melodies and the chord progressions on the closing track here are a little floyd ian still even though darkside does embrace a rock direction on this LP i would not say this album in any way is is in-your-face or incredibly upbeat it's still a slow burner it's still a record that requires a lot of patience there's really nothing that says you need an attention span for this record like an 11 minute opening track the way this opener kicks off with these really warm kind of sporadic synthesizers there's a really just ear tickling fuzzy drone hanging in the background that I like a lot and with this Rocksteady beat just kind of subtly pulsating away in the background this to me feels more like something I would just expect from Nicolas jar but this moment in the song is merely the intro after 4 minutes and 30 seconds Dave Harrington brings in these really dry prickly guitar leads that just kind of bounce and plink around the mix I love the heavy groove that this song sort of flows into toward the finish as well as the bill that's backed up with some really high pitched synths it sort of explodes and dissipates fizzles a little bit and then floats on this very textured outro it's a fantastically structured song stays engaging from beginning to end and nearly every other song on here is engaging from begin and to I think the most lackluster maybe least memorable songs on this LP are the two shorter tracks on here that kind of feel like intermissions maybe I was looking for a little bit more from the song Greek light though the song does fall just short of three minutes and it's a kind of interesting three minutes with these somewhat kitschy keyboards playing a very mournful set of chords and then these vocals are laid on top which are incredibly odd and maybe that's another thing I need to sort of make note of with this record a lot of tracks on here feature vocals and many of them are not sung in a very traditional way to go back to the song heart there's a very awkward and strange falsetto over a majority of that track and the track the only shrine I've ever seen has these falsettos and maybe some mid-range vocals doubled up on top of each other for pretty strange listening experience that that I actually liked a lot also the water Ian and very sharp rhythm guitars on this track kind of leave me feeling like Nicolas and David really did take the disco direction that Daft Punk took their new album in' to heart overall not a lot of complaints about this record a few songs on here most notably the shorter ones paled in comparison to others but still Nicolas and Dave came together on this album and made a series of tracks that are intensely hypnotic low-key and very detailed with layers of instrumentation and some pretty interesting textures too especially at the beginning of a track like freek go home which it was day which is mostly an instrumental song that is chock-full of all of these odd samples that that really could have been lifted from anywhere sort of reminds me of his live sets when he samples radio noise or radio static I am feeling a strong eight on this album transition but if you've given this dark side album a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it dark side psychic forever

hi everyone Anthony fed tato here internets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new haunted horses album watcher these guys are a rock duo hailing from Seattle they have dropped some singles an EP they've got a KEXP performance as well under their belts and now this new full-length album and basically what they deliver on the nine tracks here are a heavy heavy combination of numerous musical styles including a little bit of post-punk on the darker side of that genre industrial rock noise rock encapsulated into this very chilling cavernous atmosphere there's definitely a vibe a sonic vibe that they bring to the table that reminds me of old swans records as well as maybe a little bit of Bauhaus or Killing Joke and if we're going to put a few contemporaries into the mix maybe a band like pop 1280 like their debut record as well as Ice Age when they're incredibly slow and depressing and at their most cacophonous it is a very primal and overwhelming 25 minutes of music with heavy drumbeat after heavy drumbeat in lockstep with incredibly grimy and harsh guitar riffs occasionally what sounds like a sinister keyboard pops in and there are these very distant disembodied vocals moaning out in the background in a very eerie way delivered mostly in a deadpan style occasionally reaching up into this screamed intensity and all of these sounds combined on this record really do have a huge presentation this is a very very loud loud album from the very first guitar whale and and bellowing the record is pretty ear-shattering it kicks off with the song numinous which feels a bit like an intro to the next song go attea which has this very Spacey one-minute track following it which feels a bit like an outro it's like you've got these three songs which together really feel like one song but the middle point of these two tracks go at TIA is just the thrilling energetic blood pumping and adrenaline filled highlight these driving guitarists are just pumping and pumping and pumping with these skittering noisy just bright brittle glitches happening on every fourth bar and even though the riff is essentially kinda just a couple notes switching back and forth between one another taunted horses is throwing so much noise and so much sound this mix it's almost actually a fulfilling song the band does sort of layer things a bit more with tone on the track the moon's March with some keyboards that I like a lot even if I do wish that the vocals were a bit more up front I see the appeal in just how cavernous and distant and deadpan the vocals are on this record but they do kind of lose their appeal after a while I think I get much more of a thrill from the odd vocal samples and the vitriolic shouting on the track children of light I love the explosive shots of dissonance and and guitar distortion around the middle point of this track it's a moment where I feel like haunted horses really shifts themselves from being a rock band to just some kind of primal noise act like these are the kinds of terrible sounds that would be created if rock instrumentation had thrived in the Stone Age I love the drumbeat on this track too really busy way more detail than some of the other beats on here and I feel like in order to keep things very just the drummer does hold himself back it points to kind of play into the aesthetic of this record but still there are songs like the void where the beat is oddly danceable the closing track on here actually features a beat that feels a little tangible - and it spots like this that make me feel like maybe the drummer's a little more versatile than he would seem on the surface playing these really loud crushing noise rock songs it certainly feels that way on the song luminance which has this very scattered drumbeat with these high hats jutting out every single direction but when it comes to the guitar work on this track it's just not a moment that sticks out to me in comparison with everything else on here while I think haunted horses has a fantastic sound they are amazingly heavy I'm really being crushed by this record I just wish they would diversify their sound a little bit sometimes the second-to-last track on here was a bit of a surprise to me because the guitar chords here are actually pretty harmonious in comparison with many of the other songs here and moments like that moments that really stick out to me and feel different from every other spot on this album are sometimes what I feel like this album lacks that in length because I would love to hear these guys go add it with a few more songs in the tracklist but still this is a really enjoyable release if you're into that could coffin is industrial rock then do give this thing a listen I'm feeling a decent strong seven on the cell P transition but if you've given a listen to this thing what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that said haunted horses watcher forever
