hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for your review of the new Danny Brown album Oh Danny Brown Detroit rapper who in 2011 dropped one of the most acclaimed hip hop mixtapes of that year XXX AKA 30 a tape that i loved myself showcased Danny Brown as a rapper with a lot of personality a lot of split personality the dude raps in numerous pitches a voice some very high out there and over the top some very low and kind of subdued he's got numerous rhythmatic flows in his arsenal and emotionally he seemed like a guy who was a little all over the place to the first half of this tape kind of displaying a dude who was drinkin smokin poppin pills talking shit fifth album in the mouth the nasty conjuring images of Sarah Palin herself deep throating until she hiccup but also putting together some clever wordplay and some internal rhymes within his lines as well like every time I indent you could see my intent leave your mind bent hanging on every sentence but the latter half of this album was way more toned down way more depressing Danny Brown was a guy that not only did drugs and rapped about doing drugs but he was a lyricist that sort of brought everyone willing to listen to the entirety of xxx into this twisted downward spiral of addiction really however even though xxx really caught on for Danny and he made a name for himself on this tape it's as if that half of the message didn't really translate so much to this wider audience he seemed to have gained overnight and I'm not exactly sure why was the tape too long did people only listen to the first half did his crazier drug-addled tracks just have more replay value because as soon as XXX got big it was like the indie music media and Danny Brown embraced this image for him as this crazy Molly poppin party animal and what's interesting is that there were some men of Mali on xxx but it seems that as Dany was getting more popular Mali MDMA was sort of on the rise being mentioned in hip-hop either mainstream or underground and sort of what else was on the rise - was really zany EDM influenced rap beats so he really capitalized on it with new singles like black Brad Pitt and with it he had a pretty big track with a rap music as well of course he's collaborated and toured with ASAP Rocky who was huge into trap music himself he also appeared on a track that DJ Muggs of Cypress Hill produced that was hugely trap influenced actually his whole new record was hugely trap influenced and the appearances and the collaborations that I just mentioned are a very small slice of the pie Danny spent majority of the time between these two records working making connections building this clout in the hip-hop community that he never had before he was on the new tech 9 album new Flatbush zombies mixtape he was also performing at the gathering of the Juggalos which surprisingly within the indie community he received no backlash for not only was Danny building himself up to be this really off-the-wall personality but he was just everywhere as awesome as it was to sort of see Danny's career taking off because I was such a huge fan of xxx part of me was kind of worried that he would abandon his more introspective side in favor of really embarking on making these party tracks as much as he possibly could because they seemed to be gaining more buzz for him than those more introspective tracks off of his record thankfully that's not actually the case on old because there are plenty of songs here where Danny explores the darker side of his past and his psyche however on this record I can't help but feel like the multiple sides of his personality his emotions and his addictions are just at odds and I'm seeing less connections between sort of the dark somber Danny Brown and this wild just let's party as hard as we possibly can Danny Brown and I feel like these separations are increasing because of the lyrical content between these two sides the cadences that he uses of course the beats that he usually hops on when he's going in a particular direction just like on his last record Danny does his best to keep one emotion on one side of the record and the other emotion on the other side of the record but he flips it putting the more introspective tracks at the beginning and maybe that's sort of in an effort to get people to listen to that side of him a little closer and it definitely pulls me in because I think lyrically Danny is a lot more descriptive when he's going down this road than he was on xxx like on the opening track he rolled which essentially is Danny kind of talking about going back to that old self of his getting his braids back going back to wrapping up drugs dealing constantly tripping and even though this is not really a new tail and hip-hop music there's just this incredibly grimy urgent vibe to this track especially with the really thick Basie and noisy instrumental going on behind Danny and he just has a voice that cuts through all of it this instrumental and a lot of others on here have a really psychedelic edge whether they're going for more of a boom-bap flavor maybe something kind of toned down or something really trap influenced following the opening track is the return with Freddie Gibbs again another track on here that I love has really kind of funky dark nocturnal vibe to the instrumental and it kind of continues with that theme of Danny Brown going back to his old gangsta self going as far as to say fuck a hipster squeeze a trigger but then you have songs later in the track listing on this side like lonely where Danny Brown is saying that he's a hipster at heart but he can tell you how the streets feel hopping on the track with a flow that you might remember from xxx talking about how he enjoys some of Radiohead's music and even though the instrumental here is just very pretty it's sparkling it feels like a dream some of Danny's lyrics just feel nightmarish he's stacking for abortion he's trying to get creative with spam because it seems like that's all he has to eat and there's a moment here where he feels the need to address some societal racism - and the next track here clean up is a song that as well the instrumental feels heavenly it feels pretty but Danny's lyrics man they're heavy sort of him acknowledging his addictions with pills with smoking really with everything and how it's affecting his relations with his family with his daughter spots like this really make me think that man maybe Danny is sort of on the cusp of a major change in his life where he's going to be giving this stuff up but part of me also thinks how could that possibly happen Danny's kind of been playing the field for the past few years as this underground party icon a rapper whose personality and in lyricism and success is is heavily indebted to drugs drug culture and later on this LP Danny drops the track dope song which opens up the second half it's a track where it seems like Danny Brown is kind of lashing out at his past and getting tired of other rappers kind of telling this 10 year old story about something that they did it seems like he'd rather keep things fresh keep things new keep things forward-thinking and essentially says here on this song that this is his last dope song again there are spots on here where it feels like Danny goes deeper into his introspective side than he ever has before but on the second half of this LP it feels like Danny goes further into his party animal side than he ever has before - you have tracks on here like smoking and drinking one of the catchy ER songs on this LP really infectious chorus really loud over-the-top instrumental of course a hybrid of EDM and trap here - Danny kind of talking about his vices coming down to his depression and wanting to get away from that in the second verse of this track there's also the song dip on here two equally influenced by EDM and trap he really does kind of put himself at the forefront of malli culture in hip-hop takes shots at other rappers that sort of embrace it or mention it to gain attention and I think that's why Danny goes so deep lyrically into the malli experience with this track because he feels like he can kind of give that more detail than anybody else can and then on top of that lyrically with getting into his zone I feel like we get a bit of a watch the throne reference here and I would go so far as to say maybe a little freak nasty influence with the dip then a beaut if we did it seems like Danny is is literally with the instrumentals and with the lyrical content on the second half of this tract trying to put himself in that party atmosphere as much as possible to kind of alleviate a lot of the torture and a lot of the that occurs on the first half of this LP now these EDM trap hybrids that I just mentioned I like them I enjoy them and in a way I was expecting tracks like this to pop up on this album considering that that's how so many of Danny's biggest singles between the release of xxx and old were going but I think after a while on the second half of this LP instrumentally and lyrically things get a little one-dimensional they get kind of redundant it really does feel like Danny isn't trying to put as much effort into his lyrics and that his cadence is so over the top on a lot of these tracks that it's hard to really read into them unless you're going on rap genius or something like that it seems like this desire to just be as crazy as you possibly can over these Diplo inspired beats is just kind of the goal here just create a party atmosphere and that's it that's essentially what he's serving up on tracks like break it and handstand which are kind of like twerk anthems and after he releases these two tracks the album doesn't really redeem itself either delivering the song way up here with AB soul where I feel like both him and Danny put together some pretty unmemorable verses and then there's Kush coma which even though ASAP Rocky has been added to the track since its original release I'm still not really crazy about the song instrumentally the track to me feels just jumbled the hook is kind of gaudy and again we just have a lot of lyricism that isn't hitting me as hard as some of Danny's grittier stuff from the first half of this LP the grittier stuff from xxx as well as just the over-the-top nasty in-your-face stuff from xxx as well that was just laugh out loud hilarious and there are some other spots on here too where I feel like Danny is trying to reconcile his old self with his new self and he really gets some mixed results like on the track 25 bucks which lyrically and and hook wise as well I think is a great track but he's all over this kind of trashy electronic which house influenced instrumental with purity ring on the hook just is not doing too much for me it really feels out of place sonically with the rest of the album especially the first two tracks that preceded then there is the song Wonder Bread which really I only wish was longer I like the odd flute led instrumental it really kind of feels like a twisted fairy tale or nursery rhyme or something like that with Danny talking about going down to the store to get bread and being confronted with the violence in his neighborhood and the drug fiends there as well then there's the track dubstep where it feels like there is a bit of dubstep influence in the keyboards and Danny embraces a bit of grime on this track as well which if you've been following his career between xxx and old he has been kind of over there in the UK networking with some artists in that genre - and I think lyrically with the guests that he brought on here's the song turns out really well just not too crazy about the instrumental and the very sugar-coated hook then there is float on toward the back end of this album with Charli XCX whose contributions are very subtle which is great and I think she complements the track well it's not a bad closer however it's not exactly the thrilling cliffhanger that thirty was at the back end of xxx though it's still a really introspective track I feel like Danny's very subdued vocals are almost buried in the beat a little bit too much and instead of me kind of sitting on the edge of my seat wondering where Danny is going to go next he ends up feeling a little beaten down by the process and just sort of the grind of driving himself crazy and wanting to make his next album better than his previous one truth be told the dynamic of this album even though Danny is on different instrumentals than he was before isn't too different from xxx were just seeing the same addiction the same problems and the same drugs and the same over-the-top attitude framed within a different part of Danny's career he still is hopeful that he will see his influence sort of play out in hip-hop music when he is 50 years old and considering how much personality Danny has whether I enjoy this album or not that may in fact happen now there were moments on here where I did enjoy the trap and EDM influences coming through and I felt like they were executed really tastefully in a way that still sort of maintained mean that edge that you expect from Danny tracks like dope-fiend rental or dope song and given these more shallow party tracks toward the back end of this album they still sound unique nobody is doing tracks like this quite like Danny is however it's still hard for me personally to not get sick of them at least a little bit as I'm listening to this album from beginning to end I'm feeling a decent too strong 7 on this thing transition but if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantan Oh Danny Brown old forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new one o tricks point never album r+ 7 1 o tricks point never is the pseudonym of electronic music composer Daniel o Patton whose productions usually sit on the experimental side of things embracing elements of ambient music of progressive synth music of drone of a little bit of noise a lot of the time the music he makes kind of sits somewhere between being somewhat epic and grand and also very Spacey or numbing he's also collaborated with quite a few artists and put out some side projects as well one of which and is kind of credited with starting this whole vaporwave thing the project that I failed to mention in my review of OneNote explained ever is last full-length LP replica but now that replica has been mentioned I have to say that that is my favorite album to come out of this project thus far mostly because I think that record takes such a strange unique and obtuse approach to producing sample-based music it's just like listening to these very somewhat ambient but odd and weirdly shaped plunder phonics compositions I'm finding are plus seven to be a continuation of this trend in Daniels music to produce stuff that is a bit more engaging is more eventful is more detailed however stylistically I find him drifting away from the samples upon samples upon samples that made replicas such a sonic treasure trove I have no clue what happened to my mouth right there instead of relying heavily on samples Daniel kind of rests on his laurels and goes back to using synthesizers really heavily which sound like they're produced via MIDI sequencing kind of a calling card for Daniel at this point I guess what I'm trying to say is that Daniels music feels like it's entirely generated inside of some computer program to the point where it just does not feel human anymore however still our plus seven is is kind of change for Daniel because I do think he puts in a lot more effort into finding some synth textures on on this record that yes while they do feel like they are composed in this very rigid way sonically it's it's very lush plus I would say that Daniels songs are pretty structured on this album as well not meandering so much not really kind of spacing out so much even when he seems to build up to a moment he kind of takes it away really quickly and goes down a completely different Road compositionally I feel like Daniel jumps all over the place but sonically a lot of what he pulls together is is very pretty it's very heavenly actually when it comes to synth textures on this record anyway I would say that Daniels number one influence is like cheesy kitschy new-age music from the 80s and 90s but he does it with a slightly experimental angle with kind of a progressive angle to the point where maybe we're listening to like post New Age here take the obviously synth generated chorus vocals what sounds like a children's chorus on the track chrome County which has these very relaxing sweet instrumental swells but then as the song progresses Daniel grabs these synth generated chorus vocals and stretches them out samples them and just slows them down to the point where you're getting these digital noisy just hissy stretch marks Daniels music can be kind of seductive but it can also be very otherworldly and and kind of like you're in the midst of this odd weird cuckoo-land where nothing makes sense like how he finishes this track up with this really epic grand organ solo that sounds amazing really moving but then as soon as it comes up it's like he just kind of fades the track out and cuts it down and just lets the album close which is sort of how the first track on here ends as well which is another track that I like we have the song Americans on here which I feel like borrows from this cheesy sense of relaxation by incorporating these just very commercial sounding synthesizers that are also simultaneously dated and like these jungle sounds there are these fake synth horns all over the track too but then sort of thrown into this mix that I would normally cringe at are these very tightly composed like progressive synthesizer arpeggios that make the track feel really primal it's an interesting juxtaposition of ideas but then around the 1 minute and 30 second mark of this track this music just starts to melt away into these somewhat jittery sounds that are kind of unpredictable and popping up and snapping at me really quickly the track eventually turns to its original sound and then kind of cuts things off and I don't know I feel like I'm left wanting more at the end of this song and a lot of other songs here too but then again a lot of what Daniel is doing on this album and maybe this is kind of an issue I had with replicas as well a lot of what's here is so unorthodox whose really to say how long or how short it should be all I know is that there are some tracks on here that I feel are maybe just completely uninteresting because of how short they are songs like he-she or cryo which to me don't even ever really get started into something that I would want to return to they don't even really fade into the following tracks all that well so I it's hard for me to sort of see what they do for this album I find tracks on here like zebra the the six-minute highlight off this record so much more interesting with it's really jittery synthetic opening with all these skipping tones it's really quickly skipping all I know is the tracks like this seemed to me like this really odd little gadget or toy that I don't know what its purpose is but I could just stare at it and just kind of like move it click it this way and then this weird thing pops out and it's just puzzling and maybe this entire album itself could be sort of perceived in that light too but I guess that doesn't stop me from thinking that some of this album's tracks or functions are less exciting than others I'm a little all over the place with this album in terms of what songs I like what songs I don't and I seem to dislike some like others for completely different reasons because of how different these songs feel and tone in vibe and sound and I like that daniel has come together with a record that so many of the songs here come from totally different worlds and yet they all feel like they're a part of our +7 nothing on this album sticks out to me as like whoa this doesn't belong here or this just doesn't stick with the whole theme or this doesn't really I guess I just don't find the tracks the content within the theme and the aura in the world that he creates on this record to be entertaining from beginning to end much of the time they are which is why I guess I'm feeling a light too decent hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a quick little review of the new Mazzy Star album seasons of your day these guys are a West Coast rock band I would consider listening to them if you think of yourself as a big fan of Dream pop and they're maybe considering how many reverb Laden and and buzzy guitar-driven pop rock bands there are out there these what Mazzy stars music was now this is Mazzy stars first album in 17 years and in the meantime between these album releases key members hopes and of all and David robach we're working on other musical projects however I would hardly call their time away from putting out Mazzy Star Records prolific now a lot like the last My Bloody Valentine record some of you may already know that I dug that album this Mazzy Star album consists of material that was recorded between this huge hiatus so it should be no surprise that on this record Mazzy Star sounds exactly like how you remember them the instrumentation on these songs has tons of space they're played at a slow pace the melodies are shy the percussion is sparse hope Sandoval's vocals still sound as fantastic as they ever have they still have their main characteristics in that they feel a little aged dusty a lot of people would say smoky but simultaneously they are very light breezy and and youthful very young the guitars of course are slow-paced as well splashed with reverb the acoustic guitars yes but especially the electric guitars both of which have a slight country twang to them too sonically Mazzy Star has not changed a bit and it's kind of weird because I can't help but think of this band as well because they just came out with their first album in 17 years to the UK melodic death metal band carcass both albums that I really feel like returning to at the end of the day honestly there are tracks on this new album of Mazzy stars like spoon and flying low that that to me are showing just how little direction the songwriting on this album can have at points to me these tracks just meander they don't really stay engaging from beginning to end and it's not like Mazzy Star hasn't written tracks that are this long before and there are other tracks on here that though they may be shorter they feel similarly stagnant in in how the songs progress like California or does someone have your baby now hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Bill Callahan album dream river bill Callahan is a singer-songwriter who underwent a pretty interesting musical evolution throughout the 80's 90's and 2000's under the singing songwriting pseudonym smog it was singer-songwriter music but with kind of a strange experimental edge in the later years of smog in the late 90s and 2000's things kind of smoothed out mellowed out a little bit really bill callahan was singing in a completely different way the songs the melody is the instrumentation it was all a bit more melancholy and it seemed like bill was embracing some sounds coming from the worlds of all country and Americana a little bit more maybe getting into some classic Neil Young albums stuff like that an influence that definitely shows up on this new LP as well Smaug dropped its last studio album in 2005 with Bill Callahan kind of switching to releasing music under his government name after that and since then bill has been releasing some very enjoyable albums like the LP the sophomore LP under his name sometimes I wish I were in Eagle album that featured a lot of very slow-moving folk instrumentation with Bill's very low soothing voice gracing it and emotionally bill comes off sometimes very urgent or sad but for the most part very very relaxing lyrically telling a lot of esoteric tales that to understand them you really have to be paying close attention and dive into them a little bit these were good things these were interesting moves but maybe there was such a thing as too much of a good thing when Bill Callahan came out with his next full-length LP apocalypse maybe it was a little too slow-moving to me maybe it was a little too uneventful to me maybe the stories were just a little too obscure for me to latch on to now bill Callahans new LP dream river walks down or really floats down that same gentle tranquil stream with more direct lyrics and more engaging instrumental performances I would actually say that in comparison with Apocalypse and maybe even sometimes I the instrumentation here relatively is kind of lively I feel like the album actually kicks off on a really engaging note with some really rustic electric and acoustic guitars stacked up with some beautiful fiddle embellishments and some shuffling drums all of which are beautifully played recorded and mixed there are even moments on this track and on this album in general where the instrumentation just kind of moves in this really live-in-the-moment way where it's all kind of digging into the groove really hard together toward the instrumental break in the middle of this opening track this actually happens and it really picks up the track for me and lyrically bill seems to be singing about this very relaxed moment of solitary drunkenness where he is singing about just kind of blankly staring at the carpet and chairs at this hotel bar people who are coming into the bar and hanging around unknowingly are sort of spending time with him keeping him company just by being in the same vicinity bill even goes further to say that the only two things he said that day were beer and thank you it's a kind of funny self-aware and maybe slightly self-deprecating track and bill vocally just sort of tumbles through this song and many on here with this very warbly baritone on the surface Bill's singing especially on this album with all of the you know sort of very obvious Americana instrumentation feels very mundane and kind of dusty but I feel like as I listen to this album more and more and and maybe as you do too if you give this thing a listen there's something also very warm and welcoming and inviting and just so sweet beautiful and and relaxing about the singing that bill continues to bring to the table and at least for me that is the sentiment that prevails on Dream River especially on the track small plane where again we have an instrumental and we have a story and we have a vocal that is incredibly soothing we have these very gentle interjections of electric guitar playing over these slow-moving guitar arpeggios and percussion lyrically bill kind of puts himself into the cockpit of a plane and talks about learning about flying early on in the track with someone teaching him and I'm not really sure what the relationship with this person is but to me at least it feels like there's a lot of love there maybe not a romantic love it's it's just the kind of love that feels like it's been there for a very long time or at least some kind of appreciation or some kind of long lasting relationship or a Queen's ship to the point where it doesn't need to be blatantly mentioned or talked about it just feels like it's there really this track focuses on on the journey in an odd way being in this plane learning to fly this plane going home in this plane lifting off landing having control losing control other people having control of you it's it's an interesting set of ideas thrown together in the lyrics here things that really make me just get a little emotional and kind of reflect a bit the issue with this song maybe a few others on here is that it feels like they end a little abruptly and and maybe that's because bill doesn't really write clear concise endings to some of these tracks because a lot of them wander a bit they meander a bit they kind of go where they pleased when they please and just kind of follow the narrative of bill's lyrics and while that's not necessarily a terrible thing it leads to these songs being either very linear or having slightly adventurous song structures it does leave me wanting more from some of these tracks because it feels like they've ventured out so far why and them here meanwhile there are other tracks on here that instrumentally aren't bad like ride my arrow and seagull but are maybe not as structurally built up and are just like kind of repetitive a bit and while again I feel like lyrically and in vocally Bill Callahan does step up to the plate and deliver something interesting I guess I wish the instrumentation was a little more engaging throughout maybe these moments remind me of some of the more underwhelming moments from Bill's last album but they're few and far between bill actually brings some instrumental diversity to this album and some heat I think with some really nice solos especially on the track javelin on landing the instrumental diversity carries on with the tracks spring which has some watery guitar effects on the rhythm guitar they're playing this riff that feels a little old-school little classic rock influenced and lyrically bill is kind of diving into this narrative into this poetry into this story about the changing of the seasons kind of being in the midst of this transition period between seasons in spring when it looks like just hell has frozen over and the skies are gray and everything is just dead and it's funny because on Bill's last LP he seemed to be so infatuated and so impressed with the beauty of nature and so many natural things and now he's saying everything is iying and tired of praise mountains don't need my accolades but maybe the most chilling track on this entire LP is summer painter something I think features some of bills most interesting introspective and and wonderful lyrics yet singing about how he would paint boats paint words on boats kind of comparing himself to a beaver that builds dams like something that just does this work mindlessly suddenly it just does this work because there's nothing else to do but also using these beavers as a metaphor to kind of block himself into this work like he's not changing his life he's not going anywhere he's not trying to do anything other than just this kind of work and as bill is singing a lot of these lyrics he's reaching into his upper register which he doesn't do too often and is sounding really nice and and very passionate and convincing doing so and then it seems that a hurricane rips through this area and even though there is more work than ever to do he kind of turns around and just abandons this life saying that I guess my rainy day came now again I love that bill reached up in that upper register of his voice I mean yeah it's it's it's not that high comparatively with with other singers but this shows up again on the final track on this LP - which is a really passionate closure it feels like a really warm goodbye even though there is imagery of winter in the air of coldness in here it's difficult to put into words but there's just a real sense of finish to the warmth and beauty of the melody on this track especially with the ascending harmonized car leads that sounds so pretty especially as bill is reaching up into that upper register of his overall the this is a really solid album for Bill I do enjoy it more than his last one and lyrically instrumentally I really got sucked into it all over this album there's just wonderfully played dry instrumentation really intimate setting and aesthetic really intricate interplay the poetic lyrics on the cell P the tender sweet emotions I know that as someone who reviews music and people who are huge fans of music it's really important to kind of stay current stay on top of trends stay in to what's hot what's creative what's fresh what's new but also every once in a while it's it's great to kind of stop smell the flowers and listen to something that is written and recorded really well and is grounded in in in in in a long-standing tradition because there's just something that is so human about what Bill is doing on this record you could feel the blood pumping through these songs my only real issues is that I find hi everyone Anthony Pham tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Flatbush zombies album better off dead Flatbush zombies are a new york hip hop trio consisting of Michi Darko zombie juice and Eric Ark Elliott I first heard of these guys not too long ago when they put out a mixtape titled drugs and honestly the tape didn't really stop me in my tracks enough to sort of make me want to review it so I figured I would kind of sit down and give a hard listen to this new project of theirs especially since they seem to be gaining more momentum behind this new one some of their biggest tracks so far have come off of this mixtape palm-trees Mraz and 222 plus the trio has been continuing to develop their sound and have been stretching out into different modern hip hop styles now a lot of you may be conscious of this new underground hip hop movement going on in New York right now beast coast you've got acts associated with this thing like pro era underachievers and of course Flatbush zombies and thus far Flatbush has kind of been the underdog in this movement I feel however at least artistically I think Flatbush zombies kind of come out ahead with this new project better off dead delivers a series of songs that are some of the boldest grimy as' in-your-face hip-hop that you're going to hear out of New York this year and even though this project stands pretty long at 19 tracks I think it's at least somewhat diverse diverse enough to want to listen to the entire thing on most fronts this project impresses 4:1 the production Eric Ark Elliott is a very sharp producer sharper than I've actually heard him on even his solo stuff with the opening track on here I love the way the heavy rock guitars the crushing drum fill the operatic vocal cut and the pluck strings come together and you know we have four sounds here that that seemingly come from different worlds but they come together to make a really ear grabbing intro you've got tracks on here like death and Nephilim and God bless the dead that all have kind of an atmospheric Spacey and somewhat psychedelic vibe something I think fans of the utter achievers would enjoy and there are other tracks on here that go that direction as well like palm trees and 222 but those songs are much more serene by comparison with their instrumentals especially palm trees which has these beautiful cooing vocals that are sampled and played throughout the track you've got boom bap cuts on here like club soda which is this really classy instrumental with these soaring vocals and a nice bounce to the groove the instrumental and regular and complex goes for this vibe as well also mindfuck which has a pretty nice sample coming from the Luis Enriquez back a lot of track prelude do which is a sample I had to look up listening to this mixtape because I remember hearing a sample of that song as well on a nonfiction track which is pretty awesome because I'm sure there's got to be a connection there because I read the zombie juice was influenced by ill bill there's the track Thugnificent on here which has this slow druggie auto-tune chorus it's not a terrible track I feel like the vocals were kind of annoying and we're sitting too well with me at first but as I trip through the tape more and more and more it kind of grew on me a little bit then there's the song live from Hell which is one of the few tracks on here that's produced by another person Harry fraud and the beat on this thing is absolutely killer like a trap nightmare really eerie synths and psychedelic trippy acid soaked guitar solos throughout this thing the only instrumental and chorus on here that I think is even more nightmarish is the song drug parade which maybe is one of the few moments where I think Flatbush zombies are so eccentric and so in-your-face that it gets a little obnoxious bolli the instrumentals on this album are a lot of things they're aggressive they're grimy they could be smooth and sweet and kind of chilled out and druggie they could be chilling an eerie and psychotic and unnerving as well but above all even when Flatbush zombies do something instrumentally that feels like it's a bit of a trip backwards they do a great job of keeping with the New York hardcore hip-hop tradition of being reckless witty gritty and Quaeda rebellious now as far as flow and lyrics go on this album Eric zombie juice and Meech all rap on this LP and they've all got kind of their own vocal style as well so it's not like you're hearing one MC after another and you really can't tell who is who in fact I think a few these guys actually have voices that were just made for rap like the genre was invented decades ago jest so that in the future we could hear a guy like me Chi Darko on the mic the dude has this gruff low baritone which sometimes he's not so rough with it sometimes he reaches into a mid-range which feels really smooth really natural but most of the time when you hear this guy's voice it's gonna be zany and remind you of a ton of different people just kind of mashed up together into this bloody pile of MC corpses there are moments when I hear his voice and I think a little bit of ol Dirty Bastard or maybe a member - of Onyx or Busta Rhymes and oddly enough I came from the Ying Yang Twins there are quite a few tracks on here that actually remind me of sort of that crunk era of southern hip-hop like the chorus on the track bliss which I mean Michy's vocals on that really sound to me like Kane's vocals whenever he would write a chorus and of course the flow on the track palm trees kind of reminds me of a slowed down version of the flow on the chorus get low and there are moments on here where the inflections and the flows of Meech and zombie juice kind of remind me of early horrorcore acts like grave diggers for example now zombie juice like I said before definitely an ill Bill influence that I read about but from the first moment I heard this guy's voice I was like man it really kind of sounds like he listens to a little bit of eazy-e now as far as vocal register zombie has a really great separation from each in the mix because his voice comes off so high so hyped so energetic to me comes off just as ear grabbing just maybe not as cartoony and as far as Eric he's a kind of middle-ground vocally not so low not so high and just a little bit of rasp now if there's a downside to the vocals and the cadences on this album and and this is essentially what kind of Drew me away from Flatbush zombies at first dating back to their drugs mixtape their vocals are so over the top there so just crazy a lot of the time they can kind of drown out their flow talents their lyrical talents and abilities and and the bright spots in the production to now as far as lyrics go these guys are again staying with that hardcore hip-hop tradition of being braggadocious a lot of wordplay of course insults are thrown into the mix grimy gritty while I wouldn't say their rhymes are smart or incredibly socially conscious to the point where you're like whoa these guys are really thinking about the world but I wouldn't really say they're dumb lyrically either there are plenty of moments on here where zombie juice or Meech approach issues of racial inequality and hypocrisy I mean that's really the entire theme of the opening track on here American Pie one of Michy's lines on this track sticks out to me about him having money now him having bread and people coming to him with their hands out and all simultaneously whenever a line comes through as being kind of silly it's like his voice his delivery is cartoony enough to the point where it's kind of funny I think that comes through on the fuck fuck fuck fuck verse that he does on the track bliss on another verse where he's talking about being too mentally unstable to be fucking with them labels imagine him kind of yakety-yak and around these round tables and past these lines I think there are plenty of highlights throughout this project I think flat Barzani's even though there are some duds here and there they place great songs on this song is fantastic cleverly referenced and entertaining verse gt-r's has this really smooth soulful chorus despite the fact that it's Meech singing on the song with his really rough voice and on the track regular and complex with meat rapping about rap being illegal and then him writing bars and being behind bars and ba-ba-ba-ba-ba continuing that rhyme scheme that was just another moment where i feel like he's kind of clever but very charismatic and just fun to listen to as far as features on here there is the song club soda which has action bronson on the final verse he really heard him do to the point where I can't even make out a lot of what he's saying I feel like he was up against these other rappers on this tape who also have incredibly eccentric voices and this track has this really awesome beat change up with the synth line from Easy's boys in the hood coming through and then it goes back to the original instrumental again solid memorable and enjoyable moments occur throughout this thing originally I feel like there were some adjustments my ears needed to make or just my head needed to make to the voices and just how over-the-top they are on this album but yeah poke poke link link banana hi everyone Anthony Pham tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new machine drum album vapor City machine drum is the longtime pseudonym of electronic music producer Travis Stewart he has been making music under this name for well over 10 years at this point and over the years that he's put out music in this project he has sort of used it as a testing ground for numerous electronic music styles he's a very versatile producer with a sharp ear for sound I first talked about his work back in 2011 with the album rooms an album on which he brought a real stylistic shift embracing the worlds of Juke footwork future garage all in one go and while there were some standout tracks on this thing that I like tool I didn't enjoy kind of the vibe and the aesthetic that he was going for on this album maybe he embraced the very maximal tendencies of these genres a little bit too much because there were a number of songs on here that to me came off way too jumbled to even sort of be enjoyable or make sense of and now on this new LP machine drum is still hanging in that same stylistic realm but maybe the songs are actually coming together a little more focus actually a lot like that sepal cure album that he dropped that very same year simple cure being the collaborative duo of him and Praveen Sharma however I can't really say I was that much crazier about sepal cure than I was machine drum because with sepal here I felt like those eccentric tendencies that machine drum had those more experimental those noisier tendencies that machine drum had were kind of just sucked away to the point where the future garage the juke that was embraced on this album was just kind of very pastel colored not that memorable a little bit of a wallpaper background version of this style of music I thought this new LP from machine drum though vapor City seems to be a little bit of a middle ground however not quite as jumbled as rooms but maybe a little darker a little grittier a little bit more personality than sepal cure and what I also appreciate about this LP is that machine drum definitely brought a nice variety among the 10 tracks on this album there are more serene songs on here just prettier atmospheric songs and then we have some very hard grooving bangers as well like two of the lead singles off of this LP gunshot ah a track that has a really interesting intricate and constantly shifting rhythm some very warm sub bass and some tight vocal edits and then there's eyes don't lie which is me my favorite track on this entire LP the groove even harder but kind of has a sway to it that to me makes the track feel really unique the bass is crushing in the the kind of pitch shifted and and manipulated and somewhat ghostly vocal sample is incredibly hypnotic as don't as there are a few tracks on here that kind of come out of left field like vision which is this somewhat short very textured very grainy drone of a track but maybe what's even more surprising to me is the track you still lie which actually feels like a bit of electronic psychedelic dream pop something I would expect more from an artist's like washed-out actually the song features all these rippling handclaps and and swelling synth chords as well as these lead vocals that that are very somewhat deadpan not that emotive but cavernous with reverb what I think Machinedrum actually fell short of on this is that the track honestly is not that memorable which in my opinion is sort of the issue with a lot of music that tries to go for this vibe I was just sort of hoping that Machinedrum would change things up by actually making something that hit a little harder had a bit more impacted memorability I feel like he attempts that with this really sharp synth lead but to me this song sticks out like a sore thumb in the flow of this album just because it feels so stylistically out there and because it's it's just not as much of a highlight as many of the other songs on here are for me and there are other highlights on here outside of the two lead singles that are a little lower in energy but still have some pretty creative ideas a song baby it's you bill with this really slow-burning introduction it really kind of gets the tension set and it has kind of a future garage groove to it especially with the vocal edits but I found some of the sounds surrounding this vocal edit to be kind of glitchy which I dug a lot there is a song infinite us the longest track on this album a song that has these really nice arpeggios sparkling throughout the track these constantly ascending chords a very fast beat in these vocal edits that feel like they're treated with auto-tune a little bit warbling in the background it's a bit of an odd track I feel like the fast pace of the song catches my ear but maybe it's a little long-winded and then there Center your love which has some pretty nice female vocal edits as well as some rich pianos and some guitars too overall it's it's not a bad mix of tracks from Machinedrum maybe not that cohesive of an album and and I will say that maybe track 4 track 4 track it's not as hard hitting his rooms because a lot of the time and I feel like this is what made room so exciting for some people is the album feels like a little bit of a barrage machine drum came through with a lot more clarity on this album and I think it makes it more enjoyable more listenable just more approachable there are a few tracks on here that feel forgettable but I think I prefer this LP over his last one I'm feeling a life 7 on this thing transition but if you've given this Machinedrum album a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Machinedrum vapor City only the strong Subscribe forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd creepeth and it's time for a review of the new Keo album huh Bardot ko dot is an experimental rock outfit that is masterminded by versatile singer composer and multi-instrumentalist tobe driver I first got into his music through his modeling of the well when I was sort of on the lookout for some modern prog rock that didn't suck modern progressive rock with an edge keeps the rock in progressive rock as well as a little bit of doom metal and death metal they actually came out with an album a few years ago in 2009 after a very long long long hiatus it was an album whose budget was actually collected through fan donations but since this maudlin record came out Toby drivers taken his musical efforts and focused them back on Keio dot which is essentially the band he pulled together after madlyn went south in the early 2000s and you could actually argue that the move from maudlin to KO dot was actually great for Toby's career the very first album that ko ever put out actually came out on sadiq records which is John Zorn's record label which if you're an experimental rock outfit and you're looking for some kind of endorsement in the experimental rock world that will get your career going and get people paying attention to you that is it now over the years Kyodai has embraced a series of different stylistic influences as well as personnel and despite that their music has always stayed relatively consistent until in my opinion about 2010 with the album coyote which i think is one of the more austere and just kind of up to sand difficult albums to come out of this project difficult to the point where that there was just not much in the way of enjoy ability and then I think things got even less entertaining with the next full-length Keo album Gamma Knife which is the most low fire recording the band has ever delivered to their audience part of me sort of assumed that KO dot was down for the count at this point it's been about 10 years since their first full-length album and you know not many bands make it to that point and still sound great but then all of a sudden ko dot Toby driver comes out of nowhere with this new album within a year's time and it's like 100 minutes long not only that but the recording on this thing is incredibly sharp done by Randall Dunn it didn't take long for me to realize that what I was listening to on this album was more ambitious more fully realized louder bigger and just more grandiose than than anything that Kyodai has been doing for it's two previous albums maybe even three of course the stylistic inspirations on this album are nothing new for Toby driver but maybe it's a little jarring for some fans to hear them all packed in so tightly into this one 100 minute LP you have art rock on here prog rock avant-garde metal heavy metal black metal death metal jazz fusion post rock maybe a little bit of sludge metal some chamber music too as well as just some beautiful chorus vocals it's a very diverse album but somehow Toby gets it to flow pretty well even though I think he really kind of left some of what happens on this LP up to chance maybe just really up to pure improvisation that much is clear from the opening track on this album the song is called the black stone it features Jason Byron who Toby has worked with before doing guttural vocals on this track and and basically this track involves a lot of just strung out guitars who are playing phrases and playing noises that feel almost random at points they are accented with drums a little bit of strings and even though there may be some chords and some melodies that that seem to be agreed upon between all these musicians it feels like all of them are just kind of reacting to one another in the moment to make this very intense and and tightly knit performance and typically I'm into this sort of thing but the sporadic rushes of guitars and drums on on this track didn't exactly stay entertaining for the six or so minutes that they last before the song goes into this chilling frenzy of blasts beat drums and really intense vocals and just these ascending guitars and sentences and I didn't really find Byron's gutturals to be that fantastic either maybe kind of limited in in dynamics and abilities I think there were moments on the beginning of this track where his voice sounded maybe a little cartoonish and just not that chilling thankfully the next track on this thing crown in the muck is a little more consistent a little more coherent there's some ominous horn harmonies on this track some great guitar lines time signatures switch up a little bit I love the slow heavy and passionate explosive guitars toward the finish of this song and the doubled-up shouted vocals it was almost kind of a punk vibe to this track coming from the vocals that I really liked the screams were just manic as hell song thief right after seems to be kind of a continuation of this same sort of rock intensity except there are some incredibly psychedelic reverb effects being thrown all over the vocals and a lot of the instrumentation making everything bleed into one another there's some very fast and intense playing all over this track and then Toby driver and company sort of make this switch from black metal influenced intensity to the soaring clean vocals a la Mike Patton however this element of surprise we're doing this now we've changed gears this does lead to some of the tracks on here feeling kind of gimmicky gaudy kind of like the song vision adjustment to another wavelength which goes straight from in the middle of the track cacophonous death metal inspired instrumentation to kind of quirky tongue-in-cheek flute jazz and you know it just feels to me to be a shame to waste such good playing in such good musicianship I'm kind of a semi ironic thrill I like mr. bungle as much as the next guy but this track isn't really doing that for me fortunately this sort of thing is is sort of a rarity on Hobart Oh a lot of the song structures on this album do take twists and do take turns but they are coherent and they flow pretty well like the passion coming from the instrumentation on this song if you only listen to one song from this album make it this song so the storyline in this album is is is insane to say the least I think my only major issue with it though is that it doesn't really feel like soundtrack why's that the vibe of a lot of these songs don't really fit at least what I perceive to be the vibe coming from what's actually being told in the lyrics if the lyrics are actually even audible because there are a number of tracks here where the lyrics are just literally screamed or shouted or they're delivered with death metal vocals or they're buried under a ton of instrumentation there's only a handful of tracks on this pretty long album where Toby drivers vocals are actually very clean intelligible to the point where you can make out everything you say but case in point the song floodgate this song is easily the most noisy cacophonous heavy and just a chaotic song on this entire album with just instrumentation playing fast and as noisily as possible just pile on top of each other and there's nothing really about the story at this point in the song that in my opinion would warrant this kind of intensity this kind of ferocity I mean merely what happens in the story at this point is that the poet comes across the river that was created by the forest and the seed that he planted the night before I mean I get that the song is titled floodgate and maybe that the flood the waters are open they're rushing so the instrumentation is rushing and it's loud as possible but still I mean I feel like there are different ways to go about that vibe than to create something that's so scary that's so evil and that's so wretched because literally that's how this song sounds so even though I like the arc of the storyline and I like the instrumental arc of the music on this album I feel like there are a handful of points where they don't really lock in together all that well another example would be the closing track on this album the song passing the river which is the tenth track on here instrumentally I think is about as good a closing track as you're going to get and yet there's another chapter to this story and instead of maybe bringing in a song that maybe has a bit of a sense of closure to it we get this kind of quirky jazz fusion instrumental that has these long winded solos that lasts until the song is is 14 minutes long overall I gotta say I was impressed with this record I enjoyed this record quite a bit I'm happy to see ko doc come through with a project that once again feels ambitious recorded well intense and just at some points a thrill to listen to however I thought that the concept that this album came through with was executed really only in an O a way it's like this album was trying to deliver this really grand story line but instead kind of threw dirt on top of it by bringing together instrumentals that sort of buried that storyline whether it be with some loud guitars or just some obscure or very vocals but other than that I think kayo dot pulled together a really solid LP I'm feeling a decent too strong seven on this thing transition if hi everyone Anthony Santana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new MGM's no no time look at me like this car when you finish you shouldn't look like this okay um could I have some no I hate Cal Church esta MGMT self-titled album these guys re indie electronic indie pop duo or they were at one time within the span of a few years they went from that to just complete psychedelic pop and rock it was a pretty surprising transition from their first album oracular spectacular to their sophomore LP congratulations even though there were elements of psychedelic rock and pop on their debut the fact of the matter is is that congratulations was a much more ambitious grandiose and kind of out there record not quite as sweet with the pop appeal and it ended up disappointing a lot of the fans that they collected off of the backs of great singles like electric feel and kids and time to pretend I defended that change they made in my videos not only because I love it when bands get ambitious and try to reach for the stars but I thought congratulations was a good record and MGMT must have found the process of making a record kind of on their own terms rewarding because it seems that they are doing it once again with this new LP that I'm sure will earn them even more backlash from whatever fans they have left before even a single song was released from this self-titled album MGMT was saying that our next record it's gonna be weirder so watch out and the forecast started to look like just that after they got Dave Freeman Fredman back to produce the record who produced their first album also produce music with Mercury Rev Flaming Lips Plus MGMT dropped a few tracks before this album came out like alien days and your life is a lie and even though songs were more off-kilter than what they had put on congratulations now like I said earlier this record MGMT does have a little bit of a tie to the Flaming Lips and I would say that shows up influence wise on on some of the songs especially with Flaming Lips more recent stuff the very fuzzy ominous and effects soaked track mystery disease feels a lot like something The Flaming Lips might have put on their embryonic record and the song a good sadness which is a very vast track it's a very spacious atmospheric track this I think would have slipped in pretty nicely to the new Flaming Lips record had that LP been maybe a little lighter in mood a little more cheerful cheerful light-hearted those are definitely two words I would use to describe this album as a whole with the exception of a couple of little tracks many of the songs here feel pretty absurd maybe a little silly and intentionally so the sound the MGMT are going for on on pretty much every track here is just really cacophonous noisy lots of conflicting signals going on between the instrumentation this album production-wise is compressed as hell everything in the mix here is just so pressed and so squeezed in and so claustrophobic it's it's kind of like a casserole even the quietest tracks on here have a bit of digital fuzz on them from all the compression thrown onto these tracks and you know a lot of people have pointed at this record because of that have said oh loudness war brick walled however I don't really think MGMT compressed the songs on this record for the same reasons that a mainstream pop star looking for radio play may have their record heavily compressed I think the reason that this album sounds so crackling is that they legitimately tried to experiment a little bit and come together with a uniform sound and just kind of make a record that has again this this very Bhoomi very overwhelming quality to it however there's really only so far that I feel like I could defend this production choice because it does really kill the dynamic range of the instrumentation especially on the quieter tracks and it does kind of grate on my ears and wear on me as I am listening to this album all the way through it does get a little suffocating I think the space in the breathing room is really kind of necessary when you're talking about enjoying a tracks such as astro-man C which is such a spacious odd an experimental track I can't really tell why I'm not enjoying this track is it because MGMT sound play is legitimately not that interesting or is it because the way this kind of emphasizes experimentation and just strangeness over putting together a sweet punchy and melodic psych pop tune and to be completely honest I sort of find tracks like this to be a little bit of an unrewarding jumble in kind of the same way that some tracks on the last animal collective were a little shaky for me and I didn't really connect with any of them emotionally because a lot of hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet stuffiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new crystal stilts album nature new are crystal stilts are a New York rock band who I've been a pretty big fan of ever since about two thousand eight when I first heard their album a light of night which in my opinion was a pretty good spacey trippy odd and and somewhat off-putting psychedelic and garage rock album I think the band hit a bit of a creative peak in 2011 with the album in love with oblivion which was one of my favorite rock albums of that year still is it's done shake the shackles I described this album in my review as a pure rock and roll nightmare lots of reverb on these guitars very onymous ominous melodies and tons of energy and just momentum coming from the tightness of the band playing together and of course the very deadpan low-pitched and disembodied vocals a front man Jamie Townsend kind of was the cherry on top of this whole thing the sonic variety was much bigger than it was on their last LP I think this was just a fantastic album for crystal stilts they ended up following this album up with with a somewhat lackluster EP pretty soon after and now they have dished out a new full-length album which while maybe I didn't find it as disappointing as the EP that they followed in love with oblivion up with I'm not really warming up to this thing to the point where I love it head over heels on this album the band goes into a decidedly less energetic psychedelic and experimental direction I would say but to what end I'm not really sure a lot of the instrumentation on this thing is is much more audible not so smothered in effects but the only thing getting rid of the effects has exposed is is the band's incredibly simple approach to song and melody writing and and performing it hasn't really added any kind of newfound depth or this aha moment where I'm like oh crystal stilts doesn't sound too bad without the effects as much as I like many of the songs from crystal stilts previous records I'm not so sure how game I would be to hear any of them acoustic or with all the effects stripped back for me the effects the reverb you know just the studio trickery was a part of the fun on tracks like electrons rising and spirit in front of me crystal stilts are sounding like a slightly slower and less detailed less layered version of their former selves one of the few tracks that sounded actually good with some of the effects trip back was the song future folklore which had this really swagger filled guitar riff some schmaltzy organs on this thing as well as this floor tom bass drum beat this song just romps it bounces around it just has that smooth just danceable again swagger that I think crystal stilts should bring to the table if they're gonna strip some of these eerie sounds back there was just a really captivating energy to this track it kind of felt like a slightly creepy take on a guitar riff for just a song idea from Velvet Underground's white light/white Heat what I think the band really tried to do on this record is is make an album that is not so odd or off-putting her eerie or scary or nightmarish but maybe put forth an album that's a lot prettier because there are a good handful of tracks on here that feature some strings some layered arranged strings like the song star crawl or the track memory room which is also an acoustic ballad and the song phases forever to which also has woodwinds in it that sound nice the song sticks and stones is definitely one of the more light and airy songs that crystal stilts have ever put together with kind of a jangly sweet little rhythm guitar and JB Townsend kind of singing in his higher register which does sound odd but but in a way there is kind of a sweetness and innocence to it and even the title track on this LP feature some very soft rock instrumentation with this really eerie melody that kind of creeps in really delicately and and this kind of delicate approach isn't really something you usually hear on a crystal stilts album I i think the direction that crystal stilts are shooting for sounds really great on paper and I think it sounds really great instrumentally most of the time however I think there are moments on this album where some of the loose playing some of the loose and slow playing that the band delivers like on Star crawl and JB's vocals on pretty much every track don't really lend themselves to the beauty that I think they're trying to grab for and sometimes even though the melodies that they do employ on this album can be kind of pretty they're not enough they're they're they're really too simple and too short to kind of carry the weight of an entire track that feels really repetitive and kind of mundane sort of like world gone wrong overall I did like this LP I feel like crystal stilts have still kept their aesthetic while trying to change and sort of do something new for the band at least half of the songs on this thing I find to be really enjoyable and I have faith that into the future maybe they'll find a way to take some of these beautiful melodies and more delicate sounds and incorporate them with their strange and odd effects or go that roar out go that softer route but maybe bring a little bit detail into the process so that the song stay engaging from beginning to end I am feeling a light six on this album transition but what did you think of this album did you love it did you hate it why and what do you think I should review next Anthony Fantana crystal stilts nature noir forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new weekend album kiss land the weekend is the somewhat experimental emotionally tortured and kind of dark and moody R&B project of Canadian singer-songwriter Abel Tesfaye personally I have a bit of a rocky history with this project despite Abel's pretty decent falsetto as well as some rave reviews I firmly believe that his big breakout project house of balloons that dropped in 2011 was one of the most unrewarding musical lessons I had that year the really thin production on this album ruined it for me as well as the even thinner lyrical topics which all kind of seemed like this desperate attempt to make excessive partying drug use and sex kind of introspective meaningful and deep we have the character that Abel puts himself in in these weekend songs indulging in just about everything as much as he possibly can all the while kind of painting himself is someone who is troubled sensitive and incredibly self-aware of the danger that I guess he's putting himself in impressively Abel dropped two more free projects within a year's time Thursday and echoes of silence and it was kind of weird because as people were cooling down on the project and I can understand why that was because Thursday was definitely not as entertaining or as grand or as ambitious as house of balloons for a lot of people but but I felt like I was warming up to what the weekend was doing especially when echoes of silence drop the production improved in a big way got way heavier more lush more vivid the songwriting felt a lot more straightforward and to the point a lot less moments where Abel was kind of just wandering over these repetitive beats with his vocals and to me on echoes of silence his voice sounded way more raw natural and just human and I think on that project as well the dark vibe that Abel had been going for this entire time really sort of hit home for me it actually felt real this is the first project I'd heard from the weekend that to me was kind of chilling I understand that dropping these projects within a year's time might have been a little bit of over saturation but I still don't see why that goes up silence doesn't get as much props as house of balloons now last year all of these projects got repackaged and were commercially sold as a trilogy which did kind of build the buzz up for this project again all of the previous projects to drop from the weekend did get cleaned up a little bit sonically and in my opinion even though I didn't really love house of balloons once this remaster came through I did like the sound a lot more so having heard these better sounds on this trilogy enjoying echoes of silence I was legitimately looking forward to whatever the weekend was gonna do next but then the single the lead single the title track for this album dropped in in my heart just sank the instrumental on this track was just glistening not as much darkness or edge in my opinion as some of the previous beats to drop from the weekend though I still think the atmosphere on this track was huge the bass and the drums were slow heavy kind of crushing but I think the most disappointing thing about it were Able's vocals his his singing and his lyrics on this song really the entire track felt like a rehash of everything he had been doing for the past three weekend projects not only that but it felt like Abel was backing away from writing those more straightforward songs and was getting back into that habit of just merely finding a beat finding a groove just repeating it over and over and then aimlessly singing your story over it in a really badly paced way unfortunately this really redundant songwriting style is exactly what Abel serves up for every single track on kiss land the production is still large is still atmospheric in a way kind of cinematic but what always ends up disappointing like I said earlier it's the pacing take the song adaptation for example it's just four minutes and 44 seconds but it feels like it goes on forever it's just got this really large slow lumbering beat that just repeats repeats and repeats and there's not much changing up on this song there's not much progression or alteration outside the story that Abel is trying to tell in his lyrics and if you dive into the lyrics like adapted to the models who adapted to the bottle they take it down like water just to burn away their sorrows it's clear that Abel is not changing his lyrical game up on this LP after listening to this album I'm absolutely convinced that the weekend is not as lyrical as some people make him out to be his stories are not as detail there is fleshed out or as meaningful as people believe they are and in my opinion taking these themes and in trying to make them really sad trying to make them really emotional to me just feels like throwing lipstick on a pig and those lyrics I just mentioned are from from a chorus where you have all these vocals stacked on top of one another something I think was placed into the track to kind of break up the monotony of the instrumental and Abel's voice but whenever that attempt is made it usually kind of comes out sounding ridiculous or just not that interesting the chorus on the song professional 2 is incredibly underwhelming and almost pointless and a non chorus I think the most notable change in pace on this entire album came on the song live for where I never looked more forward to a Drake verse in my entire life though the song wanderlust has kind of changed gears for the album it's it's this weird synth funk track with this upbeat funky groove that feels kind of Rick James inspired but still even this track doesn't develop that far past the funky groove it establishes at the beginning and once again were delivered another monotonous song just this time it's got kind of a catchy groove but I think maybe part of the issue with the weekend not only his songwriting style which does get kind of repetitive but the instrumentals on this track - which just don't show that much variation and a lot of the very very cloudy and Atmospheric sense surrounding these tracks kind of take away the body of the songs and probably give them less character in the long run because toward the end of this album Pharrell Williams actually has a remix of this song and it is way more enjoyable mostly because these scents are Way punchier and the instrumental itself is is just a lot more colorful a little fruitier if you want to say that and you know what the thing is even though the instrumentation feels a little more upbeat I feel like that inherent sadness and just that melancholy the weekend brings to the table it's it's still there overall I feel like able kind of went easy on us with this album by not delivering any stories that that felt fresh or new or bold for the weekend for not bringing any instrumentals to the table that had any true character outside of their overuse of reverb and their really really slow pace there are even moments where I feel like Abel's vocals are a little bit more subtle dainty and just kind of understated than his vocals in the past even the last track on this album there are some effects on his vocals that kind of obscure his voice and make it difficult to even make out what he's saying and if the weekend has been consistent with anything up to this point it has been having intelligible lyrics while I think the weekend still has some potential to come through with something interesting in the future and and still has a defined sound in the R&B world when you hear a weekend song you know it's weekend song but overall this project just feels like a rehash of a lot of moments from the weekends previous stuff but done in a slightly less interesting way while this record wasn't terrible to me it wasn't you know the worst thing in the world there were some good points but the good points that I heard here I've already really heard from from this project I'm feeling a light five on this thing honestly transition but if you've given this weekend album a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana weekend kiss land forever
