hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Denzel Currie album nostalgia 64 Denzel curry is a young southern rapper from South Florida who has ties to the Rader clan which is this southern hip hop outfit affiliated with MC Space Ghost purp and him together with the Rader clan are largely responsible for this resurgence of dark atmospheric Memphis inspired hip-hop classic artists like three 6 mafia Juicy J coupes - whose music comes out in a big way in the music of little ugly man Space Ghost purp Halik maul and Denzel - and denzel's take on this very dark bleak Memphis rap style combines elements of cloud wraps and very atmospheric effects at times in his music as well as modern and hard-hitting trap rap some chopped and screwed stuff - and there's a little bit of early horrorcore eeriness kind of lurching and some of the songs here - the soldier is not denzel's first project but he seems to be gaining more attention than ever off of this and while at first I didn't really see the appeal of this thing the more I listened to it the more that I saw that there was a lot of potential in what Denzel is doing at its most surface level if you're not really digging deep into this album Denzel essentially sounds like another young rapper whose voice is not really that distinct he just kind of sounds like an aggressive young dude his instrumentals are very trap inspired some of the hooks on this thing are really grimy an in-your-face and loud kind of like as if they were Waka Flocka Flame inspired however I think what's going on on this LP runs a lot deeper than that for one this is a pretty dark record and the instrumentals are incredibly crushing with the bass like the song dark and violent whose instrumental is very very spacious and chilling and even the song Zone 3 one of the more hard-hitting tracks on this LP even has a bit of darkness there in the instrumental coming from the sort of repetitive sense and Denzel is pretty consistent throughout this LP until the very very end with this very morbid and tortured vibe now though I did like the beats on this album a lot they really fit with denzel's aggressive style when he's trying to go hard they fit with his ear your style when he's trying to tell a bit more of a story just get really dark get kind of in your head with with something kind of sickening they really fit the bill but where I really ended up being the most impressed with this LP was with denzel's flow and his lyrics I don't get me wrong there are moments on this LP kind of like the song widescreen where Denzel sort of sounds like just any young rapper who has a pretty decent flow but there are moments on this album where it really feels like he has something sort of significant to say like on the track Zone 3 which essentially is a bit of a grim painting of where he comes from in South Florida and being someone from that area there are some Trayvon Martin references in this track as well as other moments on this project but what feels even more cutting is the next song on here parents where essentially Denzel is dealing with a few people who he's describing in some verses who are sort of the result of crappy parenting we have a girl who's stripping and getting naked and letting guys basically take advantage of her physically just to pay the bills we have another person who essentially over spends money all the time doesn't know what to do with his life still lives with his mother and on the song dark and violent we kind of had this character who sees no other options in front of him other than committing crime to kind of get ahead and make a way for himself in the world and there's a beat change up a significant beat change up in the second half of the song where essentially we're introduced to the character in the first half of this track and then we're sort of let into this first-person view story of him pulling off a bank heist and another thing that kind of hit me on this album is sort of denzel's willingness to sort of mix these dark aggressive themes with with things that for him are kind of either fun or nostalgic I mean obviously in the title we have a reference to Nintendo 64 we have rob banks on one track sort of name checking Charmander on the song mystical virus we have the main character of this track screaming out in pain in fear like he's Sindel the character from the Mortal Kombat video game series and even on zone 3 Denzel paints this picture of a drive-by not killing somebody who was meant to kill and then the guys involved in the drive-by getting out and cutting his hands off leaving him with nubs like the Powerpuff Girls you have some more hard-hitting tracks on here like threats and and talk that maybe the most dumb angry just in your face tracks on this entire LP but still very catchy really energetic and just kind of wrapped me up and just how mad they are really where this album gets kind of shaky for me is the second cache we have a bit of a love song on here with like me where denzel lyrically it's it's not bad I feel like his flow is a little less smooth than it is at times and he sings a little bit toward the end of the track which doesn't turn out too well in his favor it's a little confusing to me considering that he already has a good singer guesting on this track who performs really well on the hook but this isn't even really the worst moment on the album for me still here I think Denzel maintains his personality I think its tracks like bends where in my opinion because of his flow the lyrical content on this track which is honestly a little shallow and his his voice as well which i think is still kind of yet to come into its own he sounds like just any young rapper who's just swagging and kind of rapping about drugs and material things and the song denny cascade this track would be purely generic and forgettable too if it weren't for the really epic and dark beat change up in the second half and the clothes are on here a bit of cloud wrap with some awful awful singing and some lyrics that really just kind of breezed by me it was just a very uneventful closer still toward the end of the cell P I admire denzel's attempts at kind of breaking up the vibe of this album trying to deliver something a little different toward the end but I feel like as the album changes up its style and just it's emotional feel denzel drifts away from what his strong points are I feel like he could either consistently deliver these dark tracks which I think he does very well or find a way to be a little more captivating or unique on these more lighthearted and maybe just less serious songs still not a bad project and and something that I feel is going to keep me in to with whatever this dude is doing next I'm feeling a light to decent 7:00 transition but if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantan Oh Denzel Curie forever

Lana Del Rey sleighbells Charli XCX part of me thought that yeah maybe people are hung up on the fact that Miley Cyrus used to be this innocent tween pop star Disney affiliated but the thing is there are plenty of P in the public eye now who were doing raunchy stuff given their innocent Disney past Christina Aguilera Britney Spears Justin Timberlake Selena Gomez was in that Spring Breakers movie hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for your review of the new Janelle Monae album The Electric Lady Janelle Monae is an R&B and art pop singer-songwriter who turned heads in a big way back in 2010 with her album the ark Android easily one of the most ambitious and conceptual records in R&B music to come out in a very long time and the thing about this album is that it's a sequel the second and third suite in an ongoing series that Janelle Monae is kind of penning as she puts out more albums and this narrative that Janelle Monae is penning it has Afrocentric themes futuristic themes science fiction themes and even though Janelle Monae comes through really heavy with concept I think she delivers music as well that is just as grand as her conceptual ambitions the arc Android proved Janelle Monae was an incredibly versatile artist delivering tracks that were influenced by jazz baroque pop funk soul hip-hop now even though the third suite on this album was a little disjointed it's still an incredibly impressive LP and while the storyline the the narrative that Janelle Monae pulls together on her records isn't necessarily like a/b c/d one point to another point to what she does instead is just creates this entirely different world in her mind gives you glimpses of it through her music and through her lyrics and then plays inside of this playground she's created to expel some great songs about love free expression oppression people living in harmony gender equality racial struggle and I would say these themes come through in a really strong way on this new LP as well in fact The Electric Lady adds two more suites to the ongoing metropolis series and puts another empty circle at the end of all of it implying that there is more to come and honestly I have no problem whatsoever with implying that as long as Janelle monáe's music stays this funky stays this thematic stays this interesting lyrically and stays really well arranged instrumentally the most apparent thing to me on this record what really hit me as I was tripping through it and this could be a good or a bad thing are Janelle monáe's influence is for one prince who she also counts as a collaborator on this LP also the Jackson 5 Marvin Gaye Stevie Wonder Destiny's Child Solange is actually on this LP as well as Erykah Badu who's on this album as well we will get more to the influences later but another thing that hit me about this record is just how accessible it is at some points even though Janelle Monae seems to be like in her own little galaxy there's no denying the huge amount of popularity growth that has occurred from her first album to the arc Android to this new LP and I feel like her wanting to bend to those wins a little bit is displayed big time in this LPS two primary singles dance apocalyptic and queen but still even when trying to appeal in a really big way I feel like Janelle Monae puts effort into her lyrics giving them a little extra subversiveness that you could read into the song Queen has this raunchy raunchy groove and Funkadelics style keyboards playing throughout the track and lyrically it's it's really a song about being kind of the boldest person you can be and not worrying about who that offends or worries or makes uncomfortable the groove is okay it's a little corny but the end of the track is is actually fantastic really gets lifted up with these wonderful strength sections and Janelle Monae bust this rap verse with a flow that she returns to at a few other points on this album which she feels like she needs to say something poignant but the verse that she ends this track off with one of the most politically charged moments I've ever heard in a piece of her music it's a really inspirational gripping and kind of beautiful declaration of self and even catchy or dance apocalyptic to me has a bit of a retro vibe coming from the instrumentation like an old-school rhythm and blues pop kind of thing going and lyrically it seems to kind of delve into being driven crazy and being boxed in by just the limitations of the modern world the food tastes like crap you have allergies from the animals that you have as house pets your bathing and bathing and bathing but nothing really gets the funk off it's really the most bubblegum I've ever heard Janelle Monae get especially with kind of the Juicy J reference right at the beginning of the track but to me instrumentally and MA - this song has a bit of a corny quality to it just like Queen does in comparison with previous singles like cold war or especially tightrope these two lead singles definitely don't have the same amount of class or wonder or charisma but to me those two tracks which is the poppy or highlights off this album as far as the other tracks go on here Janelle Monae again kind of gets back to the grand smooth funky and pristine tracks that made the arc Android so good the song electric lady the title track off of the selfie has a hard groove bright bright since in the background and just has this smooth funky feels the instrumentation that I love Solange Knowles sounds great on the track and there's just something about the instrumentation especially some of the background vocals - after the chorus that really reminds me of like some late 90s early 2000s mainstream R&B type stuff and the thing is the R&B influences don't stop here on this album of course it's never been any secret that you're now Moana is influenced by R&B music she makes R&B music but it's almost as if nearly every track here kind of tributes a different flavor or a different era of R&B song prime time with Miguel one of my favorite tracks on here a beautiful ballad really to me kind of feels like it's it's a tip of the hat to the slow jam the song it's code which is an all right track it's a track that to me feels a little generic and style and melody and and maybe that's because it feels like a carbon copy of a Jackson 5 track there's the song get a woman which is this really jumpy hyper upbeat ballad with a really strong lyrical message and it feels kind of like something Stevie Wonder would have made back in the day it's not a bad track I feel like Janelle Monae tries to progress this sound forward by throwing a lot of effects on her vocals on some of the instrumentation - but it just ends up feeling kind of muddy and unrewarding and there are a few other tracks on her which feel like these smooth soul ballads with a really reflective personal theme going on in lyrics tracks like victory really good tune on here as well as Dorothy Dandridge eyes and the song what an experience feels like just this pure soulful 80s R&B with some electronic drums and some really strong listening synthesizers and as the song moves along it's got a little bit of a pop reggae thing going on on the back end with some upstroke guitars and as cheesy as some of that stuff was it's actually a really good song beautiful tune nice mix on the instrumentation it has a nice pristine sound to it and just refrain to this track to finish the album ah feel so fitting really what an experience The Electric Lady was overall I had a lot of positive things to say about this record the production the songs the instrumentation janelle monae singing of course which is always fantastic the interludes where you kind of have this really eccentric radio DJ talking about this robot culture that this music is set in are not only sort of eye-opening but hilarious but where the shortcomings come through on this record is in Janelle monáe's influences more than on the ark Android and on her debut EP she kind of does this dance of death with a lot of them trying to get as close as possible to them without completely drowning out her own style her own essence sometimes that works like on victory and in other moments like I said with its code it kind of just sounds like a regular old Jackson 5 track and then on top of that there are moments of fast paced pop Souls such as rock and roll and the song look into my eyes which is a sweet little piece of baroque pop that both sound like songs that could have been on Janelle monáe's last album however even though I can draw a lot of comparisons between the arc Android and The Electric Lady it's a different album at least different enough for me with its interludes and guest appearances its songs its production aesthetic it's slightly more political lyrics and the fact that all together these songs kind of feel like an all-around tribute to the world of R&B music from its inception up to the current day I'm feeling a strong 7 to a light 8 on this thing transition but if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it janelle monae the arc Android Anthony Fantana forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new self-titled factory floor album factory floor is a musical trio hailing from the UK this is their second full-length album depending on whether or not what they previously released actually qualifies as an album either way I've really been looking forward to this album merely because I loved one of the singles that drop previous to this thing I love this band's sonic aesthetic essentially factory floor makes old school dance music really rigid rudimentary electronic dance music with influences coming from old school house some acid house - and it's likely strip a lot of these sounds back to be as simple and as minimal as possible reappropriation a lot of old-school drum machine sounds and synth textures in the process and undeniably these guys pulled together some really hard edged grooves do they have momentum down to a science on this LP and a lot of their other tracks - these are beats that you just have to kind of move to however I would not say the factory floor songs are all that melodic or traditionally structured like a song with a verse chorus so on and so forth but what does that really matter there are plenty of great dance songs that aren't however it's like factory floor really wants to bring this point home like this is not poppy dance music don't you understand we're trying to keep this thing as noisy and is weird as we possibly can almost to the point where it feels like there's a really strong industrial music vibe coming off of the music that factory floor makes or a post-punk vibe and neither are that surprising considering one of the members of this trio collaborated with two members of throbbing gristle last year on a strange little industrial music & Noise album called transverse got it right here check it out it might lift your skirt on this new LP factory floor works to make these very accessible dance grooves weird by slathering them with very monotone drab moaning dead Panvel goals vocals that are so intentionally drab they kind of kill the fun mood that the dance beats bring this was a key feature of factory floors last release as well and doing this on their tracks can kind of be a little bit of a double-edged sword there are moments where factory floor with these very odd vocals and these hard edge dance beats come through with a piece of dance music that is authentically weird and kind of refreshing because of that weirdness however there are spots on this album as well where I'm not really sure what to do should I dance or should I just stand here stone-faced and be kind of weirded out as far as highlights off of this LP go there is the song fall back a track that I heard earlier this year that I mentioned in the beginning of this video that I absolutely love I love the unpredictable synth notes on this thing the really crisp crispy drums as well as the kind of pulsating bass line and Nick voids disconnected vocals feel oddly sexy this song to me is just a weird combination of being entrancing and hypnotic but also kind of wild and edgy as well as emotionally numbing and off-putting there are other songs on here too that I feel like hit that perfect balance tracks like how you say or work out which is a track that is well deserving of its title and has this synth riff that really reminds me of early Daft Punk now even though there are moments on the selkie like how you say where it feels like nick void is trying to be a little more lyrical with her vocals it is the fact that she is always singing with the deadest of deadpans that kind of makes this album feel slightly one-dimensional I guess the vocal style does make this album get a little old a little fast I mean yeah it is kind of something that factory floor specializes in and it's something that I could signify as being a factory floor thing I would know a factory floor song if I heard it because of these vocals but I wouldn't necessarily say that Nick void singing makes the songs enjoyable plus on top of it many of the tracks on this album are very similar in concept and I guess you could say that a lot of the sounds that this album puts forward won't be too unfamiliar to you as well if you are into many ADFA records release so unfortunately even though I really dug the song fall back and a few other songs on here overall this album didn't end up feeling as refreshing to me or as radical to me as I had hoped I feel like many of these tracks standing alone would work really well in a DJ set for a kind of off-kilter dance party but as far as a listening experience to almost a full hour of music on this thing while I liked many of the tracks on here I did kind of feel like I was stuck in dance music limbo like I was just in one place for way longer than I actually wanted to be overall I got to say I feel a decent 6 on this LP transition but if you've given this factory floor album a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana only the strong subscribe all mistakes are intentional factory floor self-titled forever

Anthony Fantino here the internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Holy Ghost album dynamics Holy Ghost is in New York synth pop duo that is incredibly influenced by disco electro disco but a new wave as well and this is their sophomore full-length LP I've been highly anticipating it especially since their debut album that came out in 2011 on DFA records was when I favorite albums of that year for me the band's debut is just a little slice of dance music bliss memorable choruses really sharp melodies hard just fun grooves and on top of it some of the tracks had an interesting lyrical angle to them whether it be some kind of funny personal perception like the track do it again which was a bit of a critique on dance music scenes and there's the track Jam for Jerry which was sort of in tribute to a friend of theirs who had recently passed of course James Murphy was meddling in the production on that album and it led to just an immaculately sharp and modern dance music sound for the band and he returns for this sophomore album as well making sure that the instrumentation sounds vivid and just punchy as well as so colorful I would say the only weak thing that holy ghosts whole ensemble is the vocals the thing about their debut is that the songs were just too good to deny and while I wasn't exactly expecting some kind of night and day difference between the vocals on the band's debut and the vocals on the sophomore record of theirs at least I was hoping for an album where again the songs were just too good to deny and admittedly I did get some solid tracks on this record I got some very good tracks on this record and the production is is actually still phenomenal I would actually say it's a little more detailed and layered than it was on the band's debut there are loads of different textures on this thing whether they be buzzing bouncing bass lines they're sharp sporadic bleeps and bloops really atmospheric beautiful icy chai very airy elongated notes that kind of hang in the background wonderfully as well but the vocals again they're there a little bit for the most part on these songs they're just kind of passable not really reaching too far up or down and pitch or coming off that passionate or fiery either and this can especially be an issue when you have a track that has a very repetitive verse melody where you're not really getting a lot of just mmm I still find the lyrics to be pretty interesting self-aware the song okay kind of details this story that for me feels like dealing with a bit of relationship trouble and the song dum disco ideas literally seems to be some kind of jumbled mess of phrases and ideas having to do with the band running on a really tight schedule playing on a set playing on a stage needing water going to this place going to that place and the song I want to be your hand is maybe one of the strangest love songs I've heard in a while sonically it sort of sounds like a piece of adult contemporary soft rock from the 80s the band plays it off well with some really great production and a really catchy chorus though and some sort of silly lyrics that I hope are tongue-in-cheek if anything the song actually reminds me of something aerial pink would do in the middle and maybe my favorite track on here has got to be it must be the weather dude this is one of those tracks that makes me feel like not only this holy ghost play this retro vintage style of pop music of synthesizer pop music but they make music in this genre that sounds as awesome to me as the older stuff as the classic stuff not only do the vocals on the verses on this track feel a lot more passionate to me but the layers of this song ah the way it kicks off wow the lead vocals those little background vocals that sort of chime in when you're nearing the chorus it must be the way and as the song progresses you get these stretches of time where you're just getting these little beat interludes awesome fills it's it's such a wonderful track it just it makes me feel like I'm listening to just the magic of Toto and just slowed down and smooth that and sexified and and speaking of influence there are some moments on this LP where I feel like I'm hearing guitar parts drum beats or bass lines that sound identical to guitar parts drum beats and bass lines from the three fantastic LCD Soundsystem albums ah hi everyone Anthony fan tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Chelsea wolf album pain is beauty Chelsea wolf a mistake California singer-songwriter multi-instrumentalist and darkened songstress of the seventh circle and she initially caught my ear back in 2011 with this album overhear apocalypse and that album is really difficult to put in a nutshell because Chelsea wolf does not really stay in one spot sonically on this LP really the only common threads throughout that album are her very beautiful voice which is slathered and reverb off in the distance but has some incredible range and passion to it and the generally dark depressive and just shadowy a cult vibe that her music brings to the table there were elements of rock music on their experimental music some folk music as well sludge metal a bit of noise black metal especially with the retching vocals at the start of this thing and while their influences may be a little obvious artists like PJ Harvey some Sonic Youth a little bit of Radiohead as well some swans too she in my opinion brings them very successfully into her world and just blends them into her darkness so that they don't really feel like she's pulling directly from them any given time you're just not deafened by the reminder that she sounds like a B C and D and as far as the production aesthetic that she goes for while I don't really care for reverb to be overused much of the time and Chelsea does lay it on in a way where her songs do feel cavernous I feel like her melodies her vocals and just her very sharp and kind of at times noisy instrumentation really cut through this reverb and and connect with me in a very intimate way even though it all feels kind of like it's hanging out in this very black pitch black and because she's a little unpredictable because she really kind of stretches out on her albums I was excited to hear where she would go next would she come through with a more uniform sound or would she kind of try to reach out more and essentially Chelsea's answer to this was reach out more coming through with songs that have some electronics in them actually track track track tracks like the warden one of the songs to drop before the release of this album which is essentially some really gothic moody synthesizer pop the throbbing electronics and what sounds kind of like a sample the cousteau guitar on this track are very pretty I didn't really care for Chelsea's vocals on this song because they didn't really feel as intense as I expect her vocals to be but I did really like the creepy and kind of subtle sad melancholy tune that this track had to offer [Music] and the song destruction makes the world burn brighter while I do like the very just sour and kind of dark guitar interludes happening in between the verses as soon as the song hits it kind of feels like Chelsea is embracing a little bit of Beach rock or garage rock kind of in that bleached best coast Vivian girls Frankie rose sort of vain again a track that I'm not all too crazy about the vocals especially the vocal melody which to me is just way too sleepy just not that memorable really one of the reasons I don't care for a lot of artists who shoot for this sound a couple tracks on the first half of this thing are bust sure however there are a lot of highlights to the song Farrell love that kicks this album off more throbbing electronics just like the warden but way more intense and heavy especially toward the back end of the song where Chelsea is layering on just piles and piles of arranged instrumentation and just really chilling sounds I feel like that acoustic album she came out with before the release of this has really refined that element of extra instrumentation incorporation though the beginning of this track is a little repetitive the ending of it is so climactic and just so oh worth it and if there is a single vibe or idea that you can boil a lot of the tracks on this album down to its that on this LP Chelsea delivers a lot of slow burning and building songs that you may or may not get impatient with before the point they actually blossom in a pretty depressive fashion the song we hit a wall towards its finish has these intense string sections the track house of metal which kicks off of the drum machine ends with this really eerie plinky melody and some wispy strings - a huge atmosphere on this track and while these tracks are great it's really the second-half of pain is beauty where I feel like Chelsea kind of lights the world on fire songs like sick are total surprise they start off huge instrumentally with some really twisted vocal effects on Chelsea's singing and then around the middle point of the track it introduces some space into the atmosphere and then kelsey is singing against what feels like some progressives sent instrumental with these arpeggiated ascending and descending synth lines Chelsey's layering of instrumentation is definitely more impressive here than it was on our last full-length and on top of that her exploration into other sounds and and musical ideas and genres for the most part are successful I would say that this album has all of the great points that her last full-length did except it's a little more refined and well assembled for sure Pena's beauty is not as ferocious or as scary as Sharptooth as apocalypsis but chelsea still brings good songs to the table and a ton of sonic variety like the very tense and uncomfortable track kings or the delicate song reigns with this 3/4 time signature and some beautiful backing instrumentation or the very full key and kind of pj harvey inspired they'll clap when you're gone as far as downsides on this thing go yeah there were some tracks that again I wasn't too crazy about and there are other tracks too that I feel like meet somewhat abrupt endings but man are there moments on this thing instrumentally I feel like are so freakin beautiful that it's it's like I'm watching some kind of just moving scene in a movie or something just really emotionally instrumentally melodically and sonically intense I'm just loving this album it's it's just a beautifully depressive listen I'm feeling a decent 8 on this thing I hope hope hope you give it a listen don't let the variety throw you off and just see if it grows on you transition if you're given this Chelsea wolf album listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana only the strong subscribe pain is beauty forever

my needle drops Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for your review of the new Holograms album forever Holograms re Swedish post-punk outfit who last year put out their full-length debut on captured tracks records a nice fast intense little self-titled album and now about 14 months later here we are with a new full-length it's another installment of post-punk revival ISM and as you guys may know I am not usually one to just praise nostalgia for the sake of nostalgia but I think there have been some inventive and refreshing acts to sort of toy with these darker sounds in post-punk music as of late but when it comes to Holograms I do feel like they are less distinct the band songs are pretty steeped in these classic post-punk and synth punk influences however in my opinion on their last full-length album they made up for this issue easily with just some raw energy and some really catchy songwriting with singles like ABC city or deeper tracks on the record like Orfeo or memories of sweat the band's performances just had this intense energy the vocals while over-the-top and maybe a little out of control were really passionate and captivating while stylistically Holograms wasn't really adventurous I do feel like they had this art of post-punk songwriting down to a hard science and I did like the fact that the band's approach was kind of poppy and just instantaneous however I feel like on this new record of theirs forever they're trying to change their sound in their direction up a little bit I really think the band is trying to come off loftier a bit darker on this thing with moodier guitars a bit more reverb all over everything and an increase in the use of synthesizers and synthesizers of a different tone to on the band's last full-length LP whenever a synth would hop into a track it was usually bright loud and noisy whereas on this album the synthesizers a much smooth they're much more darker like they would slide really nicely into a Joy Division single or like a goth rock song and we do see Holograms on this record experimenting with trying to write longer songs on the whole of the album not really dropping in for just a 1 minute and 40 second batch fest while I do appreciate that the band made an attempt to change and believe me this is a change that they needed to make but here I feel like they're taking away some of that raw energy and trying to build up their songs without a solid foundation case in point one of the things they string these songs out with guitar solos guitar solos that are not really that exciting and just kind of feel like the band is putting it there just to pad the song out like on the song of sacred state the opener to this album or the song at test stupa whose title is actually more edgy than its guitar playing it's actually a reference to this practice in Nordic society where elderly people or those who are just no longer of use to the town that they were living in would just sort of hop off this cliff to their death but let it be known that there are some people that do not even believe that this practice was common or even existed still for a song title this gloomy and for a band this ferocious on a majority of its songs the guitar solo here just kind of feels like a very tame and limited rehash of the theme melody of this song itself now occasionally I do feel like Holograms ambition pays off like the rush of building drums and rolling snares on the track rush with these intense guitars just tightly locking in with them I feel like Holograms have reached a new level of tightness with this track especially with the incredibly climactic finish to this song really loud really powerful and there is the closing track on here to lay us down which for me is the only honest-to-god ballad on this album not a bad thing I love that the band comes through with some slightly more melodic vocals and some really huge tubular bells what sounds like tubular bells on the chorus just building the track higher and higher but for every triumphant moment for me there is at least one kind of well mning spot and even though holograms last full-length record wasn't really all that original I do feel like that album did have some kind of element of diversity to it you had these harder faster more in-your-face tracks poppier tracks slower more depressing songs that are bleak as hell but on forever it seems like Holograms is trying to deliver a series of variants on the same synth backed goth Punk song now there are tracks on here that stick out like flesh and bone or meditations songs that are a testament to the fact that hologram still has an immense talent for hook writing which really makes refrains as basic and as simple as I'm so tired pretty freakin catchy and something that most likely you will be singing along with by the end of the song especially since the vocals are so passionate and the band repeats some of these refrains a lot of times overall I didn't really hear anything on this album that I thought was awful and I still enjoy the songs that dropped ahead of the release of forever a lot I feel like they stick out on their own but when you bring them all together this album becomes this homogenous piece of post-punk revival ISM I'm feeling a strong six on this record transition if you've given this Holograms album a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's about it only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional this review is only my opinion also I want to mention that I have a new music video review video over at the maker youtube channel go check that out via a link down there or on my face and that's it Anthony Fantana Holograms forever forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review the new Jonathan Rado album Law & Order Jonathan Rado singer-songwriter who you might know from the singing songwriting duo Fox agem who came out with two great full-length projects recently a reissue of the album take the kids off Broadway on jag Jaguar records and earlier this year we are the 21st century ambassadors of peace and magic which was on the same label and what I enjoyed so much about these records especially take the kids off Broadway is that John and and Sam were able to take all of these elements of 60s psychedelic pop and rock classic rock to sort of mash them together in this really jarring way but on top of just sort of being masters of manipulating a lot of these old vintage retro rock and pop sounds Sam and John I thought were really good songwriters wrote great choruses deliver great lyrics and had a lot of passion coming through on the vocals too so of course when I heard that this thing was coming out I was really excited to hear John's talents portrayed in a solo capacity but was somewhat shocked to hear this album fall very short of my expectations usually I'm not the kind of person that goes into solo efforts expecting to be completely blown away anyway because no matter how great the original band may be as soon as an artist is out of their element really anything goes and I feel like Law & Order is a testament to that fact to start with the performances the singing is really lackluster on a lot of these songs either it's not that passionate or captivating or I hear John straining in his upper register a lot on these songs making him kind of unlistenable their songs on here like hand in mine which essentially feel like a bad Adam Greene impersonation and then there are tracks such as looking for a girl like you where we are privy to this horrible falsetto which is just ear piercing Lee it hurts it literally hurts to listen to partially it's because the fall said it was not performed all that well plus there's a heap of distortion on this thing making it pretty unintelligible and on top of that it's not really mixed or eq'd all that well either it's really enough to make you want an instrumental track of which there are a few on here like the song dance away your ego which essentially is just some throwaway cheesy organ rock that I'm never gonna remember and truth is I kind of want to forget it because of how many mistakes are going on in the playing on this track it's like the drums and the guitars aren't even in sync some of the time it's just kind of a little old-school pop rock groove that John can't seem to pull together instrumentally I think the closest that John comes to delivering a decent song is the track faces the melody especially through the guitar leads is really sharp it's catchy but honestly stylistically the song doesn't have all that much personality to it it's not that distinct it's steeped a little bit too much in that whole Brit pop mod rock tradition to be memorable on its own accord and this is surprising to me because because John through Fox agem has a history of taking these sounds and doing something crazy over the top and etc quit them but here on this album we see John treating these sounds he's not even really treating them he's just kind of copying them in this really unflattering way if the production and the singing and the songwriting were up to snuff that would be one thing but man even as kind of a nostalgic trip back this album does not work unfortunately Jonathan Rado on Law & Order when he is not delivering some some bad performances or some weak singing he is just indulging in some generic songwriting that has some very middle-of-the-road retro rock and pop sounds with the exception of the track pot of gold which is a pretty nice drum machine back piece of synth pop and I want a Fela which is like this distorted fuzz doubt psyche rock nightmare that reminds me of something ty Segall would do Segal I will never know occasionally there is a decent tune on here and Jonathan does do a good job of capturing these retro sounds and vibes but I still think a majority this thing is is pretty unlistenable I'm feeling a light for on this album transition if you've given this John Rado album a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's about it only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anthony Fantana Jonathan Rado Law & Order forever

and philosophically and YC brings plenty of that on this new album of his gnk is a little bit of a concept album dealing with race religion and God power and ego topics that have been touched down upon multiple times in hip-hop music but rarely does it come off as focused and as well thought-out and is well produced as what I'm hearing here the beats on this project are done by Frank Drake a producer who I'm not particularly familiar with but I do think working with him track for track has resulted in a great project it seems like by working with one dude every twist and turn YC is able to make topically and philosophically Frank Drake is there to accompany it with a very well fitting instrumental like the track the pox which is the first full-length song on this album and with the very drum heavy verses on this track and it's the space around these rhythms with YC flowing over these beats really well it kind of feels like the start of something it's really cinematic it's like a gathering a sermon is beginning and the really grainy keyboard keys that kind of feel like they were played out on a Mellotron or something like that they sound gorgeous and just kiss the intro of this track and the hook really well with the run so that's you can't and this track fits into the overall theme of this album in numerous ways to POC Shakur kind of being revered as a hip-hop God fitting in with that God theme and the PAC's also kind of sounds like the PAC's which is an interesting play on words and the song heavenly I love the instrumental here as well with the soulful vocal sampling and the very jazzy horns it's very beautiful uplifting instrumental and YC comes through with an uplifting message lyrically as well trying to get the listener to think more of themselves and think more directly about their relation to God however even though this seems like a good thing on this track there is sort of a dark side to the mentions of God and religion on this album they come through the strongest on the song God complex a track that is kind of surprised for why I see the cynic because he sings on this song from back to front with a vocal melody that kind of sounds like Suzanne Vegas Tom's diner which is pretty interesting considering that song was sampled on the Milo mixtape that YC appeared on earlier this year I'm just sort of imagining Milo and YC like jam and some Suzanne Vega or something Y C's vocal melody does get a little repetitive throughout the song and it becomes pretty apparent pretty fast that he isn't the greatest singer in the world but he does hold his own he doesn't really sing outside of his vocal range on this track and it's really the lyrics that kind of Wow and keep this song engaging YC talking about how godly he is and using his powers to strike fear in people because he kind of needs people to worship Him in order to feel good about himself in the lyrics he says he'll part the widest ocean and bust the world wide open and with the instrumental in the background just with these plucked beautiful strings being played it just has this really dramatic theatrical element to it that is really fitting the same kind of mentality and in portrayal runs through other tracks on here - like molotovs at Poseidon or power trip except these songs go a little bit harder have some more aggressive instrumentals and you really hear y'see rap on these tracks especially at the star of molotovs episode in which I mean it's it's not a deep set of lyrics that kick this track off but you've just got to kind of imagine what he's saying at the beginning of this song and some interesting and powerful imagery of him being godlike a shooting at Zeus you know I'm cutting through my noose I'm pulling up my roots every bars like this large powerful grandiose gesture that if you think about it actually being a reality it's pretty scary that someone would be that but you do have moments on here like on the track power trip where why see kind of puts his godlike image into a fetal position sort of portraying that there are some chinks in this armor this more vulnerable side of why see is also on display on tracks like the heaviest cross where he kind of directly addresses the fact that he's a musician and he has his issues just like any musician does putting themselves out there when dealing with people that don't like their music whether it be through hateful comments or sort of very critical blog reviews he kind of just comes to the conclusion that this because of his line of work is his cross to bear it's his issue to deal with and then after this he quickly moves on to his mother having her own cross to bear raising kids getting her master's so on and so forth closing track on here being God's her breaks that fourth wall again and addresses the listener directly either thanking them for listening or asking them to kind of take part in spreading the word on this music he again kind of displays a bit of weakness by saying that he feels threatened because he's a free open thinker and that's kind of a dangerous thing for someone to be while I do think it is a really personal and introspective finish to the album I guess my issue is that I didn't really see this song pulling the whole concept of this album together into kind of a nice tight little package that's really my biggest letdown with this LP though even though YC doesn't meticulously assemble this album together in this flawlessly segwayed concept album it doesn't necessarily mean that the songs themselves are bad actually a majority of them are great the only shortcoming on some of the tracks here I think are the hooks why see maybe a god but I think hooks sometimes are kind of his kryptonite either they don't add to the song in a way that's all that meaningful or at least meaningful in an obvious way kind of like on the song Murphy's Law which I think the hook only really makes sense after the second verse when he's kind of talking about the evolution of the mind 999 because on the hook he's essentially saying fuck bitches get money i think the only hook on here that i really disliked was the chorus on know-it-alls not necessarily because it didn't make sense to me but why cease singing on this track is incredibly off pitch and not really in a cute or interesting way just really kind of killed the hook here for me still lyrically it is a very interesting song that plays into ycs relationship I think his relationship with God and when you dive into this album overall even though I feel like it doesn't all tie together in a very clean way it does portray this really deep and personal back-and-forth struggle with these issues that this album addresses like I said earlier God power ego race the last of which is specifically address on the track the n-word all I know is this sort of mental wrestling match is is really interesting blow-for-blow so as far as his lyrics go I find YC to be really fascinating dude vocally I think he does have some personality he's got a bit of a speech impediment that comes through on his vocals a bit but he seems to sidestep it sometimes it doesn't ruin his verses or make them difficult to listen to in my opinion it adds character and as far as his flows go he changes him up he has a good command of flow I wouldn't say he goes ultra fast a lot of the time really he's kind of keeping it at a mid pace to focus on delivering a message in the lyrics I'm feeling a decent strong eight on this album turn so yes I am heavily endorsing this why see the cynic album right now definitely check this thing out if you're an artist like A Tribe Called Quest Kara's one most def del the funky homosapien this review is my opinion only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional magic happy magic love you YC the cynic gnk forever

my needle drops Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for your review of the new underachievers mixtape EP project the Lords of Flatbush underachievers hard-hitting New York rap duo that dropped a pretty good mixtape much earlier this year through brain feeder indigo ISM I wouldn't say I loved it I enjoyed it I still enjoy it listen to it every once in a while I think it's pretty interesting that the duo brings across a nice blend of different hip hop influences some of that southern stuff some of that boom-bap stuff some of that cloud wrap stuff but it's not like they have one track that sits in one direction and one track that sits in another it really comes together in sort of a seamless fashion with beats that feel kind of trippy layered psychedelic the instrumentals are seriously mystical on this project and for the most part the lyrics kind of tip their hat in that direction - it's a - and a que have some incredibly aggressive flows however I saw that there were some shortcomings in the lyrics as far as diversity goes while the underachievers do have a really solid theme together having to do with souls and third eyes and just higher levels of thinking of course a lot of drug use as well it feels like a lot of the tracks are more based on buzzwords than they are narratives or just some really quotable lines still I dig the underachievers vibe I'm looking forward to when they drop another full-length project into the future but it seems that we had this little EP size deal with Lords of Flatbush to kind of hold us over some production on this thing done by lex luger trap music titin lex luger kind of a risk factor for the underachievers a lot of people who sort of perceive that music to be ignorant see the underachievers being a kind of a higher-level mentally and I feel like jumping on with Lex for this project has its positives it has its negatives for one I do not find the instrumentals on this tape to be as wonderfully melodic as the stuff I was hearing on indigo ISM however it is a little more hard-hitting it is a bit catchy er sometimes a K and it settle their flows down into a simpler more southern vibe to maybe gain some more appeal factor if that is the case though I don't really see them delivering the kinds of infectious and overly repetitive hooks that you would typically hear from an artist that usually rides these kinds of beats I could actually hear maybe even Chief Keef just yelling something ridiculous over some of these instrumentals toward the middle and back end of this project there are some beats that feel like they could totally slip into the Indigo ISM tracklisting like melody of the free a fantastically soulful and jazzy instrumental that I think is my favorite of the bunch however my biggest disappointment on this tape other than some of the beats and maybe some of the vocals sounding a little muddy in the recording is that the lyrics are not that surprising and I feel like the underachievers really could have used a bit of a change or development with their lyricism while again the flows are aggressive when they need to be to just keep things kind of hard in your face and just high energy there aren't many tracks where the underachievers venture out of their comfort zone just kind of shouting again those buzzwords and kind of making sure that you don't go too many lines without hearing at least one of them there are some tracks on here where it feels like the underachievers do try to come together with a concept like this on fake fans or melody of the free which are tracks where the underachievers really try to dissect the fame that they've received since the Indigo ISM tape got so popular dealing with people who are into their stuff but maybe not right or die I guess overall I was just a little underwhelmed by this thing I was hoping that the lex luger production because I heard that this tape was coming through the woodwork would be a bit more hard-hitting and while I guess I don't expect the underachievers to say anything incredibly deep over this lex luger production I'm still kind of waiting for the moment when they say something a little heavier a little loftier something that really delivers on the promise that is essentially brought to the table by the fact that they're constantly talking about their knowledge their enlightenment their third eye their higher state of thought when that comes through I'll be psyched until then I'm really kind of feeling a light too decent five on this thing but if you've given the Lords of Flatbush a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that is it only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anthony Fantan Oh forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new dawn of midi album dis no mia dawn of midi is a california instrumental music outfit whose musical influences really reach far and wide experimental jazz minimalism and electronic music are among the many things sort of play out in the many tunes on this album and that list of influences had me pretty freaking psyched to check this thing out it really kind of seemed like it was definitely something that was up my alley there are albums in the recent past that i have praised pretty heavily for bringing together elements of acoustic instrumentation acoustic sounds and executing them in a way that feels sort of chilly repetitive techno or house music influenced artists like for tet or john hopkins or even that new portico crash no record what sounds like a guitar some upright bass piano and various pieces of percussion and executing them in a way that feels really rigid mechanical on the surface it sounded really cool with these off-kilter bass lines that only consisted of a few notes very minimal minimal piano leads this is hand these just twittering rhythm sections all the instrumentation is just in this busy lockstep as if it's just all the inner workings of a grandfather clock or something like that and while dawn of midi is really that rigid they're also really that sterile to the point where a lot of the grooves that these guys are rocking honest to god kind of sound like i'm listening to a broken record kind of skipping over and over and over and over and over and who it doesn't really add much to these songs emotionally or compositionally I think pretty much all the songs on this LP build up a little bit and then reach a point of plateau where they just kind of hit this tension and never really release it resolve it or even build it higher even as the band is introducing or subtracting pieces of instrumentation so yeah for me the grooves are a little too mechanical not all that visceral but I guess on top of that there's not much melody to a lot of these tracks either even though there are elements of tone to this album it's like every piece of instrumentation only adds into the track in a rhythmic way even when you do get a baseline that feels a tad bit embellished or a little piano that ascends or descends further than two or three notes it comes off so simple that it's really hardly worth remembering so while dawn of MIDI definitely has a vibe and has succeeded in creating an instrumental blend that is really stiff clearly it's intentional it just doesn't add up much to me plus by the end of the record a lot of the Tambor's and sounds that they're working with just gets stale mostly because the Tambor's and the grooves these very sterile against sterile grooves are really all you can focus on for the duration of this record it's not like there is an element of melody or a strong element of sound play to kind of pull your attention away from those things really those are the only things you could think of for this entire LP and they only go so far as being interesting I'm feeling a decent five on this album but what did you think of this dawn of MIDI album did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that is about it only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional this review is my opinion anthony Fantana dawn of midi forever

my needle drops Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new king cruel album six feet beneath the moon quickly before I get into this review I want name and about and a 2010 beginning a 2011 when he signed a true panther sounds before then he was known as zoo kid had some band camp music up that was grabbing a lot of buzz eventually he put out an EP on true panther sounds that I reviewed enjoyed quite a bit I felt like some of the songs on this thing were a little half-baked I also wish it were longer above all things that were presented on this EP I really dug kink rules aesthetic with the bare bones instrumentation the really sharp reverb guitar and his voice uh his voice this dude is a low tone crooner and I love singers like that but more than most people that sing in this register he makes music that just is sharp it's bright it's stark King cruel instrumentally tends to run a little minimal and even when he does have some more backing instrumentation he usually leaves it so spacious that there's just a lot of room around everything ah but it feels like king cruel tries to take this very little amount of instrumentation and make it as loud and as expressive as possible with these guitar strumming patterns that emphasize these just really tiny sharp up strokes he's just really fluid with these strumming patterns and his vocals which are just really emotive eccentric loud and raw yelling a lot of the time I wouldn't say screaming but he does just have some force to the way that he sings to the point where he loses control of his pitch and really his composure part of what makes this album so good and so entertaining is that few artists are this early in their career and have such a defined sound and on top of that it helps that kink rule has sharpened his songwriting chops up a little bit he was able to effectively build up excitement for this album with some really good singles to drop before this thing the song rock bottom which unfortunately does not make it on to this LPS tracklist it's a shame very good song would have added to this thing in my opinion but the song easy easy which kicks this album off from the moment the guitar strumming pattern comes in and and King cruel sings the same ooh boo boo somos boo I'm just hooked that thick accent that voice the vivid lyricism that's coming through with the storytelling and even when he just loses control of his voice in the chorus and just wails on these guitar chords it's such an explosive point in the song and still with just those vocals and those guitars it feels incredibly powerful it's like I'm listening to some sort of intimate performance and he's just plugged an electric guitar into a small amp and is playing in a chapel or in a stone underpass underneath a downtown London Bridge it's a great track to me though I don't think it's necessarily going to be for everybody because of kink rules voice it's a bit of an acquired taste however if this track does not turn you off I would say just continue on if you are into this track though there are still some questions that are worth asking will King cruel stay so minimal and so simple that the entire album will sound essentially the same will he be able to come through with a diverse LP for the 50 minutes that this thing lasts and I don't really feel like he runs into those problems per se kink rule does change things up instrumentally from track to track carrying his vocals with either guitar synthesizers some loop drumbeats some background vocals from himself or even a little bit of piano and there's kind of a fresh approach in how he brings these vintage pop and rock aesthetics together with some subtle trip-hop and hip hop beats there are moments where it kind of feels like he's doing a little spoken-word slash rapping and I love the fact that he's able to incorporate some of these older sounds but not have this album feeling like a throwback or some kind of pointless tribute to an essentially dead musical movement however what I think is going to grab people even more than the genre labels for this album are the emotions of this album this thing is such a drag however the sad and kind of wild demeanor can only go so far if the songs aren't great all the way through because there were tracks on this thing that had me wondering whether or not they needed to be here if the cell P really needed to be 50 minutes long there are a handful of tracks on this thing that don't do too much for me like the track 4 & 2 which for all of its instrumentation loop drum beats and the watery synthesizers some sound effects and these really noodley guitar lines that play throughout the track there's not really a solid tune coming out of any of it and I like kink rules voice over the track but it just kind of feels like vocally he is just wandering this track to me feels like really half of a track stretched out to three minutes long hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new ASAP ferg album trap Lord ASAP ferg New York based rapper member of the ASAP mob and this is an album that I have been dreading reviewing a little bit to be completely honest partially because of the singles that came out before this album was released like the song work as well as the track Shabba Ranks really huge trap music influence on these songs however lyrically and just sort of flow and and vocal wise what ASAP ferg was sort of reminding me of was kind of like a goofier version of ASAP rocky if you can imagine that I guess there are elements of his shtick that you could also liken to rap artists such as Trinidad James little B waka flocka flames but he clearly has this deeper appreciation for the classics in hip hop and great instrumentals and good flows and overall just a more holistic aesthetic because this album as weird and as goofy and as bad as it can be sometimes does feel like it flows really well from track to track with interludes that segue and bring tracks together and just sort of make trap Lorde kind of a seamless experience and also on this LP I think ASAP ferg brings a ton of humor and charisma and just some personality that may not have been completely apparent just from the earlier singles and from where I've heard him featured before still despite I guess some initial reservations Ferg does come through in a lot of ways on this LP especially instrumentally definitely ASAP Rocky's great taste in beats have been passed over to Ferg for this project a lot like ASAP Rocky's last album you're getting these elements of trap rap southern hip hop chopped and screwed Memphis stuff on top of a little bit of cloud wrap making things really cavernous muscle bruised consistently on this LP the instrumentals are loud they're epic their dark they've got a lot of synth textures and flavors I love the opening track from this thing let it go the beginning of this album is actually pretty solid for the first 30 tracks but let it go man with the hand percussion and the kind of Middle Eastern to me synthesizers over these trap beats to me kind of feels like ASAP ferg is this trap Sultan in the middle of this smokey harem the song Shabba Ranks definitely brings that vibe to me too I dig that song as well that has grown on me but I do think the song gets a little shaky toward the end with Ferg's flow getting kind of just a little weak and ridiculous but it's not like the song didn't start ridiculously with it being kind of in tribute to this 90's dancehall rageh star that just kind of plays into the overall absurdity of ASAP Ferg's personality and this album really I think my favorite tracks on this album are songs like this and Lord where essentially you have these trap instrumentals just hitting really hard and just having a lot of reverb on them a lot of Darkness coming from the melodies on these tracks to me the synthesizers on Lord are incredibly sinister as well as on the song Fergie Vicious and the remix for work which is cold and as hard as hell especially with the schoolboy q verse on the back end of this track and I actually dug the song Mertes something quite a bit too with waka flocka flame which has this awesome opera sample going on in the instrumental not usually something I like in my hip-hop beats but it was kind of applied subtly enough to help out the rising action of the song and just sounded great it wasn't strung out too long it wasn't to God he was just in the background first let's second added some character Tertre and of course over these instrumentals another kind of melodic component that you get his first voice when he is singing if he is doing it well and you can manage to tolerate it there is some serious Bone Thugs influence coming through on this thing again just like that Live Love ASAP just like the long live ASAP but Ferg does take it a step further and invites bone thugs-n-harmony onto this album for a feature on the track Lord that I just mentioned and it is fantastic just machinegun flows one after another really thrilling exciting other hip-hop greats are attributed on this LP like on the song out my face with be real from Cypress Hill the first verse on this track onyx is on the song bringing these really loud scream choruses sticky-fingers from onyx has a verse - I think we're Fergus little shaky is when he is pulling together some hooks or structuring songs or even singing singing is really the Achilles heel of this project hood Pope while maybe hearing ASAP ferg sing might be funny or sort of entertaining for a minute there's no reason it should be lasting for three minutes and 30 seconds on top of that the track for outh I can't think of anything less sexy than hearing ASAP ferg sing as if it's some kind of kid cudi Drake collaboration about a threesome and as far as the closer on this LP goes cocaine Castle I can appreciate that lyrically Ferg is trying to come in and and say hey listen drugs will destroy your life except I need my album trap Lord and I'm rapping about trapping and murdering people throughout much of this thing there are some spots where the choruses feel a little half-assed or obvious like dump dump and the track didn't want to do that while I do think it's kind of silly that again ASAP Ferg raps about murdering people quite a bit and yet seems to want to make this track hear about his friend getting murdered over his chain either way what really ends up killing this song off is the incredibly long vocal interlude in the middle where you have one person telling another person about the entire incident on the phone and then the person being called getting angry about it still despite that handful of complaints I don't think this is a bad album it's incredibly fun ignorant silly and just ridiculous again it's not like there's this incredible depth to the lyrics and when ASAP ferg does manage to bring that for me it's kind of like thankfully this album doesn't make you have to choose between highbrow and lowbrow all too often it's an interesting blend of both the ASAP mob I think is doing a fantastic job of bringing this absurd ignorance together with just kind of high fashion and more refined aesthetics I guess that's how you could put it I'm my needle drops Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for track reviews where I review a track it's the new death grip song birds if you don't know Death Grips by now they are an experimental hip-hop trio from the Sacramento area in California they put out one of my favorite hip hop albums in 2011 and two of my favorite hip hop albums last year in 2012 they have a new full-length LP which they say is going to be released on their own label third world's in 2014 sort of in tandem or with support from gram old records which is kind of an interesting and funny music business connection considering that the band completely sploded their last record deal by allowing their album to prematurely leak and all their fans pretty much downloaded it plus it has a penis on the cover the latest little tidbit of excitement having to do with Death Grips is this new track of there's birds and this track brings up a lot of questions for me about where Death Grips is gonna go from here especially in the experimental hip hop realm where they have trail blazed a little bit to the point where they have just brought a lot of attention to themselves to the genre rappers and producers hopping on this bandwagon and just sort of trying things out for themselves most notably Kanye West recently with his new full-length LP we could have been somebody you had to bet somebody take it back to the first pilot when you tried to first matter and Captain Ellie and I'm sweaty well as excited as I was to try this track out it felt a little bit like kind of Death Grips as usual with some newer ideas and just some some slight changes of pace one of the viewers of this show points out Nick Palmer there are some interesting samples going on in this track one of which I'm pretty sure is Muttley who is a cartoon character that you might be familiar with if you grew up watching hanna-barbera's laff-a-lympics there's just this weird quiet laughing sound that's happening going on very subtly in the background like the 106 point and of course there are a league of other noises flow throughout this track that are just as esoteric and obscure that's the thing about Death Grips they're so freakin esoteric puzzling and cryptic and maybe the reason that they continue to sort of stay on the lips of so many people who are generally music fans and people who are in the music press is that we haven't really technically figured them out yet it seems like they continually do things that are bad and horrible for their careers and we're kind of stuck wondering what's their motive to start with the track instrumentally I do dig this song quite a bit it has this blazing opener with these warped vocals screaming this refrain over and over and over but it's so twisted and manipulated that it feels like it's synthesized electronically generated then these murky synths and dissonant scents and electronic drums come just bashing in just thickening the track up and once this all kind of breaks away after a really quick like punk music style drum beat it sort of slips into this very quiet subtle and kind of spacious spot where hurry chopped up and skipped out vocals sort of deliver some verses and behind this is a very eerie eerie melody that sounds like it's being played by a guitar of some sort but that could have been sampled from somewhere else the melody to me feels almost as if like it's got a little bit in common with a corne single falling away from me from their life is peachy album of all things but anyway at this moment not only is the melody kind of pretty it's captivating I think just this instrumental alone without emcee rides vocals are one of Death Grips more interesting instrumentals but with everything being so straight back I feel personally that they're trying to put some kind of emphasis on the lyrics here there's definitely some symbolism going on here having to do with birds and power but the more that I read through the lyrics the more confused I am about them what their overall messages and if some of them are even right there's one thing in the lyrics that makes me feel like there might be some typos is when MC Wright says that he had a bluebird but now it's dead but written out it says that it is did there are moments where I catch statements from this track like about attitude or life being wore which are expressions that Death Grips has kind of made in the past however the statement that power is cheap and the mention of Jesus to Jesus does not come up often in Death Grips music I wonder why but it spots like this that have some people sort of guessing that this track in some way or another might be some kind of Kanye West disc but honestly that's not a statement that I feel personally willing to make because just about every supposition that I've read people making about this song feels like kind of a stretch because you can only really pull out a few lines or words from this thing and be like ah that's what this means but what about the rest of it lyrically the entirety of the song doesn't really bring me to any one conclusion and being disjointed may be intentional maybe it's just supposed to be addressing or bringing up a bunch of different topics still I feel like that kind of loses some impact overall with this track I feel like I have been tossed this puzzle that wasn't really meant to be figured out however Death Grips knows full well that everybody's gonna grab onto this thing and be like what's it mean what's it mean but if you've given this track of listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why and what do you think I should review next only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anthony Fantana Death Grips birds forever and here's
