hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Giulia holter album loud city song first off just want to say I'm happy I'm back happy I'm doing reviews again for you guys I missed you I even missed Cal you're really hurry life missed me yes I did I missed you so much I even wrote a song just for you oh boy sing it I will I will well I didn't actually write a song you're an idiot I hate you so much Julia halter is a California singer songwriter she has several studio records under her belt this is the latest and she is a musician who I have been a little weary of because of her past work for a while because of how dreamy much of it tends to be and while that aesthetic isn't bad there wasn't much vocally or musically that was kind of stopping me in my tracks and making me say wow holy crap however this new LP of hers is a slight change of pace and enough of a change of pace to get me to say wow holy crap for the most part Julia's songs are still abstract slow burning ballads but the instrumentation on Cloud City song feels very very upfront Center tangible detailed yes their synthesizers on this LP yes there are vocals on this LP but these songs are also beautifully layered in these just tangible strings and horns making for a record that yes is is art pop yes is dream pop it has some characteristics of chamber music and a bit of jazz in here too I would actually say a bit of musical theater seems to seep through on the opening track to this thing world which features Julia halter singing these very dramatic lines which are delivered with this faint delicate singing style Julie being very subtle and tender on this track and she comes through with these kind of abstract lines tipping her hat two hats as well as misters and mothers cities this no named girl who is singing on the fifth floor of an apartment building which she later reveals to be herself she's asking herself questions like how can I escape you what am I looking for in you there's this great sense of longing that sort of permeates nearly every track on this album even as the music gets increasingly more bubbly bright cloudy blissful like the song maximum layout which has these very puffy string sections gently pulsating against these wailing strings that are just crying away in the background Julia comes through with her beautiful voice again on this track but is much more animated than on the previous song and brings through a little bit of whispered spoken word on this track as well which is a technique she uses at a few other points on this thing too for example the song in the green wild which for a good chunk of the song features just Julia kind of blending these elements of singing and talking against this very busy upright bass line it's kind of a fun captivating more playful side of Julia and on the flip side we have more spoken word right at the beginning of the track horns surrounding me which maybe isn't spoken word as much as it is just straight creepy with Julia recording herself or somebody else running from what sounds like horns through the woods whispering oh my god they're getting me it's kind of like the Blair Witch Project but like PLA re4 blaring horns music joke however this is one of the tracks that maybe I wasn't completely enamored with because Julia was getting drowned out a bit by the horn she is kind of a subtle singer however maybe that was kind of the point with the horns surrounding her because after all her voice does cut through the mists of instrumentation beautifully on the track hello stranger and this of course is a nice contrast from one of the more harder hitting songs on this LP maxims to which features these multi-tracked vocals from Julia in this tense rising instrumentation Julia does bring quite a bit of diversity to the table on this thing I am really impressed with the fact that she has these more animated tracks these songs that have more hard-hitting instrumentation just these really serene songs these beautiful songs these songs that are just more odd and kind of obtuse and off-putting and yet it all kind of has this thread of Beauty running throughout all of it toward the end of this LP Julia continues to deliver some pretty decent songs like he is running through my eyes which is a very beautiful piano ballad and this is a true heart is maybe the most bubbly fancy-free track on this entire LP it's kind of like a psychedelic dreamy prance romp around through Candyland however the last track on this thing highlights one of the major overall issues that I do have with this record record with so many of these songs and this album in general being so abstract in terms of structure or flow there are a lot of moments where I feel like these tracks come through with legit endings that feel like they deliver some kind of closure or some kind of cool-down point where I feel like the finish is coming the last track on this thing doesn't feel all too climactic or even really like a finisher for what themes and ideas are presented on loud city song for the most part lyrically it brings a lot of the same themes that were delivered on the opening track here maybe it's a bit of a reprieve I guess this LP doesn't really end with a significant change because so much of what's here is based upon Julia's surroundings and and those haven't changed by the end of the album or at least that's what it feels like this LP is is really more of a space that can be wandered through as opposed to some kind of urgent tale that has a beginning and a middle and an end which is pretty interesting considering how much pop music influences this album and that's typically the mentality that that flows through that kind of music overall to me the mood the style the production the singing the songwriting and melodies on this thing incredibly solid very enjoyable occasionally Julia does come off very Kate bushy really kind of wears her influences on those sleeves but it doesn't ruin the experience for me because I think she's come together with a solid record that she could call her own I'm feeling a strong 7 to a light 8 on this thing but what do you think do you love loud city song do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next only the strong subscribe all mistakes or intentional Anthony Fantana Julia halter lad city song forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Earl Sweatshirt album Doris Earl Sweatshirt California rapper member of the infamous Odd Future Wolf Gang kill them all hip hop collective and this is the long-awaited follow-up to his debut tape that came out a handful of years ago and maybe it wouldn't have taken him so long to follow it up had he not been sent away to a trouble boy's camp in Samoa by his mother and I in no way whatsoever questioned the parenting abilities of mrs. sweatshirt however I do wonder whether or not that sort of stalling prevented this album from being as as big as it could have possibly been because when Odd Future was first getting huge it was like there was an incredible demand to hear music with the hole-free earl hype tyler the creator saying that earl is is far better a rapper than he is and the mixtape that he dropped itself shows that he is one of the better MCS and odd future in general definitely with Earl you don't get the cheap production the weak flows the bad singing that sometimes appear on odd future releases however I don't really feel like he ends up coming ahead of the pack on Doris what Earl serves up well on this LP are Flo's wordplay and just a really strong mood maybe mood is the strongest characteristic of this entire LP this album is dark it's nocturnal it's pretty low-key kind of surreal in some ways I do feel like this album is a mature growth past that dark side that odd future used to have in its earliest stuff and that shows to me because lyrically Earl is is going for a lot less shock value and I think he has brought the best best instrumentals that have appeared on any Odd Future project across the board you have Earl himself doing production and co-production under the name random black dude on this LP the wu-tang as the RZA is on this thing as well as The Neptunes I think the only instrumentals that I didn't dig were the one that opened this LP up it just sounded like chopped and screwed molasses to me the beat that Tyler put together on Sasquatch kind of sounded like a wolf throw away drops this awful line saying that he used to be dope but now he's not dope anymore but Chris and Rihanna are fucking so there's still hope oh shit he went there which is there's nothing worse than someone who thinks they're being controversial when they're not I don't even think someone on the view would have batted an eye at that line maybe my least favorite song on this LP overall the one with Mac Miller on a guild was the title the song for me was really too slow to be exciting too sparse to be interesting and to hear Earl and Mac Miller just pitch shifted lower for a full few verses which were pretty empty substance wise was just terrible still I was happy to hear a group of instrumentals that covered a wide array of hip-hop flavors from the more synthetic stuff to jazz rap and boom bap the song Burgundy brings these grand horns and pianos with this awesome little synth lead in the background instrumentally to me the song hive is kind of like an improvement on this yonkers formula and the track Chum kind of has that rough synthesizer odd future flavor to it but it's balanced out a little bit with these weird piano samples i love the heavy thick base on Centurian bad bad not good kills it on horse and the beat that the RZA brought to the table wasn't bad could have come from any era could have just been a throw away for him but I feel like it worked itself into the album well but when it comes to features Doris starts to get a little inconsistent especially right at the start of this thing with la flair who brings this just boring flow boring tough-talking bland verse and very little in the way of personality another feature that completely disappointed me on this thing the RZA I'm molasses horrifyingly underutilized on this track a frugal Foods Booch really bringing a hip-hop giant down to that odd future level the features I ended up liking were Frank Ocean who had some interesting wordplay about his sexuality on Sunday and just a very personal verse on this song there was Domo Genesis who completely surprised me on this thing I've heard him on some tracks from wool for you sounded pretty good but he came out very hungry on doris actually to the elite field as far as vince staples goes to me a more interesting rapper than earl on this album to when he spit some bars though I will say that part of what makes him so appealing is that he sounds like a baby Snoop Dogg but still to me vince staples seems to have this kind of charismatic quiet swaggy badass tough-talking persona down tools hit like pool sticks the way IQ shit Oh as far as Earl goes he's hard to make heads or tails of sometimes occasionally on doors he'll come through with a song where the intentions are very very clear Chum where he's getting incredibly personal talking about his non-existent relationship with his father growing up a whole series of things burgandy delves into his current mind stay and sort of has him dealing with his fans in a way hearing them say dude we don't care how you feel we just want bars and Sunday seems kind of like a tender personal moment for Earl as well dealing with some of the love and some of the turbulence going on in his life due to drugs or just the trouble he's been getting in or his fame and music career however to me this song has an incredibly weak hook not only do the lyrics not really jump off the page to me but it's delivered with absolutely no enthusiasm whatsoever there are moments where I kind of wonder whether or not Earl wants to be here but I think what really ends up killing this thing is that when we drift away from the more focused tracks and get into songs they just have one loose bar after another the album becomes a little shallow and kind of forgettable and there are moments like this where lyrically earl is an interesting emcee other spots where he says his mama raised him a prophet and instead of rhyming that with prophet he rhymes it with dollar incentive which of course does not rhyme but you get it I also dug the line where he said he spits blizzard as' and then goes to eat venison with Saint Nicholas it's moments like this where he really reminds me of MF DOOM where you have this guy putting himself into these weird ridiculous abstract situations where he's just doing something that's kind of evil or villainous but delivery wise even though he has flow he is just such an unenthusiastic and just kind of lackluster guy to listen to for the length of an entire LP he doesn't bring a lot of different ideas and a lot of diversity to the table at least when it comes to his rap style I don't really feel like this is going to be an explosive release for Odd Future because of how narrow the appeal of this album is and I think in a way it could kind of be a grower if it weren't for the fact that when I dig deeper into the LP there's not much to find other than some witty word play here and there other than that this LP kind of delivers up the same sort of cocky violin blunt blowing immaturity that a lot of odd future releases do just maybe with a bit more talent and focus I did like this thing I just think it's too underwhelming and full of potholes for me to be completely enamored with it but what do you think of Doris do you love this album do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anthony Fantana Earle Doris forever

No okay hi everyone anthem if you did we're gonna do a review of the new no age album an object these guys were a California rock duo this is their latest full-length LP no age if you haven't heard of them they're definitely a group you want to get into if you're into lo-fi rock lo-fi indie noise rock and pop punk music I would say that no age delivers rock and roll that has this high extreme amount of energy and just distortion and volume but also there's a lot of sound play in their music too with some ambient interludes outros and intros legitimately beautiful walls of ethereal guitar sound and even though toying with a lot of these Styles has earned them comparisons to great acts like Dinosaur Jr Pixies My Bloody Valentine and slow dive Sonic Youth Mission of Burma there isn't one band I would specifically say that no age sounds exactly like whether you're talking about stuff coming out today or in the past because I don't feel like there's a single band in the underground right now that is making noise rock with the same kind of detail especially ethereal details that no age typically does even at their most lo-fi back in 2007 their songs were incredibly textured and colorful loaded with sounds that were conjured from guitar feedback guitar freak-outs loops effects I feel like the band really kind of came to a pinnacle with their sound and broke out with it on the 2008 album nouns an LP that I loved from front to back it's exciting thrilling tense sort of simple melodically but still very catchy the band ended up following that album with a pretty decent EP that in my opinion showed them working with a better recording quality some newer sounds I felt like there were some really interesting progressions coming over the horizon but the band's next album everything in between unfortunately I did not enjoy it quite as much as nouns or even weirdo rippers I felt like there was an element of reservation on this album that kind of held it back and kept it from being as exciting it was almost as if a lot of the sounds that no age was working with instead of being wild and free and kind of having this visceral rock edge were kind of a little more mid paced and subdued in order to make a recording that was a bit cleaner a little more sterile this album made me kind of miss their low fire which is exactly the direction they're headed in on this new LP and it's really difficult for me to describe this LP describe how it makes me feel because it's sort of threw me for a loop it is a bit of a surprise because I feel like no age does go for a different vibe on this album and and truly part of me really enjoys it but part of me is is very cold toward it as well as far as positives go that give this album personality this is definitely no wages most abstract album it's one of the more experimental albums in their catalogue I would say it's actually pretty even tempered and consistent to a lot of no ages previous material featured tracks that were very very slow soft or ambient and then bunched those up with tracks that were high speed aggressive and fiery while neither was necessarily bad it's it's not like no age really found a way to make these slower tracks meld with the faster tracks without making them kind of feel like just merely a forgettable interlude or a detour on this LP with nearly every song on here featuring pretty much the same recording quality it's made for an album that doesn't really feel like a mix tape or a compilation it feels like a bit of a concept LP a part of me also kind of wonders whether or not this will go down as no ages most boring album and if not that it's definitely the album so far in their catalogue that has the narrowest appeal because when I think about it in respect to previous material songs like come on stimming for example which is maybe the only track on this LP that I could say has legitimate single potential even when no age tries to be ferocious on this album I'm not really finding a lot of power in this decidedly muddy muddy muddy recording I would say there's actually kind of a dullness that persists throughout this entire LP again I use the word decidedly because no age has worked in low fight sounds before I would say that there was kind of a similar dullness to their last album I'm positively sure they're conscious of how this album sounds how this album feels and how it might impact how people perceive their music I feel like deadening the sounds a little bit has actually made the music on this LP really live up to the title that they have given this album an object because it really makes me feel like I'm listening to music that I can only observe like it's this thing that is separate for me and it's like sitting there on the table and I'm just kind of staring at it as opposed to the music on nouns which I felt was something that just bled out of my speakers like a giant destruction rainbow of psychedelic punk magic Jake Jake Jake Jake Jake Jake scrambling my emotions and consciousness and object feels like so much more of a static experience it's like that soundscape side overtakes the Punk side on this LP and takes a group of songs written in no ages typical style for the most part and then melts them fries them strips them back a little bit until we have these tracks that feel brittle and and warm and crackle II and claustrophobic I really feel like no II just trying to get back to the basics of their earlier stuff and make a recording that has some kind of beauty in its flaws in its shortcomings in its damaged and broken presentation and emotionally there's a little bit of a shift on this album too because for sure there are a lot of songs on this album that are pretty moody and Dean spuntz vocals on this LP definitely convey that as well he's not really singing in that high-pitched nasally Yelp that blazed so many of the Bands faster tracks on previous LPS though there are occasions where it seems like he reaches up into that register for the most part he is kind of howling in this much lower voice on this album and it seems to have a bit of a sadness to it even though there have been a lot of changes on this LP I feel like no age is stuck to their pretty simple melodies songwriting and vocal style and I feel like they're putting just as much detail sonically noise wise into their tracks if you compare to their last full-length album I just feel that it's a lot less obvious because this is not a loud record you've got all of these sounds being squeezed into this incredibly small space and a lot of them drown each other out really cancel each other out because again this recording is very opaque and another thing that sort of takes the guts right out of these tracks or takes the excitement out of them is that a lot of tracks here forgo drums completely or have drums that are just barely audible and while that has led to an object being way less intense part of me loved hearing the band move into this slightly more difficult territory whether it be with somber songs like I won't be your generator which lyrically I feel are very sort of depressing Dean sort of singing on this track about not allowing this person to abuse him or sort of get power from him anymore whether that be through having control over him or some kind of emotional command and while he doesn't come across as the best vocalists of all time on this record he falls very short of that mark I feel there's an element of vulnerability kind of in the same way that a Kimya Dawson song would be admirable and the song and impression a track where Dean does reach up into that more nasally register of his though he is singing a little deadpan on this track there is still some kind of painful emotion in his voice and I just love the tenderness of the ambient sounds kind of floating in the background behind his voice against these very subtle guitars and the strings I assume their strings that pop in toward the end of the track they just really seep in very slowly they're gorgeous one of the more beautiful moments I've heard on a sub pop record this year there are some louder tracks on here but they can be just as off-putting honestly the opening track on here no ground has just one single snare just mixed up with all these very fuzzy fuzzy guitars it has such a demo kind of feel to ABBA teens lower vocals all over this tracker kind of wild they're weird while it did catch me in this really weird way at first I found it to be slightly alluring the more I listen to it there's a pretty audible bassline on this track too which is also kind of a rarity and no ages music and the song lock box I like that we have this weird floor tom role mixed very loudly in the left channel and that's pretty much all we're hearing in terms of percussion for a majority of the track I just have to emphasize again how strict back this album feels it's like no age was really trying to take everything they had built up until this point smash it down into its most basic foundation and then just redo everything it's like we've really hit the reset button and while has led to some interesting ideas sounds noises and aesthetics and I feel that no age has delivered some songs on here that do shine past the low fire recording they didn't need a good recording to be captivating there are still songs on this record that I do find to be completely boring and Moe's like we would have benefited from some more vivid or more high-pitched or distorted sounds I'm kind of feeling a strong five to a light six on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to Thomas and Vice Portugal who I recently did a little interview with you can find a link for that in the description box only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anthony Fantan oh no age forever

oh hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new washed out album para kasam washed out is the solo pop music project of music producer Ernest green who gained widespread attention across the music blogosphere in 2009 via some songs from his life of leisure EP and not only did the songs on this EP have a smooth psychedelic sexy dreamy vibe to them but a lot of music fans were labeling this aesthetic that Ernest was going for as being a new genre entirely chillwave and while I did find the album he followed up that EP with to be kind of dull appoints I definitely saw the appeal I think washed-out is maybe the only chillwave era artist who actually stuck to his guns but was actually able to mature the sounds that he was working with with some more interesting instrumentation better sound quality and production I think the only point where this album really lacked for me was in the songwriting which had a serious sameness quality to it throughout the LP though the grooves on this thing were great now as far as para kasam goes I would say that washed out strong points continue to be strong points and weak points continue to be weak points really though I would say on this album in comparison with washed-out slash full-length LP there is more attention to melodic detail and instrumental detail I would say there's more instrumental diversity on this thing too in a lot of ways it feels like washed out as usual and yet there are spots where it feels like he's pursuing some different musical ideas but trying to capture them in this washed out aesthetic like on the first full-length track off of this thing it all feels right with these up stroked acoustic guitars it totally has a reggae vibe to it even the percussion feels subtly tropical at points I think the only thing hiding this influence a little bit is just how hazy the song is and a very blatant psychedelic pop influences especially coming from these string melody on this thing the sudden break in momentum that the song hits after the verse is kind of this slow syrupy chorus while I don't really care for the sudden transition I do like the contrast of these two parts of the song overall it's a great track kick this thing off even if overall the vocals do feel a little too subdued for me yes I do know that at this point this is Ernest green style this is most likely what he's going to continue delivering on subsequent albums still for the length of an entire album it doesn't convey much of anything to me other than this sense of listlessness or bliss there are points where I do feel a little underwhelmed by the lack of surprises being presented on this thing like the track don't give up which is a nice piece of Balearic be if we're going to look at this thing from a percussive standpoint and the melody on the chorus here is pretty nimble too a lot busier than what you'll usually hear from washed out but in terms of the verses the groove the vocal melody it all feels eerily similar to something he had done on his previous album however the track waitlist to me is is one of my favorites on here because what's happening here to me feels like kind of a rarity from washed-out it is an honest-to-god ballad with the vocal melody really leading the way on this thing as opposed to the beat the very slow spacious drum machines and Cynthia Peggy rose on the track had me feeling like I was listening to this syrupy piece of New Wave I know washed-out has always had very prevalent eighties music influence going on in his tracks but this is the first time where I feel like I'm hearing a sincere re-creation going on here as well as the song fall back with these very tight sixteenth note high hats just very busy beat on this song and this vocal phrasing that really reminds me of Bernard Sumner there are tracks on here that I really enjoy highlights just like the previous few washed out releases but again there are tracks here that I just feel do nothing for me or have this real kind of hollowness to them tracks that I just wish had a bit more body to them a bit more detail the song all I know for example for all intents and purposes to me sounds like the soundtrack to a car commercial nearly every sound in this song has no personality to it if it wasn't for the hazy effects and the vocals I would have never guessed this track was from washed-out the very gentle piano arpeggios and the basic root note bass lines playing out this AED chord progression it's boring I feel like the tracks one chance to redeem itself came around the solo or the interlude that was placed in there which has I'm not sure I can't tell if it's a horn or it's a string or it's just some MIDI instrument either way it just plays a handful of do-nothing notes that really have nothing behind them it's like they were randomized I think the closing track on this LP has a similarly basic vibe to it too that keeps what could have been a pretty good song from being an interestingly detailed or layered beautiful piece of music again and again and again washed out misses out on making some good tracks because the effects kind of take hold and the music really sits on the back burner again Ernest green excels when it comes to creating vibes moods addition out grooves if those are your primary focuses if those are your primary interests and music then forget what I say and get this record because there's definitely some better production and a better sound set and an interesting array of influences going on with this LP from psychedelic pop to Caribbean music and dream pop as well as synth pop and new wave however on the musical side of things there's just not enough diversity on this LP really and these very subtle changes in influence and instrumentation just aren't enough to keep this album from feeling a little monotonous I'm really kind of feeling a strong 6on on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to Flying Lotus and eclectic only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anthony fan tanto washed out forever

toad endless night hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd going to do a review here of the new toad album endless night toad a Phoenix rock band this is their latest album mini album sort of though this release is pretty short doesn't even hit that 30 minute mark it is a pretty powerful piece of rock music now these guys even though their name is towed in great big fat capital letters it's actually an acronym for take over and destroy which is actually a pretty badass name and as much as I love hearing something extraordinarily fast heavy melodic or moving being well-rounded in all of these things is is kind of a quality that is overlooked at times especially on the more extreme side of music however endless night takes all these things into a cow across its five songs tracklist it's a group of songs that work in multiple layers crushing heavy riffs that occasionally play slow are fast at times especially when the band is going down a more black metal road with the blast be drumming but a lot of the time you're going to find this LP two going at kind of a mid pace a lot of the grooves that these riffs are playing have a bit of a heavy metal vibe to them or maybe even some rock and roll swagger there's some organ and in synth keys that feel kind of retro throughout this LP as well really kind of bringing in a cult vibe to the table and on top of all of that take over and destroy has a pretty strong sense of melody to melodies that are dark and are sinister and romanticized again pulling from that very clear black metal influence throughout these songs which also plays out on the blast beats that I mentioned tremolo picket ours and some vocals that are really really ferocious bloody raw sometimes blending elements of black metal and death metal it's a really seamless blend at times of these extreme and not so extreme Rock styles and really when I think of all the genres that influence take over and destroy I really am reminded of Keller talk however take over and destroy comes to a very different musical conclusion as they feel much darker and I feel have a little bit more finesse at times like the very chilling pianos and hellish melodies that play at the title track on this LP even though the very crushing guitarists that come in after this intro change the vibe alot images of candles and pentagrams and hooded cloaks and demons all of this is sort of still at the core of takeover and destroys music and they continue to emphasize this vibe when the songs get heavier with some harmonized guitar leads some very sort of deadpan background vocals or even some very morbid lyricism which at times can be kind of cosmic and otherworldly really this LP feels like a sort of short soundtrack to a very devilish ritual and hooks on this LP can be kind of catchy as well especially with how ferocious and just over-the-top the vocals can be and I'm also digging how when toad attempts to stretch some of these songs out past the six-minute mark there are some successes as well with some really climactic builds of harmonious guitars and synthesizers which make for a pretty haunting contrast from the pummeling riffs they usually back up most of the verses on this LP now I love the ambition that makes toad write some of these longer songs or just in general right multi-phased songs but occasionally it doesn't go over amazingly like on the intro track from the selfie as well as the second track where I feel like some of the slower moments instantaneously just bust right back into the heavier spots kind of ruining or not even really fully appreciating the tension that these slower spots had built up to this point still the latter half of this LP is pretty solid the third track howling house is pretty interesting in its transitions it has this 68 intro breaks into these 44 blast beats goes back into the 68 on the latter part of the track over the 68 time signatures bringing some really moody guitar leads the song boundaries of flesh has some fast and sludgy riffs that remind me of some of more intense moments from high on fires last full-length LP but also brings in some cleanly sung and eerie vocals on the second half of the song that worked pretty nicely and as far as the closing track goes on this thing maybe one of the more cohesive songs on this thing with this very slow intro a lot of heavy metal guitar heroism going on in the middle of the song and then the very end just building up to this huge climactic finish overall I dug this LP a lot it's loud it's heavy its destructive it's memorable with the vocals and melodies just burning just on fire throughout this thing however I did end up kind of wanting more material more length from not only some of these songs but just this album in general and I guess there is one more thing that kind of hinders this LP for me it's that there is kind of a sameness that runs across many of these tracks in terms of some of the vocal deliveries or just the sound and the vibe of these riffs and it is a positive and that it makes this help you feel really cohesive and maybe even conceptual in a sense but then again there is kind of a stagnation to that as well I'm feeling a decent too strong 7 on this thing if you've given them a listen what did you think did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's X this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to friends family God country and apple pie only the strong subscribe all mistakes were in church you know Anthony Fantan Oh toad forever you

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internets busiest music nerd and it's time for you review the new modern life is war album fever hunting modern life is war as an Iowa rock band and their music fit into a pretty huge trend that dominated hardcore music about ten years ago around that time there was a mountain of different bands that were approaching hardcore punk music with a much more melodic edge and when I say melodic I don't necessarily mean the kind of clean vocally sung and kind of accessible poppier choruses that that were brought to the table by bands like that religion or propoganda or ignite as good as those bands are not really the direction I'm talking about I'm talking more through harmonious guitar chords really slow and anthemic lead guitars or solos like most hardcore punk music intensity still played a vital role in the records that we're talking about here from modern life is war and these other bands but this intensity played out and more of a dramatic some would say melodramatic way than it did just an outright aggressive one things were a bit more subtle darker emotionally dismal groups like life long tragedy and ruin her and have heart killing the dream and and more than life took a similar approach as well it hasn't been that long since modern life is wort disbanded they disbanded after their third full-length LP however it almost feels like an eternity when you consider how fast the musical trend they survived in grew and sort of dissipated however not to crap on the efforts of a band like modern life is war or their legacy because I feel like what happened ten years ago in hardcore music was a necessary step to a lot of the very dark dismal heavy and melodic hardcore influenced music that we're hearing today especially when you consider that heavier and darker is exactly how they left us on their last full-length album before they disbanded her sort of went on this hiatus but there are a few surprises with this LP for one this album not as heavy as their last full-length it seems almost as if they've abandoned that idea of being a heavier band and have gone back to just sort of a more dynamic sound and also I would say the other surprise with this LP is that it doesn't really sound like modern life is war ever stopped making music I know from the ALF years in between albums isn't an immense amount of time but still considering that they disbanded for a moment and now our back it's like they never even skipped a beat really the vocals are as impassioned as ever the guitars sound really melodic the drums have a nice intensity to them really propel the songs I feel like maybe there's a little bit more dynamics to modern life as war instrumentally honestly I see them having more in common with groups like Touche amor or La Dispute at this point now as far as the tunes on this LP go when the instrumentation I feel like modern life is war has really delivered they're doing what they usually do just as well as they've ever done it and I've done it and I love the driving bass in the shrill guitar chords on the track health wealth and peace just an example of how with simplicity modern life is work and pulled together these really captivating punk anthems anthemic again is just another word I keep using on these tracks like the anthemic descending guitar chords on the second half of the track chasing my tail just about this epic and it's just huge and as ambitious as you can expect a really rough heavy and intense just frothing at the mouth punk song to be and the very slow-moving guitar peji us on tracks like blind or breeding are just another example of how a band like modern life is war feels more sad and moody in their punk aesthetic than they are aggressive the title track on here is a really pretty and sinister stick in my head melody that I dig and the song dark water has a kind of bluesy characteristic to the riff that they play throughout this song which is not completely surprising considering that this same band had a really interesting take on these songs Stagg early on their last full-length if there is a weakness on this LP for me it's really kind of lyrically I feel like on this album maybe more than other modern life is where LP is the lyrics are a little too repetitive or don't fully explore some of the topics that I feel like are being addressed here I almost feel as if tracks like media for example which is a great song with fantastic guitars really pumps me up but the refrain on this thing could really have been I don't know shortened and then the extra space could have been used to bring together some verses or just another part of the refrain that would have been memorable or would have sort of talked more in depth about what exactly the song is trying to highlight same goes for old fears new frontiers or brothers-in-arms forever and there are other points on this LP where I feel like where for example we're talking about time slipping away friends slipping away and even though I am saddened by the idea of this I think with age I've kind of just grown okay with this fact and we're not really that upset by it things change however groups like Lotte dispute for example are able to take things like letters being sent to you but coming less and less and being stranded in your hometown and sort of taking all these specifics and turning it into a poem that I think for even somebody who isn't directly connected with that emotion or feeling that way can just it rushes back you know feels powerful still having said all of that I think that modern life is war has pulled together a really good comeback record and if you're looking for a punk album that has a lot of passion has a lot of melody and has
